Tank.description: Leveraging its high mixed natural bulk and resistances to many prominent offensive types, along with its natural ability to ignore Knock Off and status conditions, Mega Venusaur becomes a decent Mega Evolution for a myriad of team compositions. Sludge Bomb allows Mega Venusaur to threaten Fairy-types like Tapu Koko, Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant. Earth Power is required to hit Heatran and also to prevent the likes of Gholdengo, Sneasler, and Kartana from taking advantage of Mega Venusaur’s STAB options. Giga Drain hits most foes that resist its coverage moves like Landorus-T, Mega Lopunny, and Great Tusk for neutral damage. It also gives more healing opportunities, since Synthesis has low PP. The given EVs allow Mega Venusaur to outspeed Landorus-T and Moltres, potentially KOing them with a crucial Giga Drain or Sludge Bomb, respectively. Mega Venusaur pairs well with teammates with a strong offensive presence, since they can fall back on its defensive capabilities to break throughout the course of a game. Specifically, since Mega Venusaur is unfazed by Knock Off and status conditions, it can reliably check Pokemon like Toxapex and Ferrothorn. Wallbreakers like Iron Valiant and Kartana can utilize its defensive capabilities and ability to switch into their checks to wallbreak more consistently. However, Mega Venusaur is very vulnerable to entry hazards, so allies that can remove them like Rotom-W and Great Tusk make great partners. Mega Venusaur is also easily checked by the likes of Zapdos and Tapu Lele, which can threaten it with powerful STAB moves, and Skarmory, which ignores damage from its moves. Some good teammates that can cover and check these include Gliscor, Heatran, and Gholdengo; in exchange, Mega Venusaur can check opponents like Rotom-W and Landorus-T. Finally, since Synthesis heals less in rain, Mega Venusaur has reduced longevity against this archetype despite its resistance to Water, so it will need additional support from teammates like Gastrodon and Rotom-W to cover this.

Drought Wallbreaker.description: Mega Charizard Y stands out as a powerful wallbreaker thanks to its high Special Attack and its ability, Drought. Weather Ball is recommended for its high damage, perfect accuracy, and ability to pressure rain teams by doing magnificent damage to Pelipper in rain. Flamethrower is a great alternative, allowing Mega Charizard Y to maintain its STAB move outside of sun, but at the cost of being slightly weaker than Weather Ball. Fire Blast is less reliable due to its accuracy but serves as a powerful nuke, capable of OHKOing Gliscor after Stealth Rock and guaranteeing a 2HKO against Galarian Slowking and Garchomp. Roost lets Mega Charizard Y heal off potential Stealth Rock damage and act as a soft check to Mega Scizor and Rillaboom. Under sun, Solar Beam hits instantly and provides excellent coverage to obliterate bulky Water-types such as Alomomola, Rotom-W, and Slowbro. Scorching Sands 2HKOes Heatran and pressures Toxapex, Gouging Fire, and Raging Bolt while also having the chance to burn threats that can switch into Mega Charizard Y's moves, like Garchomp and Mega Tyranitar. Focus Blast enables Mega Charizard Y to OHKO Mega Tyranitar while still allowing it to hit Heatran effectively, but its poor accuracy and ineffectiveness against Toxapex make it a less recommended choice. Entry hazard removers like Great Tusk, Kartana, and Landorus-T allow Mega Charizard Y to come in more often, as it is incredibly weak to Stealth Rock; Great Tusk in particular benefits from sun thanks to Protosynthesis boosting its Attack, letting it break past foes like Mega Latias and Dragonite for Mega Charizard Y more easily. Mega Charizard Y’s mediocre Speed and below-average bulk leave it vulnerable to revenge killers like Mega Diancie, Mega Lopunny, and Garchomp. Therefore, defensive switch-ins such as Great Tusk, Alomomola, Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Galarian Slowking create great synergy with Mega Charizard Y. Weavile is a fantastic partner for its ability to beat Dragon-types such as Mega Latias, Garchomp, and Dragonite; it also appreciates Mega Charizard Y forcing foes like Alomomola to Tera Dragon. Raging Bolt also serves as an excellent partner, benefiting from Mega Charizard Y's Drought with Protosynthesis, which boosts its Special Attack, allowing it to break through Pokemon like Garganacl more easily.

Dragon Dance.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Utility.description: Clefable‘s unique combination of an amazing ability in Magic Guard, solid bulk, and good defensive typing allow it to function as an amazing utility Pokemon and a solid defensive check to a myriad of offensive threats such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Dragonite; it’s also a good status and Knock Off absorber. Clefable is an effective Stealth Rock user due to its ability to threaten or cripple the majority of entry hazard removers, including Great Tusk, Kartana, and Tornadus-T, forcing out the former and paralyzing the latter two. Knock Off lets Clefable cripple switch-ins like Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Galarian Slowking, severely cutting into their longevity. Thunder Wave helps Clefable incapacitate offensive threats like Volcarona, Heatran, and Ogerpon-W. Trick alongside Sticky Barb gives Clefable a more efficient tool in wearing down its sturdier switch-ins like Heatran, Ferrothorn, Gliscor, and Toxapex, opening up avenues for its teammates to sweep more easily. Leftovers can be used instead of Rocky Helmet to provide some passive recovery, letting Clefable check Mega Medicham more easily. Tera Water lets Clefable take a Steel-type attack in a pinch and is a generally useful defensive type. Clefable works best on bulkier teams that can take advantage of its durability and role compression. Entry hazard setters such as Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Gliscor are solid partners, as they can form a potent hazard-stacking core, which is especially solid alongside Clefable’s Knock Off. The latter especially works well with Clefable, as it can pivot in on Heatran and Galarian Slowking, which both force Clefable out. Offensive Pokemon such as Volcarona, Mega Lopunny, and Weavile are also good partners, as they appreciate Clefable crippling their checks like Heatran and Toxapex. While Clefable’s bulk is solid, it is often not enough to function as a sole check to the powerful offensive threats in the tier, so it is best to pair it with a sturdier teammate like Toxapex, Slowbro, or Galarian Slowking that can scout wallbreakers and spread out the defensive load.

Defensive Pivot.description: Slowbro's valuable defensive typing, solid physical bulk, and remarkable longevity between Slack Off + Regenerator make it a very reliable defensive pivot, capable of consistently checking dangerous physical attackers like Urshifu-R, Mega Medicham, Mega Lopunny, and Mega Swampert. The combination of Teleport + Future Sight lets Slowbro support its offensive teammates by providing them free entry while forcing immense pressure on a prospective switch-in. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Slowbro to switch freely in spite of any entry hazards. Tera Steel can be used in a pinch to check foes like Mega Tyranitar and Tapu Lele, letting it either cripple them with a Scald burn or use Teleport into a revenge killer. Wallbreakers such as Urshifu-R, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta appreciate Slowbro's FuturePort to bring them in safely on foes like Ferrothorn and Garganacl and subsequently pressure their switch-ins like Great Tusk, Clodsire, and Toxapex with the impending Future Sight. Specially defensive Pokemon such as Ting-Lu, Clodsire, and Heatran help cover threats like Tapu Koko, Volcarona, and Gholdengo, respectively; in return, Slowbro deals with Ground- and Fighting-types like Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Urshifu-R. Corviknight, Tornadus-T, and Buzzwole cover other physical attackers such as Kartana, Meowscarada, and Weavile that Slowbro struggles with; the former two remove entry hazards with Defog in case Slowbro is forced to take a Knock Off, while the latter can make use of Future Sight to wallbreak easier.

Assault Vest.description: 84 Attack EVs let Muk OHKO a Mega Charizard Y at full with Rock Slide.

Pink Blob (Defensive).description: Thanks to its gargantuan Eviolite-boosted special bulk alongside a lack of relevant weaknesses, Chansey stands firmly as a formidable wall that blanket checks the metagame's special attackers, including Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Volcarona. Toxic lets Chansey whittle them down, especially in conjunction with repeated Seismic Tosses, while Thunder Wave punishes poison-immune foes like Heatran and Toxapex and cripples switch-ins such as Mega Lopunny and Kingambit. Chansey can provide cleric support with Aromatherapy, especially since it can switch into status users like Clodsire and Rotom-W thanks to Natural Cure. However, Stealth Rock can be used if the team lacks another user, and Chansey can do it sufficiently by outlasting common entry hazard removers such as Great Tusk, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T. Tera Steel allows it to reliably check Tapu Lele, Hatterene, and Tornadus-T, and it prevents Chansey from being poisoned. Chansey is generally reserved for bulkier builds that appreciate its defensive profile and can tolerate its overall passivity. Sturdy walls like Skeledirge, Buzzwole, Skarmory, and Corviknight can cover physical attackers like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Kartana for Chansey. Skeledirge's Unaware helps against setup sweepers like Mega Scizor and Mega Charizard X that attempt to use Chansey as setup fodder, while Corviknight's Defog alleviates Chansey from entry hazard pressure that would overwhelm it easily. Knock Off and Trick absorbers like Clefable, Toxapex, Mega Scizor, and Gholdengo make sure that Chansey can keep its valuable Eviolite; Additionally, Mega Scizor helps deal with Psyshock Tapu Lele, Gholdengo threatens Calm Mind Hatterene, and Calm Mind Clefable overwhelms Heatran—especially if it's paralyzed—all of which are special attackers that can beat Chansey one-on-one.

Offensive.description: Zapdos serves as a powerful wallbreaker while also sporting solid bulk in conjunction with Static to threaten common revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. In rain, it becomes even stronger, boasting a Water-type Weather Ball to threaten Gliscor, Garganacl, and Landorus-T and more accurate Thunder and Hurricane. Volt Switch allows Zapdos to freely pivot while doing very good damage, especially due to common Ground-types like Landorus-T and Great Tusk being greatly threatened by Hurricane. Hidden Power Ice allows Zapdos to hit Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Gliscor for massive damage. Heat Wave is used to surprise Ferrothorn trying to come in on a Thunderbolt or Hurricane as well as consistently threaten Mega Scizor. Flyinium Z allows Zapdos to KO chipped defensive Pokemon that would otherwise be out of range of a Hurricane. If Zapdos is not using Flyinium Z, then it can Tera Flying for stronger Hurricanes. Pokemon like Iron Boulder appreciate offensive Zapdos, as it can rack up chip damage on Pokemon that would otherwise annoy Iron Boulder, such as Garganacl, Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Ferrothorn. For rain teams, Zapdos can do good chunks of damage to Pokemon rain teams would otherwise struggle to break, such as Rotom-W and Ferrothorn. Galarian Slowking can comfortably take any of Zapdos's moves, and then set up a Future Sight, threaten to poison with Sludge Bomb, or pivot out into an offensive check with Chilly Reception. However, if Galarian Slowking is predicted to switch in, then Volt Switch can be used to gain momentum, allowing Zapdos to switch into something that can threatens Galarian Slowking like Great Tusk, Landorus-T, or Gliscor. Bulky Pokemon that resist one of Zapdos's STAB moves and then threaten Zapdos, like Heatran, Landorus-T, and Gliscor, can prove to be annoying. To help with this, Zapdos appreciates having teammates such as Gliscor and Ferrothorn.

Bulk Up.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder untill an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Defensive.description: Moltres’s main niche comes from its variety of useful qualities making it a prominent defensive Pokemon. It is a defogger that can threaten Gholdengo; a check to common Stealth Rock setters like Great Tusk, Heatran, and Garchomp; and a deterrent to contact attackers like U-turn users, Kartana, and Mega Lopunny. However, its main weakness lies in its overreliance on its Heavy-Duty Boots—although Tera could let it drop its weakness to Rock, Tera is usually better spent on other Pokemon, so Moltres still fears Knock Off from opponents it would otherwise check, like Iron Valiant, Landorus-T, Kartana, and Mega Scizor. Tera Water is used to ease the matchup against rain, becoming a check to common rain abusers like Basculegion-M, Mega Swampert and Barraskewda and threatening to burn them with Flame Body. Tera Ground instead grants a resistance to Stealth Rock and Stone Edge from Choice Scarf Landorus-T and an immunity to Volt Switch from Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Rotom-W and Thunderbolt from Iron Valiant. Mystical Fire is chosen over Flamethrower, as its Special Attack drop is useful to more easily check Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Mega Charizard Y, and Gholdengo. Scorching Sands is used to beat Heatran and also deter physical attackers looking to set up due to its high burn chance. Hurricane allows Moltres to OHKO Great Tusk and Mega Lopunny while heavily denting Volcarona and is useful in general as a powerful STAB option, U-turn allows Moltres to function as a pivot, pivoting out on foes like Heatran and Garganacl, and Toxic allows Moltres to punish Pokemon such as Hippowdon, Ting-Lu, and Garchomp looking to soak up its STAB options. The given EVs allow Moltres to survive two Frustration from Mega Lopunny without Stealth Rock damage. However, there are still many opponents that can pressure Moltres, like Garganacl, Toxapex, and Tapu Koko. Moltres thus pairs well with wallbreakers that can take advantage of such switch-ins to come in, like Tapu Lele or Iron Valiant. Moltres also dislikes having its Heavy-Duty Boots removed, so teammates that can absorb Knock Off are appreciated, including Mega Scizor and Gliscor.

Nasty Plot.description: Galarian Moltres serves as a unique setup sweeper on hyper offense teams thanks to its ability to effortlessly set up Nasty Plot against metagame staples such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo with its solid defensive and offensive profile. Agility allows Galarian Moltres to outpace dangerous revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Choice Scarf Kartana. However, Taunt is also a valuable alternative to Agility in order to shut down defensive checks like Haze Toxapex and Unaware Clodsire while also preventing common status spreaders like Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Heatran from limiting its sweep. Heavy-Duty Boots negates chip damage from entry hazards and allows Galarian Moltres to set up more reliably. Flyinium Z is used in order to quickly eliminate bulkier threats such as Toxapex and Ferrothorn without risking a miss due to Hurricane's poor accuracy; however, this leaves Galarian Moltres unable to Terastallize against threats such as Tapu Lele. Sitrus Berry is another option that lets Galarian Moltres maintain its health and trigger Berserk twice. Galarian Moltres is a great user of Terastallization, using Tera Steel to set up on its standard checks in Tapu Lele, Toxapex, Tapu Koko, and Clefable. Tera Steel also lets it resist many forms of priority including, but not limited to, Mega Lopunny's and Mega Medicham's Fake Out, Weavile's Ice Shard, and Mega Scizor's Bullet Punch. However, Galarian Moltres's new weaknesses mean that it has a harder time setting up on Mega Lopunny, Heatran, and Landorus-T while also being susceptible to other forms of priority like Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Galarian Moltres enjoys dual screens support to let it set up incredibly easily, so Tapu Koko makes for a great partner as both a solid pivot and dual screens setter. Galarian Moltres can struggle against threats such as Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, Kingambit, and Mega Tyranitar, so Mega Scizor and Hawlucha make for great partners to handle its checks offensively; in return, Galarian Moltres can break through Pokemon such as Toxapex, Landorus-T, and Gholdengo for them. Fighting-types such as Urshifu-R, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta are also good partners that can check threats like Heatran, Kingambit, and Garganacl for Galarian Moltres. Iron Valiant, in particular, also synergizes well with dual screens Tapu Koko, making it a fantastic cleaner after Galarian Moltres has broken through the opposing team.

Dragon Dance + 3 Attacks.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Dragon Dance.description: Dragonite is a very powerful setup sweeper due to its amazing ability, natural bulk, and high Attack stat. It can often turn common threats like Ogerpon-W, Volcarona, Urshifu-R, and Rillaboom into setup fodder. Extreme Speed allows Dragonite to revenge kill sweepers like Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. Earthquake hits Rock-types like Garganacl and Glimmora, as well as Steel-types like Heatran and Archaludon. Roost enables Dragonite to active its ability multiple times, which allows it to set up more easily and serve as a long-term check to Ogerpon-W and Volcarona. Ice Spinner is an alternative, mainly for Flying-types like Zapdos and Landorus-T. Outrage with a +1 or +2 Attack boost is almost unstoppable, especially with Dragonium Z, which can OHKO Defensive Zapdos and has a chance to OHKO Alomomola with minor chip at +1. Tera Normal gives Extreme Speed a STAB boost to revenge kill the likes of Iron Valiant and offensive Volcarona, as well as Ogerpon-W and Mega Lopunny with entry hazards on the field. It also removes Dragonite's weakness to common super effective coverage moves like Moonblast, Ice Beam, and Stone Edge. Dragonite appreciates teammates like Mega Diancie and Iron Boulder to weaken the opponent's Flying-types and check fragile revenge killers like Greninja. Dragonite is relatively susceptible to status and Stealth Rock. Even with Heavy-Duty Boots, Dragonite can still benefit a lot if it is paired with teammates like Zapdos and Great Tusk, since they can make Dragonite less concerned about Knock Off. Gliscor and Clefable are both good partners as well because they can absorb Knock Off and status moves.

Cosmic Power.description: Mew is a potent late-game wincon that can bolster its already impressive defensive profile with Cosmic Power, shrugging off most hits after a few boosts. Mew has near-perfect coverage with Stored Power and Body Press, with the latter able to crucially smash Steel- and Dark-types like Kingambit, Ferrothorn, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile, which would otherwise exploit it. Covert Cloak is a must for Mew to avoid being worn down by Garganacl’s Salt Cure and help against being burned by Scald from the likes of Toxapex. Tera Poison grants Mew an immunity to Toxic, removing the biggest roadblock to its sweep, allowing it to beat the likes of Heatran, Clodsire, and Gliscor. The given EV spread lets Mew outspeed non-Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Since Mew is very passive while setting up, it is prone to being overwhelmed by Pokemon like Urshifu-R and Garchomp or used as setup fodder by Pokemon such as Gholdengo and Tornadus-T, thus making it crucial that Mew sets up or Tera at the right time. As such, teammates like Toxapex, Skarmory, and Zapdos are much appreciated to help check those Pokemon for Mew. Taunt from Tornadus-T and Heatran and Trick from Choice Specs Iron Valiant shut Mew down, so having teammates like Gliscor, Gholdengo, and Mega Scizor help deal with them. Gholdengo, in particular, is hard for Mew to deal with, as it can boost at a faster rate than Mew while taking a fully stacked-up Stored Power with ease and being immune to Body Press. Therefore, teammates that can threaten or Pursuit trap it such as Garchomp and Kingambit are very appreciated. Toxapex uses Haze to sit on Mew and forces it to Tera to avoid Toxic, thus overwhelming or removing Toxapex with the likes of Gholdengo, Garganacl, and Heatran allow Mew to set up and win.

Pivot.description: Galarian Slowking has valuable qualities in being a defensive pivot due to its high special bulk, Regenerator, and great defensive typing; these qualities let it check, cripple, and pivot around threats like Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Volcarona, and also pressure and take advantage of defensive Pokemon like Toxapex and Garganacl with Future Sight. Sludge Bomb lets it deal with Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele while also letting it fish for poison on Pokemon like Zapdos and Moltres. Chilly Reception lets Galarian Slowking mess with weather like rain and sun while also letting it pivot around offensive Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y, Tapu Koko, and Iron Valiant. Thunder Wave lets Galarian Slowking cripple Pokemon who would use it as setup fodder such as Volcarona and Tornadus-T. Ice Beam lets Galarian Slowking significantly dent Ground-types like Landorus-T and Gliscor, while Flamethrower can let it hit Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor in a pinch. Slack Off gives Galarian Slowking reliable recovery to handle the aforementioned threats long-term. Tera Steel lets Galarian Slowking handle Tapu Lele even better and let it pivot out into a teammate or damage them with either Flamethrower or Sludge Bomb, respectively. 0 Speed IVs let it pivot out last against slower Pokemon like Ferrothorn. More physically defensive sets can be used as well, but even with Galarian Slowking's great special bulk, it cannot sponge special attacks as well as specially defensive. Tera Water lets it take a Fire Blast from Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona and Thunder Wave in return, or pivot out on them as well. Galarian Slowking is very vulnerable to Pursuit trappers like Mega Tyranitar and Weavile, so teammates that can handle them such as Ting-Lu and Mega Scizor are well appreciated. Urshifu-R and Mega Lopunny are notable abusers of Future Sight from Galarian Slowking, appreciating it pressuring and exploiting their checks like Toxapex, Moltres, and Zapdos.

Assault Vest.description: With an Assault Vest equipped, Galarian Slowking functions as an incredibly bulky pivot that easily checks Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, Mega Charizard Y, and Kyurem. Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn, while Scald lets it punish foes with a potential burn, most notably Pokemon like Landorus-T and Mega Tyranitar. Ice Beam lets it immediately threaten switch-ins like Gliscor, but leaves it vulnerable to Heatran. Earthquake can be used to hit Heatran, but using it does come at the cost of not having the utility of a move like Scald. 248 HP EVs optimize Regenerator recovery, and in tandem with 224 Special Defense EVs, it lives 2 Fire Blasts from Mega Charizard Y after Stealth Rock. Tera Steel and Tera Water improve matchups against Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Mega Charizard Y, respectively. Both types also give it a Pursuit neutrality, leaving it less vulnerable against Pokemon like Mega Tyranitar and Weavile. Galarian Slowking appreciates Pokemon that can absorb Knock Off to preserve its Assault Vest, so Pokemon like Mega Lopunny and Gliscor make for good teammates. The latter forms a good core with Galarian Slowking, punishing and gaining information on passive and offensive Pokemon throughout a game due to the duo's prolonged longevity. Entry hazard removal helps Galarian Slowking not be ruined by Spikes, so Defoggers like Moltres and Zapdos help it not be chipped as much.

Bulky Swords Dance.description: The given defensive EVs allow Mega Scizor to always avoid a 2HKO from 112 Defense EVs avoid a 2HKO from Mega Lopunny's Close Combat after Stealth Rock, while 20 Speed EVs outspeed uninvested Heatran.

Offensive 2 Attacks.description: Offensive Mega Scizor sacrifices a portion of its defensive prowess in exchange for enough power and Speed to be able to lure certain Pokemon while still being a powerful cleaner and revenge killer. Close Combat is useful on Mega Scizor, as it is able to OHKO Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Archaludon after a Swords Dance boost while additionally being Mega Scizor's most powerful option against Pokemon such as Raging Bolt, Alomomola, and opposing Mega Scizor. On the other hand, Knock Off sacrifices the immediate power of Close Combat in exchange for permamently weakening pokemon such as Zapdos, Volcarona, and Toxapex by removing their Heavy-Duty Boots, and is also Mega Scizor's strongest move against foes such as Volcarona, Galarian Slowking, Zapdos, and Tapu Lele. Sand Tomb is an alternative option, allowing Mega Scizor to trap and KO Toxapex to the benefit of teammates such as Urshifu-R and Volcarona while retaining Mega Scizor's ability to deal with Heatran. The given EV spread allows Mega Scizor to avoid being 2HKOed by an unboosted Tapu Lele's Focus Blast after Stealth Rock while also outspeeding defensive Landorus-T. The ability that Close Combat Mega Scizor has to lure Heatran is greatly appreciated by Pokemon such as Volcarona and Serperior, whereas Knock Off variants can permanently hinder Pokemon such as Volcarona and Zapdos to the benefit of teammates such as Iron Valiant and Kartana. Mega Scizor struggles to deal with Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y, Gouging Fire, and Zapdos, all of which can outspeed and threaten it with an OHKO or safely pivot around it, while Iron Defense Zamazenta is able to set up alongside Mega Scizor and beat it. Tapu Lele can also block Bullet Punch with its Psychic Terrain, negating a potential sweep. Teammates such as Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko are able to offensively check the Flying- and Water-type Pokemon that Mega Scizor struggles with, such as Zapdos and Toxapex. Raging Bolt able to check Mega Charizard Y and Ogerpon-W, whereas Tapu Koko overrides Tapu Lele's Psychic Terrain with its own Electric Terrain. Rockium Z variants of Zamazenta can enable Mega Scizor to sweep by luring and removing Zapdos. Toxapex and Ferrothorn are able to defensively answer aformentioned Zamazenta, Volcarona, and Raging Bolt, which are able to set up in front of Mega Scizor, and Ferrothorn specifically is able to set up entry hazards that heavily benefit Mega Scizor. Defog users such as Gliscor and Tornadus-T, are invaluable partners to Mega Scizor, due to its susceptibility to entry hazards and its inability to hold Heavy-Duty Boots to mitigate this issue.

Rain Wallbreaker.description: Kingdra is a potentially deadly wallbreaker on rain teams thanks to its brutally strong STAB moves as well as its respectable natural power that, when combined with Swift Swim, lets it claim KOs left and right, especially against offensive teams. It, however, faces significant challenges in trying to accomplish this; namely, its poor bulk and mediocre typing mean it is revenge killed rather easily if it predicts an opponent incorrectly or misses an attack. It is also easy to scout because of Choice Specs locking it into a move. Hydro Pump, when boosted by Tera Water and in rain, becomes nigh-unwallable, heavily denting even stopgaps like Ferrothorn and rendering attempts to scout Kingdra using Alomomola or Toxapex highly dangerous. Draco Meteor is the other of Kingdra's incredibly powerful STAB moves, crushing common switch-ins like the aforementioned Alomomola, Ogerpon-W, Toxapex, and Raging Bolt. Flip Turn lets Kingdra keep momentum against the bulkiest of special walls like Chansey and Assault Vest Galarian Slowking that can take it on. Surf is a good mid-ground option that forgoes some immediate power for reliability, letting Kingdra revenge kill Pokemon like Iron Valiant in Rain while not having to worry about Hydro Pump's sometimes maddening accuracy. Pelipper is a must for Kingdra, as it is entirely unviable out of Rain. It also provides entry hazard control with Defog as well as a slow U-turn to give Kingdra the most chances at breaking through opposing teams with its breathtaking power. Nasty Plot Tornadus-T is a great partner for Kingdra, as it threatens the Grass-types that trouble it such as Ferrothorn and Rillaboom. In return, Kingdra helps to overload Steel-types like Heatran and Corviknight easily under rain, paving the way for other teammates. Zapdos is another option to take care of bulky Water-types more directly as well as check Rillaboom long-term. Mega Swampert is another great partner, as the two form a brilliant wallbreaking core that hit each other's checks: Draco Meteor crushes Grass-types like Ogerpon-W, while Mega Swampert beats special walls like Chansey thanks to its incredible physical power. Iron Treads is able to dictate the hazard game on rain teams by both setting Stealth Rock and by removing opposing hazards with Rapid Spin.

Pink Blob.description: Blissey's immense special bulk, useful utility moves, and reliable recovery allow it to function as a niche specially defensive pivot, as it checks threats such as Choice Specs Dragapult and Mega Charizard Y. Seismic Toss allows Blissey to pressure anything that isn't a Ghost-type with meaningful damage. Toxic is the preferred option to cripple Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona. Thunder Wave can also be used to annoy fast threats like Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. It also allows Blissey to status Steel-types like Kingambit, Heatran, and Kartana. Teleport allows Blissey to safely pivot in teammates like Dragapult, Zamazenta, and Mega Medicham. However, Blissey is an acceptable Stealth Rock user if no other fits on your team. Shadow Ball can be considered as a niche option to break Dragapult's Substitutes and chip offensive Gholdengo, but it usually isn't worth dropping other moves. Tera Fairy gives Blissey a Fighting resistance in exchange for negligible Poison and Steel weaknesses, and it reduces the damage it takes from Pursuit users like Kingambit, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. This should be used if Blissey absolutely has to take on a Fighting- or Dark-type like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, or Weavile. Blissey's defensive profile makes it a liability into certain Ghost-types, specifically Dragon Dance Dragapult and Gholdengo. Kingambit is a great option that deals with the former two threats while also benefitting from Blissey bringing it in safely with Teleport. Other wallbreakers like Tapu Lele, Dragapult, Mega Charizard Y, and Mega Medicham also appreciate pivot support and benefit from Blissey spreading Thunder Wave. A switch-in to powerful physical attackers, like Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, Mega Medicham, and Kingambit, is necessary. Options like Toxapex, Slowbro, Skarmory, and Great Tusk can help out on this front. Knock Off is irritating for Blissey, as losing its Heavy-Duty Boots is quite detrimental to its pivoting efforts. Options such as Flyinium Z Tornadus-T and Gliscor can help out in this regard.

Stealth Rock.description: Mega Tyranitar is an excellent option on a myriad of team compositions, sporting great utility with Knock Off and Stealth Rock and providing crucial resistances against many common offensive threats like Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Zapdos. Knock Off allows Mega Tyranitar to remove items from switch-ins such as Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Great Tusk, greatly impeding their longevity. Pursuit lets Mega Tyranitar threaten to trap and remove foes such as Tapu Lele Choice locked into Psychic, Iron Moth, and Heatran. Additionally, the threat of Pursuit forces foes like the Tapu Lele to play quite predictably, easing the burden for teammates such as Galarian Slowking not having to fear Psychic-type attacks lest they be trapped by Mega Tyranitar. A solid matchup into common Defoggers like Zapdos and Moltres allows Mega Tyranitar to proficiently set up Stealth Rock, while Knock Off removing Heavy-Duty Boots allows its own entry hazards to incur damage easier. The given Speed EVs allow Mega Tyranitar to outspeed Rotom-W. Iron Valiant is an incredible teammate for Mega Tyranitar, as Mega Tyranitar can trap and inflict heavy damage or outright remove Clodsire and Galarian Slowking, which are two of the biggest roadblocks for Iron Valiant. Defensively, Alomomola is very common teammate, as it can keep Mega Tyranitar healthy with Wish + Flip Turn and sponge attacks from Fighting-types it fears such as Mega Lopunny and Great Tusk. Gliscor can give Mega Tyranitar trouble, as once its Toxic Orb has been activated, it can switch in consistently without fearing the item loss of Knock Off while clearing Stealth Rock with Defog, so Ferrothorn, Urshifu-R, and Ogerpon-W are good teammates to assist combatting it.

Swords Dance.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Rain Sweeper.description: Mega Swampert is a staple on rain teams thanks to its great typing and Swift Swim allowing it to outspeed a majority of the metagame. Its immunity to Electric-type moves is greatly appreciated for rain teams, which can struggle with common Electric-types in the tier such as Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko. Flip Turn allows it to maintain momentum against checks like Rotom-W and Alomomola while wearing them down. Ice Punch hits Pokemon such as Dragonite, Serperior, and Mega Latias that would check Mega Swampert otherwise. Alternatively, Stealth Rock can be used to take advantage of forced switches on Pokemon such as Garganacl and Galarian Slowking, as well as free up a slot for a teammate like Ferrothorn to run Spikes over Stealth Rock. Superpower is another option, which hits checks such as Kartana, Ferrothorn, and Ogerpon-W. As the premier rain setter in the tier, Pelipper is a mandatory teammate for Mega Swampert, being able to grant it free switches with its ability to act as a slow pivot with U-turn. Ferrothorn is another especially good teammate for Mega Swampert for its ability to switch into the defensive Water-types Mega Swampert has trouble dealing with such as Alomomola, Slowbro, and Rotom-W as well as Ogerpon-W lacking Superpower, and it can also make progress by setting hazards and forcing switches against these foes. Ferrothorn is also able to remove items like Rocky Helmet from Pokemon such as Skarmory, letting Mega Swampert attack more freely, and Heavy-Duty Boots from Pokemon such as Zapdos and Alomomola, making them more easily worn down by hazards. Mega Swampert can also struggle against Grass-types such as Kartana and Rillaboom, which makes Pokemon like Zapdos and Tornadus-T great teammates for their ability to check the aforementioned Pokemon. Mega Swampert also appreciates other Swift Swim users such as Barraskewda as teammates, being able to wear down each others' shared checks such as Ferrothorn and Rotom-W. Archaludon is a good partner, being able to check Grass- and Water-types Mega Swampert has trouble with such as Alomomola, Ogerpon-W, and Serperior. In return, Mega Swampert threatens Ground-types that Archaludon struggles with like Landorus-T and Gliscor.

Rain Setter.description: The ability Drizzle and access to U-turn allow Pelipper to be the best rain setter in the tier, thus a staple on rain teams. 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature allow Pelipper to pivot teammates in safely with the slowest possible U-turn.. Its decent physical bulk alongside Scald lets Pelipper check and threaten to cripple popular offensive presences like Urshifu-R and Mega Lopunny, as well as Stealth Rock setters like Landorus-T and Heatran. Roost keeps Pelipper healthy throughout the course of the game, enabling consistent rain and better longevity against threats such as Urshifu-R. Hurricane can be used to hit foes such as Urshifu-R, Tera Grass Heatran, and most notably, Ogerpon-W, for super effective damage, while Defog is an alternative that removes entry hazards if common partners in Tornadus-T or Zapdos lack it. Tera Ground is used to change Pelipper's 4x weakness to Electric into an immunity to potentially absorb Volt Switch from Tapu Koko or Rotom-W and pivot out. Pokemon that need rain to boost their strength and Speed such as Mega Swampert, Barrsekwda, Battle Bond Greninja, and Urshifu-R are great partners for Pelipper. They particularly appreciate Pelipper being able to bring them onto the field safely and often into a winning position via a slow U-turn. Mega Swampert also serves as a bulky Electric-immune Pokemon that can check Tapu Koko for Pelipper. Other pokemons like Zapdos and Tornadus-T also benefit from the rain Pelipper sets up and can act both as excellent wallbreakers or entry hazard removers. Furthermore, Ferrothorn and Archaludon can take advantage of Pelipper's typing defensively, with the latter's signature move in Electro Shot pairing especially well with rain.

Defensive Magic Bounce.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Swords Dance.description: Huge Power in conjunction with Swords Dance turns Mega Mawile into a fearsome wallbreaker and sweeper, especially with its useful defensive typing, which allows it to force out and set up on metagame staples like Galarian Slowking, Alomomola, and Tapu Lele. Knock Off provides coverage against Fairy-resistant foes such as Toxapex and Ferrothorn, annihilating them after a boost, and severely cripples Heatran. Sucker Punch makes up for Mega Mawile’s poor Speed tier, preventing it from being revenge killed by faster Pokemon like Volcarona, Garchomp, and Mega Medicham. The given EV spread allows Mega Mawile to outspeed uninvested Corviknight. Intimidate is the chosen ability prior to Mega Evolving, letting Mega Mawile set up on physical attackers like Weavile and Rillaboom more easily. Mega Mawile appreciates being brought in safely via slow pivots such as Landorus-T, Galarian Slowking, and Alomomola due to its mediocre bulk. Entry hazard support from Ferrothorn, Hisuian Samurott, and the aforementioned Landorus-T synergize well with Mega Mawile, as they wear down its checks like Heatran and Garchomp into range of a boosted Sucker Punch. Mega Mawile is prone to being revenge killed if its offensive checks aren't weakened, so it pairs well with a sturdy defensive core, such as Toxapex, Gliscor, and Rotom-W. These Pokemon also handle the Fire- and Ground-types that Mega Mawile is most susceptible to, such as Heatran, Volcarona, and Landorus-T. Lastly, due to Mega Mawile’s poor Speed tier, pairing it with speed control like Choice Scarf Kartana, Zamazenta, and Booster Energy Iron Valiant is best.

All-out Attacker.description: All-out Attacker Mega Mawile trades in its sweeping capabilities to be nigh impossible to check defensively with the plethora of coverage options it is gifted with. Ice Punch nails Ground-types like Landorus-T and Gliscor that attempt to pivot into it, while Thunder Punch lets it break through Toxapex and threaten Corviknight and Skarmory. Fire Fang destroys Steel-types like Mega Scizor, Iron Crown, and Ferrothorn, that otherwise shrug Mega Mawile’s attacks off. Knock Off specifically hits Galarian Slowking while also crippling Heatran and Volcarona. Lastly, Focus Punch can be used to completely break through Skarmory while still hitting the aforementioned Steel-types, but it is extremely prediction reliant. The given EV spread allows Mega Mawile to outspeed uninvested Mega Scizor. Intimidate is the chosen ability prior to Mega Evolving, letting Mega Mawile sponge hits from physical attackers like Weavile and Rillaboom more easily. Mega Mawile works best with late-game cleaners that appreciate it punching holes in opposing teams early on, so Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, and Choice Scarf Kartana are amazing partners. Pivots such as Landorus-T, Tapu Koko, and Galarian Slowking also work well to safely bring Mega Mawile in throughout the match. Tapu Koko in particular also boosts Mega Mawile’s Thunder Punch damage, letting it pressure Toxapex and Corviknight harder. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Gliscor, and Ting-Lu are also appreciated, as they wear down Pokemon trying to switch around Mega Mawile’s colorful coverage.

Mega Medicham possesses terrifying wallbreaking power with its sky-high Attack stat, muscling through common defensive pieces like Alomomola, Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Corviknight, and even Dondozo with its powerful STAB combination. Fake Out can chip and pick off faster threats like Iron Valiant and Tapu Koko while putting foes like Diancie before Mega Evolving into Bullet Punch KO range. Ice Punch notably hits Landorus-T and Gliscor trying to pivot around Mega Medicham, as well as threatening Mega Latias and dealing slightly more damage to Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Zapdos. Teammates like Raging Bolt and Ogerpon-W appreciate Mega Medicham taking care of their checks like Ting-Lu, Mega Venusaur, and Ferrothorn. Despite its immense power, Mega Medicham has a mediocre Speed tier, so it is very helpful to have speed control like Choice Scarf Kartana and Landorus-T. Opposing Landorus-T often try to use Intimidate to weaken Mega Medicham, so teammates like Weavile and Kyurem are useful as they can pressure it very well. Since Mega Medicham is very fragile, pivots like Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, Galarian Slowking, Tapu Koko, and Rotom-W all function excellently with it, the latter two of which can notably handle Slowbro for it.

Offensive Utility.description: Mega Banette cements itself as a niche offensive disruption tool for balance and offensive teams with its ability Prankster and its support movepool. Access to priority status moves allows it to wreak havoc when facing offensive Pokemon, such as being able to disrupt with Encore or burn Zamazenta, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Lopunny. It can also switch into status and Fighting-type moves and threaten an Encore or gain momentum against Pokemon such as Calm Mind Raging Bolt and Swords Dance Gliscor, as well as Zamazenta's Close Combat. Mega Banette is no slouch when it comes to offensive power either, as it's able to use its gargantuan Attack stat in combination with Poltergeist to deal immense damage to a majority of the metagame, picking up 2HKOs on most switch-ins that don't resist or aren't immune to Ghost, such as Ferrothorn, physically defensive Zapdos, and specially defensive Corviknight. Destiny Bond allows Mega Banette to force a trade even once it's threatened out, being able to deal with fast threats without priority moves like Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf users like Urshifu-S and Tapu Lele, or setup sweepers that have gotten out of hand such as Swords Dance Iron Boulder and Nasty Plot Darkrai. However, Mega Banette requires a large commitment from its teammates to be able to function, relying on them consistently bringing it in to make the most use of its supportive capabilities due to its lackluster bulk. It also heavily disincentivizes Knock Off, since Mega Banette relies on Poltergeist. Mega Banette fits best on teams that want to keep up offensive pressure as much as possible while also having a good stopgap for setup sweepers like Volcarona and Ogerpon-W. Good partners for it include bulky pivots such as Corviknight, Alomomola, and Galarian Slowking, as they afford it opportunities to threaten foes by using Encore. Additionally, it appreciates support from strong Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Urshifu-R to deal with Dark-types such as Mega Tyranitar, Hisuian Samurott, and Weavile, which resist Poltergeist and are immune its status moves once Mega Evolved, and Garganacl, which effectively resists Poltergeist and is also immune to its status moves.

Utility.description: Mega Latias uses its immense bulk, decent defensive typing, and Spikes immunity to become a consistent utility Pokemon that is able to spread paralysis and cripple Pokemon that would otherwise offensively pressure it such as Mega Scizor and Tapu Lele while also checking threats like Mega Charizard Y and Ogerpon-W. Psychic hits Zamazenta harder and has good neutral coverage, but Psyshock can also be used hit harder against Pokemon like Galarian Slowking and Ogerpon-W when Terastallized. Aura Sphere complements Mega Latias well, hitting Dark- and Steel-types such as Ferrothorn, Heatran, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar. Ice Beam can also be used to hit Ground-types that are able to take advantage of Mega Latias’s passivity, such as Gliscor and Garchomp. Draco Meteor is a niche option that can be used to hit Pokemon like Raging Bolt and Gouging Fire. However, giving up Aura Sphere means Mega Latias has no way of threatening Ferrothorn, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar for consistent damage. Thunder Wave allows Mega Latias to severely cripple setup sweepers and offensive threats like Mega Scizor and Volcarona. Although Mega Latias has Thunder Wave to cripple most of its checks, it has issues with Dark- and Steel types that are able to take advantage of its relative passivity, such as Mega Tyranitar, Heatran, Mega Scizor, and Weavile, especially if not carrying Aura Sphere. Teammates that are able to help against these Pokemon include Toxapex, Zamazenta, and Gliscor, making them good partners. Mega Latias also struggles against Dragon- and Fairy-types that are either faster than it or immune to Thunder Wave, such as Raging Bolt, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele, so teammates that match up well against them like Ting-Lu, Corviknight, and Toxapex are good alongside it. In return, Mega Latias is able to ease the offensive pressure these Pokemon take, using Thunder Wave to cripple their checks like Heatran, Ogerpon-W, and Rillaboom. Mega Latias enjoys entry hazards wearing down its checks such as Mega Scizor and Mega Tyranitar, so Pokemon that set them like Ferrothorn, Clefable, and Gliscor are good teammates.

Calm Mind.description: With access to Calm Mind, Mega Latias is a threatening wincon, using its huge bulk, typing, and Spikes immunity to check and setup against Pokemon like Ogerpon-W, Mega Medicham, and Zamazenta and potentially bowl over teams. Psyshock is used over other Psychic-type STAB moves due to its ability to hit Galarian Slowking harder as well as win against Pokemon that also boost their Special Defense such as Volcarona. Stored Power is another option that allows Mega Latias to boost past Unaware users such as Dondozo and Clefable while also becoming almost impossible to take on defensively after a few boosts. Aura Sphere hits Dark- and Steel-types such as Heatran, Mega Tyranitar, Weavile, and Ferrothorn, all of which would otherwise either completely wall it or remove it with Pursuit. Substitute is another option that allows Mega Latias to avoid status moves that would harm it greatly from the likes of Gliscor, Alomomola, Toxapex, and Galarian Slowking while also taking advantage of Pokemon that are unable to touch it such as Garganacl and Rotom-W. It is recommended that Substitute is always paired with Stored Power and vice versa, as Substitute allows Mega Latias to stack more Calm Mind boosts and make Stored Power much more impending against bulkier teams. Due to Mega Latias needing multiple Calm Mind boosts to be threatening, it can be offensively exploited by Pokemon like Weavile, Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant, which can prevent it from setting up by offensively pressuring it. As such, checks to them like Toxapex, Corviknight, and Zamazenta are good partners. Even with Aura Sphere, Mega Latias still struggles with Dark- and Steel-types like Mega Scizor, Corviknight, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile. Mega Latias also has issues with prominent Fairy-types like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant. Teammates that can pressure these Pokemon like Zamazenta, bulky Volcarona, Heatran, and Zapdos are effective as such. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Gliscor and Ferrothorn also wears down these checks. In return, Mega Latias is able to take on Pokemon that are able to break through the balance teams that its teammates are found on, such as Ogerpon-W, Mega Medicham, and Zamazenta. Corviknight in particular is a very good partner for Mega Latias, as it checks Tapu Lele, Mega Scizor, and Weavile for it and removes hazards. In return, Mega Latias takes Electric- and Fire-types like Heatran, Rotom-W, and Mega Charizard Y.

Wallbreaker.description: Wielding its signature move Luster Purge, powerful coverage to complement it, and a good typing that gives it a favorable matchup against common threats like Ogerpon-W and Zamazenta, Mega Latios is a powerful wallbreaker in the metagame. Aura Sphere is important coverage to hit Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn as well as to KO chipped Mega Tyranitar. Mystical Fire hits the aforementioned Ferrothorn along with Mega Scizor and Iron Crown. Draco Meteor is a powerful nuke to threaten foes like Galarian Slowking after a Luster Purge drop while also immediately threatening other Pokemon like Raging Bolt, Gouging Fire, and Mega Latias. Psychic Noise lets Mega Latios pressure checks that rely on recovery to deal with it, like Heatran and Mega Scizor, while also being a backup STAB attack with sufficient PP compared to Luster Purge. Mega Latios finds itself on many team archetypes including bulky offense and balance due to its versatility. However, it is outsped and revenge killed by Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Darkrai, and Weavile. Thus, teammates that can help with this like fast threats including your own Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant or defensive walls including Heatran and Clefable can help aid Mega Latios. In return, Mega Latios can pressure defensive checks like Heatran and Galarian Slowking for them. Good entry hazard control from allies like Great Tusk and Landorus-T helps, since Mega Latios is somewhat vulnerable to Stealth Rock due to its tendency to switch in and out very often.

Stored Power.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Z-Happy Hour.description: With its 100/100/100 bulk, good defensive typing, and passable offensive stats, Jirachi can function as a Z-Happy Hour sweeper, utilizing the omniboost to its full potential. Stored Power is Jirachi's main attacking move, nailing most foes that do not resist Psychic&emdash;this also allows Jirachi to match up favorably against Toxapex and Clodsire, the two biggest setup stoppers in the tier. Aura Sphere allows Jirachi to deal with Dark- and Steel-types; these include Hisuian Samurott, Mega Tyranitar, and Ferrothorn. Drain Punch is an alternative to 2HKO Blissey, which otherwise walls Jirachi, and keep itself healthy with recovery when fighting foes like Heatran. Iron Head serves as a secondary STAB move that can also flinch down foes like Galarian Slowking and Dragonite. A Naive nature should be run when using Drain Punch over Aura Sphere. Jirachi pairs well with allies that can take out its main checks, since it can only set up once and thus has to make it count. Magnezone and Heatran are stellar partners, trapping foes like Ferrothorn and Garganacl that may stand in the way of a Jirachi sweep. Offensive Pokemon like Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Garchomp that may struggle against Fairy-types like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant pair well with Jirachi, as it acts as a soft check to these foes and can use them as setup fodder. Tapu Lele is also notable for providing Psychic Terrain that blocks priority such as Sucker Punch from Hisuian Samurott and powers up Stored Power. Finally, dual screens support from Tapu Koko or Grimmsnarl is beneficial to ease Jirachi's setup, as the damage reduction affords Jirachi more opportunities to successfully use Z-Happy Hour.

Choice Scarf.description: Sporting its infamous Serene Grace-boosted Iron Head in conjunction with a good defensive profile, decent Speed, and a wide utility movepool, Jirachi carves itself a niche as a Choice Scarf user. Iron Head allows Jirachi to easily revenge kill Fairy- and Ice-types, such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Weavile, and has good odds to flinch down any foe that does not resist Steel, as long as they are sufficiently chipped. U-turn allows Jirachi to pivot out into teammates upon forcing out foes, allowing free points of entry for allies such as Ogerpon-W and Zapdos that capitalize on Jirachi's switch-ins in Heatran and Toxapex. Trick cripples most foes that try to switch into Iron Head; foes like Toxapex, Zapdos, Ferrothorn, and Alomomola dislike being locked into a move. Healing Wish gives weakened allies another chance to sweep, additionally curing status like burn and paralysis and offering a point of entry; it is best used on offensive Pokemon, such that they can be used more recklessly early-game and come back later to sweep. Ice Punch alternatively allows Jirachi to hit Landorus-T, Gliscor, Zapdos, and Garchomp particularly hard. Jirachi is best used on offensive playstyles that appreciate its one-off heal and ability to cripple defensive switch-ins. Since Jirachi acts as a soft check to the tier's premier Fairy-types in Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele, allies like Zamazenta and Weavile that dislike them pair well with it, as they can threaten Jirachi's checks in Heatran, Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Slowbro. Jirachi also struggles to revenge kill Mega Gyarados, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Scizor, especially once they set up, so allies like Ferrothorn and Corviknight are needed to act as sturdier checks. Finally, Jirachi is easily exploited by foes like Mega Charizard Y, Mega Scizor, and Garchomp, as all of them can switch into Iron Head and can ignore Trick provided the latter has a Z-Crystal. Allies that can take advantage of them such as Tapu Koko, Iron Moth, and Weavile make for good partners.

Rain Wallbreaker.description: Floatzel is an incredible wallbreaker on rain teams, making use of its decent Attack stat powered by its Choice Band. Low Kick hits Ferrothorn and Ice Spinner hits Dragapult and Dragonite more reliably. However, because of Tera Water, its Water-type moves are all boosted considerably, so coverage is often unnecessary. Aqua Jet gives Floatzel priority outside of rain against weakened targets such as Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and Mega Lopunny, and it bypasses Kingambit's Sucker Punch. Tornadus-T and Zapdos all appreciate Floatzel's offensive capabilities, as it deals with wallbreakers such as Dragapult, Mega Diancie, Gholdengo, Zamazenta, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Valiant. Zapdos can reliably check Water-types that counter Floatzel like Slowbro and Dondozo. Tornadus-T can weaken and cripple Floatzel checks in Rotom-W, Dondozo, and Ferrothorn, as Knock Off removes Leftovers from them, making it easier for Floatzel to wallbreak. Offensive partners like Manaphy and Mega Swampert can overwhelm those same Water-resistant Pokemon as well as Dragonite. Ferrothorn can check priority users such as the aforementioned Dragonite and Kingambit, alleviating Floatzel's weakness to them.

Defensive.description: Gastrodon finds itself a valuable role in National Dex primarily off its invaluable Water and Electric immunities, allowing it to handle terrifying rain sweepers such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert and answer Rotom-W perfectly. Scald lets Gastrodon threaten a burn against otherwise safe switch-ins such as Ferrothorn and Dragonite. Toxic better threatens defensive Pokemon such as opposing Gastrodon, Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. Earthquake threatens Pokemon like Heatran, Clodsire, and Gholdengo. Relaxed should be selected as Gastrodon's nature if using Earthquake to not lower its damage output; Bold should be used otherwise. Tera Fairy can be used in a pinch to grant Gastrodon a resistance to Fighting against Urshifu-R and Barraskweda and a Dark resistance against Kingambit. The given EV spread maximizes Gastrodon's physical bulk to better take on the likes of Floatzel, Mega Swampert, and Urshifu-R. Gastrodon fits best on balance and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its defensive qualities while being able to supplement its passivity with offensive wallbreakers. Pokemon such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo can switch into Grass-type coverage from Pokemon like Kartana and Ferrothorn; In return, Gastrodon provides entry hazard support to wear down answers such as Mega Tyranitar, Kingambit, and Clodsire. Strong, fast wallbreakers like Mega Diancie, Iron Valiant, and Zamazenta love having Gastrodon as a fallback measure against the myriad of Water-type revenge killers on rain such as Floatzel and Mega Swampert. If Gastrodon opts to use Spikes, it likes having Stealth Rock setters such as Heatran and Mega Diancie as partners to form an effective entry hazard-stacking core.

Offensive.description: Mega Lopunny is one of the best offensive pivots in the metagame and can function as great speed control due to its high Attack and Speed, its unresisted STAB move combination with Scrappy, and U-turn. It outspeeds every unboosted Pokemon except for Zamazenta, allowing it to pressure fast foes like Darkrai, Weavile, and Ogerpon-W. Fake Out puts many foes like Tapu Koko, Mega Diancie, and Ogerpon-W into the range of an OHKO, and it can stop setup sweepers like Iron Valiant and Iron Moth after they're weakened or by sacrificing teammates to allow Mega Lopunny to use Fake Out multiple times. U-turn enables Mega Lopunny to pivot out on checks like Landorus-T, Alomomola, and Toxapex, while Quick Attack allows it to pick off weakened setup sweepers when paired with Fake Out; especially when they manage to reach a sweeping position. Teammates like Ogerpon-W, Raging Bolt, and Hisuian Samurott benefit from Mega Lopunny threatening Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn. Raging Bolt especially appreciates Mega Lopunny bringing it in against walls like Alomomola and Corviknight, while Hisuian Samurott can set Spikes with Ceaseless Edge to chip foes like Great Tusk for Mega Lopunny. Teammates with Future Sight support like Galarian Slowking and Iron Crown also pair well with Mega Lopunny, making it easier to break through foes like Toxapex. Mega Lopunny can be annoyed by Rocky Helmet on Landorus-T, Static users like Zapdos, and Flame Body users like Volcarona, so Knock Off support from Tornadus-T, Kartana, and Landorus-T, as well as partners that can threaten them, like Ogerpon-W, are greatly appreciated. Mega Lopunny switches in frequently due to its role, which makes it naturally weak to entry hazards, meaning it benefits from teammates like Landorus-T and Rotom-W that can clear them. Mega Lopunny also appreciates entry hazards from its teammates like Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Hisuian Samurott, since it forces many switches and can easily clean weakened foes.

Offensive Stealth Rock.description: Swords Dance Garchomp serves as a fearsome wallbreaker and effective Stealth Rock setter, capable of blowing past common defensive staples such as Toxapex, Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Zapdos with its combination of Earthquake and a coverage option in Outrage or Stone Edge, in tandem with their respective Z-Crystal. Garchomp's positive matchup versus the latter three in turn allow it to set and maintain Stealth Rock very well. Additionally, Garchomp’s solid natural bulk and good typing lets it find opportunities to set up on Pokemon like Heatran, Volcarona, and Iron Moth. Outrage with Dragonium Z gives Garchomp a stronger option that can notably OHKO Landorus-T at +1 while also OHKOing Great Tusk and Zapdos at +2. However, the Z-Move can require prediction if the opponent has a Fairy-type lest Garchomp become trapped into Outrage and easily revenge killed by foes such as Mega Diancie, Tapu Lele, and Iron Valiant. In comparison, Stone Edge bolstered by Rockium Z provides a more consistent attack for Garchomp outside of its Z-Move while hitting foes such as Skarmory, Celesteela, and Corviknight harder than its Dragon-type Z-Move counterpart. Offensive teammates who can exploit the wallbreaking capabilities of Garchomp such as Mega Lopunny, Kartana, and Dragonite are appreciated, while teammates such as Volcarona, Iron Moth, and Ferrothorn give Garchomp a solid option to fall back on in the face of revenge killers such as Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele.

TankChomp.description: Tank Garchomp maximizes the value of its ability and great movepool to check Hisuian Samurott, Mega Lopunny, and Iron Boulder. Garchomp aims to punish physical attackers and force progression with entry hazards and Toxic. Dragon Tail lets Garchomp make the most of entry hazards laid by itself or teammates, being able to force foes to take damage at random if they lack Heavy-Duty Boots. Additionally, it can also be used to deny setup sweepers like Ogerpon-W, Iron Boulder, and Dragon Dance Gouging Fire lacking a Dragon-type STAB move. Garchomp can effectively lay both Stealth Rock and Spikes due to a positive matchup versus common hazard removal options such as Zapdos and Rotom-W while also dissuading Great Tusk from using Rapid Spin, as it will take serious chip damage from Rough Skin and Rocky Helmet. Toxic is another way to avoid passivity; it can be used to wear down foes such as Landorus-T, Alomomola, Zapdos, Great Tusk, and Dragonite. Tera Ghost is best used for deny Rapid Spin or to change its typing to survive other wise super effective hits such as Mega Diancie's Moonblast and Mega Medicham's Ice Punch. 56 Speed EVs are enough to outrun Modest Heatran. Mega Tyranitar is a solid partner, being able to remove Landorus-T and Great Tusk's Leftovers with Knock Off, which allows Garchomp to wear them down more easily with Toxic and Rough Skin in tandem with Rocky Helmet. Mega Tyranitar can also remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Alomomola and certain variants of Great Tusk, letting Garchomp's entry hazards rack up more damage. Garchomp really appreciates Alomomola’s Wish passing because it lacks a source of recovery. Garchomp's matchups against other Defoggers such as Corviknight, Gliscor, and Tornadus-T make it hard to keep hazards up at times, so teammates that can help with these Pokemon such as Rotom-W, Ferrothorn, and Zapdos are appreciated alongside it. Galarian Slowking proves very useful to Garchomp because of its ability to check common Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant, which usually force out Garchomp. Galarian Slowking also invites in many Pokémon that can give Garchomp an opportunity to get up Spikes such as Landorus-T, Heatran, and Iron Boulder.

Loaded Dice.description: Garchomp is a decent setup sweeper that can use the combination of Loaded Dice and Scale Shot to boost and deal damage at the same time. Fire Fang hits Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Corviknight, OHKOing the first two at +2. Tera Steel grants it the ability to ignore Toxic and set up on passive foes like Alomomola and Galarian Slowking, while Tera Fire gives Fire Fang a STAB boost and allows Garchomp to become immune to burn from foes like Rotom-W and Moltres. Both Tera types flip the match up against Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele, both of which can heavily threaten hyper offense teams which Loaded Dice Garchomp mostly finds itself on. Teammates like Volcarona, Raging Bolt, and Urshifu-R appreciate Garchomp threatening foes like Dragonite, Clodsire and Toxapex. Garchomp requires support to set up and sweep due to its typing and Defense drops from Scale Shot, so it is very helpful to have dual screens support from Tapu Koko and Grimmsnarl. It also struggles against common threats like Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Weavile, which makes Mega Scizor and Iron Valiant good partners with it. Landorus-T can pivot around Garchomp pretty easily, which makes Mega Scizor a good teammate since it can frequently force Landorus-T in and wear it down. Unaware users like Dondozo can completely shut down Garchomp, so it benefits a lot from immediate breaking power from teammates like Raging Bolt and Tapu Lele, the latter of which can also protect it from priority moves.

Mixed Attacker.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Defensive.description: Hippowdon is a bulky Ground-type wall and Stealth Rock setter able to switch into threatening offensive Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Mega Charizard Y. It can find plenty of time to set up Stealth Rock and spread chip damage with Toxic and its ability Sand Stream. Sand Stream also allows Hippowdon to disrupt opposing weather, which is bolstered by its positive matchup against every other weather setter. Toxic notably nets a ton of chip damage on Defoggers attempting to get rid of Hippowdon's Stealth Rock and Ground-Immune Pokemon switching into Earthquake, such as Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, and Mega Charizard Y. Hippowdon can Terastallize into the Steel typing to avoid Toxic in addition to Grass-, Water-, and Ice-type attacks while maintaining its sand immunity and Stealth Rock resistance. Even beyond the simple type matchup chart changes, it allows Hippowdon to more easily check its targets such as Tornadus-T, Tapu Lele, Zapdos, and Mega Diancie. Maximum Special Defense EVs are ran due to Hippowdon having more valuable special targets than physical, namely the aforementioned Pokemon. Mega Lopunny and Tornadus-T appreciate Hippowdon's presence, as it checks both Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Zapdos while setting up Stealth Rock to help wear down their checks. Defensively, Hippowdon supports Pokemon such as Garganacl and Skarmory; Garganacl appreciates the sand and its attached benefits and Skarmory appreciates the sturdy Ground-type anchor and special wall. Hippowdon struggles to fend off strong physical attackers like Kingambit, Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Mega Gyarados. For this reason, it pairs exquisitely with strong physical walls such as Skarmory and Buzzwole. Hippowdon also suffers from a Spikes vulnerability, meaning it appreciates Defog support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Zapdos.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Weavile is a great wallbreaker with its high Speed, STAB combination with limited switch-ins, and powerful Pursuit to threaten plenty of foes like Galarian Slowking, Blissey, and Mega Latios. It forces out many offensive staples like Ogerpon-W and Tornadus-T while threatening common defensive pieces like Landorus-T, Gliscor, Zapdos, and Galarian Slowking. Ice Shard picks off weakened setup sweepers like Dragonite and Tera Grass Volcarona as well as slower priority move users like Raging Bolt and Rillaboom. Pursuit eliminates foes like Mega Latios, Galarian Slowking, and Tapu Lele locked into Psychic-type moves, as well as chipping foes forced out by Weavile like Tornadus-T, Dragonite, and Zapdos. Tera Dark boosts the power of Knock Off, allowing it to muscle through common switch-ins like Toxapex and Ferrothorn, as well as punishing foes like Mega Latias and Tornadus-T staying on Weavile with a stronger Pursuit and removing its weakness to Stealth Rock. Teammates like Mega Latios, Tapu Lele, Volcarona, and Zamazenta appreciate Weavile trapping Galarian Slowking, while Zamazenta additionally enjoys Weavile's ability to pressure Zapdos and Mega Latias. Raging Bolt also pairs well with Weavile since it likes to have Weavile take care of Ground-types like Gliscor and Landorus-T and it can threaten bulky Water-types like Alomomola and Toxapex for Weavile. Choice Band Weavile is fragile to Stealth Rock, so it is very helpful to have teammates like Rotom-W and Tornadus-T to remove entry hazards, both of which can also pivot Weavile in against the likes of Galarian Slowking, Mega Latios, and opposing Rotom-W.

Offensive.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Choice Scarf.description: Magnezone carves itself a niche thanks to Magnet Pull, which allows it to trap and remove Steel-types such as Mega Scizor, Kartana, Ferrothorn, and Skarmory, potentially forcing the latter three to Terastallize so teammates such as Kartana and Tapu Lele can beat them. Volt Switch lets Magnezone maintain momentum while eliminating foes such as Skarmory and chipping Heatran, which cannot be trapped and removed consistently. Alternatively, Tera Blast + Tera Fighting lets Magnezone remove Kingambit, potentially forcing it to Terastallize as well. Hidden Power Fire hits foes such as the aforementioned Mega Scizor, Kartana, and Ferrothorn. Toxic is another alternative that punishes switch-ins such as Gastrodon, Ting-Lu, and Hippowdon, though it can be difficult to justify over other alternatives, as it hinders Magnezone's effectiveness as a trapper. Magnezone should only Terastallize when it can trap and eliminate Kingambit, since teammates such as Dragapult and Dragonite take advantage of Tera better. The given EV spread allows Magnezone to survive an unboosted Sacred Sword from Kartana. Teammates such as Dragonite and Kartana appreciate Magnezone removing foes such as Skarmory and Ferrothorn, allowing them to sweep easier. The former can also safely switch into Ground-type attacks for Magnezone, while the latter threatens troublesome Ground-types such as Hippowdon and Gastrodon. Teammates such as Dragapult and Landorus-T provide pivoting support for Magnezone, granting it free entry against foes such as Skarmory and Kingambit to ease prediction. Dragapult in particular appreciates Magnezone trapping and removing Kingambit, allowing it to sweep without fear of being Pursuit trapped.

Physically Defensive.description: Tangrowth serves as a near-immovable physical wall and defensive pivot courtesy of its valuable defensive profile accentuated with Regenerator. It can safely switch into and check physical threats like Mega Lopunny, Mega Swampert, Kartana, and Great Tusk as well as scout for Choice item users such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta. Knock Off provides further utility by crippling switch-ins like Tornadus-T, Toxapex, and Heatran, and it hits Dragapult and Gholdengo super effectively. Hidden Power Fire pressures Kartana, Ferrothorn, and Mega Scizor—the former of which can use Tangrowth as setup fodder otherwise—while Hidden Power Ice dents Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Dragonite. Earthquake is an option to threaten Steel-types hard, including Heatran, as well as Tapu Koko and Clodsire. Stun Spore or Sleep Powder cripples foes like Tornadus-T, Volcarona, and Iron Valiant, preventing Tangrowth from being taken advantage of by them, especially if not running the appropriate coverage move. Nature Power—if paired with Tapu Koko's Electric Terrain—immediately pressures Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y. Rocky Helmet chips down the physical attackers that Tangrowth checks, especially pivot attempts from the likes of Mega Swampert and Landorus-T, but Heavy-Duty Boots makes it a sturdier pivot in the face of entry hazards. Tera Steel improves Tangrowth's matchup against foes like Weavile, Tornadus-T, and non-Close Combat Mega Scizor, and it prevents it from being crippled by Toxapex, Clodsire, and Glimmora's poison. Teammates like Clodsire, Heatran, and Garganacl compensate for Tangrowth's exploitable special bulk by checking Pokemon such as Volcarona, Tapu Lele, and Tornadus-T, respectively; in return, Tangrowth handles the likes of Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Mega Swampert. Due to its reliance on Regenerator for longevity, non-Heavy-Duty Boots variants enjoy hazard removal support from teammates such as Tornadus-T, Rotom-W, and Great Tusk, with Tornadus-T in particular forming a sturdy Regenerator core with Tangrowth.

Assault Vest.description: Assault Vest Tangrowth is a solid defensive pivot that checks threats such as Iron Valiant, Mega Diancie, and Kartana thanks to its typing, Regenerator, and well-rounded bulk. Knock Off cripples common switch-ins such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, Tornadus-T, and Volcarona, both impairing their longevity and increasing their susceptibility to entry hazards. Earthquake hits the likes of Heatran, Iron Moth, Kingambit and Gholdengo. Alternatively, Sludge Bomb can be used instead to hit Fairy-types like Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele while threatening to cripple switch-ins like Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y. Focus Blast can also be used to snipe Kingambit, or even Rock Slide to remove unsuspecting Volcarona that try to set up on the switch—the effectiveness of both options are highly matchup dependent, however. Hidden Power Ice hits bulky Ground- and Dragon-types in Garchomp, Landorus-T, Dragonite, and Gliscor, while Hidden Power Fire hits Steel-types such as Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Kartana. Tera Steel is preferred to turn Tangrowth's common weaknesses into resistances, helping it sponge Ice coverage from Weavile, Baxcalibur, and Mega Swampert and Hurricane from Tornadus-T and Zapdos. Moreover, it can be used in a pinch to resist Moonblast from Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele. Alternatively, Tera Water turns the tide against threats such as Weavile and Heatran while maintaining Tangrowth's ability to check rain wallbreakers such as Mega Swampert. Tangrowth fits best on bulky offense teams, which appreciate its ability to check Pokemon like Landorus-T, Garchomp, Rotom-W, and Tapu Koko. Heatran receives strong support from Tangrowth, as Tangrowth checks threats such as Great Tusk, Landorus-T, and Garchomp and pivots into foes with super effective coverage against Heatran, such as Tapu Lele and Mega Diancie. In return, Heatran checks Weavile, Volcarona, and Tornadus-T. Toxapex and Tornadus-T both benefit from Tangrowth's ability to pivot into threats such as Tapu Koko and Rotom-W, with the former receiving the same level of support from Tangrowth as does Heatran. This trio comprises a formidable Regenerator core, with Toxapex removing Toxic Spikes and checking Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y, Volcarona, and Weavile, and Tornadus-T providing valuable entry hazard removal to reinforce the longevity of the core. Tangrowth is susceptible to entry hazards, which can often put it into 2HKO range of certain attacks; therefore, it appreciates entry hazard removers like the aforementioned Tornadus-T, as well as Rotom-W. Defensive cores supported by Tangrowth can fall victim to Kyurem as a result of its lethal coverage. Volcarona and Mega Scizor are teammates that can take advantage of Kyurem with their ability to set up and reliable recovery. With Tornadus-T forcing Tangrowth out, Rotom-W and Tapu Koko make for stellar teammates with their resistance to Hurricane and ability to pivot. In return, Tangrowth forces out Gastrodon, which otherwise checks the aforementioned teammates.

Swords Dance.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Choice Scarf.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Nasty Plot.description: Nasty Plot Rotom-W provides a unique blend of defensive utility and wallbreaking potential thanks to its great combination of typing and ability in addition to its versatile move pool. Discharge has a chance to paralyze and cripple bulky switch-ins like Serperior, Tapu Lele, and Dragonite. Substitute keeps Rotom-W safe from status moves like Toxic and generates free turns for it to set up, turning many common utility Pokemon such as Landorus-T, Alomomola, and Heatran into Rotom-W's setup fodder. Volt Switch and Will-O-Wisp can be used as an alternative combination, the former helping Rotom-W keep up the momentum and the latter helping to cripple threats such as Dragonite and Garchomp. However, this combination is less effective for wallbreaking because it makes Rotom-W vulnerable to status moves and forces it to switch out if it needs to use its Electric-type STAB move, losing the boost from Nasty Plot. Tera Ghost combined with Levitate counters several popular Ground-type threats like Ursaluna, Sword Dance Gliscor, and Great Tusk, while Tera Steel and Tera Poison complement Levitate well and let Rotom-W effectively wall utility variants of Gliscor, the former improving its matchup into Tapu Lele and the latter granting it a resistance to common Fighting-type attacks from Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Urshifu-R. 44 Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed uninvested Landorus-T so it can set up Substitute first and dodge Toxic, while the rest of the EVs are dumped into bulk so it can check the aforementioned physical threats better. With most Rotom-W sets being pure utility, this set can often come across as a surprise to the would-be bulky checks to it such as Clefable, Zapdos, and Galarian Slowking, and it can also disrupt the opponent's pace by setting up Substitute and boost with Nasty Plot. However, both of its STAB moves are resisted by Grass-types and Dragon-types, which means it loses to the likes of Ferrothorn and Raging Bolt even after boosting. Serperior and Kyurem especially prey on this set because they both can use it as setup fodder.

Specially Defensive.description: Specially Defensive Heatran is a cornerstone of the metagame, being able to check top special attackers such as Tapu Lele, Volcarona, and Serperior while also remaining a threatening offensive Pokemon. Toxic is valuable on Heatran to wear down Pokemon that can either check it or set up in front of it, such as Alomomola, Rotom-W, Mega Latias, Raging Bolt and Volcarona, whereas Stealth Rock takes advantage of Heatran's ability to act as a blanket check to most special attackers in the tier. In addition, many defensive staples such as Galarian Slowking, Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Tornadus-T are forced to switch out of Heatran in fear of Toxic or Magma Storm, and it can also threaten many common Defoggers such as Zapdos and Corviknight, affording it many opportunities to set up Stealth Rock. Taunt is a powerful option to deny setup from the likes of Mega Latias, which could otherwise set up and eventually muscle past Heatran, while also being extremely synergistic with Heatran's other moves; in combination with Magma Storm, Heatran is able to trap pokemon such as Galarian Slowking, Toxapex, and Zapdos lacking Volt Switch, denying their recovery and Galarian Slowking's Chilly Reception. Additionaly, when paired with Toxic it is able to wear down Alomomola, which is otherwise a major roadblock for Heatran, and allows Heatran to beat it in the long run. Tera Grass provides Heatran with a resistance to Water- and Ground-Type attacks, allowing Heatran to wall Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona variants lacking Bug Buzz while also checking Ogerpon-W, additionally allowing Heatran to trap Gliscor if using Taunt and an alternative spread of 252 HP / 108 SpD / 148 Spe, which allows Heatran to outspeed Gliscor. Heatran is a powerful addition to most defensive structures thanks to its ability to check many special attackers such as Volcarona, Serperior, Mega Latios, and Tapu Lele, whereas its ability to trap Galarian Slowking and Toxapex is greatly appreciated by teammates such as Iron Valiant, Zamazenta, Urshifu-R, and Volcarona.
