Due to lacking both reliable recovery and an immunity to Spikes, Heatran is extremely vulnerable to hazards, and is prone to being worn down during longer battles, thus Alomomola is a powerful boon to Heatran's longevity, allowing it to remain healthy throughout a prolonged match, and is also an exceptional pivot, allowing Heatran to switch in on Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Toxapex that commonly switch into Alomomola, providing Heatran with more opportunities to set up Stealth Rock or wear down the opposing team with Magma Storm and Toxic. Pokemon such as Zapdos, Gliscor, and Ferrothorn are able to check Pokemon such as Zamazenta, Urshifu-R, opposing Gliscor, and Ogerpon-W that Heatran struggles to deal with; the former two also utilize Defog to aid in Heatran's longevity, while the latter is able to set up Spikes to further capitalize on the many switches that Heatran forces.

Offensive.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Stored Power.description: Cresselia serves as a potentially terrifying setup sweeper, using its naturally titanic mixed bulk alongside Terastallization to accumulate multiple Calm Mind boosts, bolstering its Stored Power to incredibly dangerous levels to easily snowball if given the opportunity. Even without Terastallization, it can use its natural typing to withstand attacks from dangerous Pokemon such as Zamazenta, Great Tusk, and Mega Medicham. Hidden Power Fighting is the preferred coverage move to hit Mega Tyranitar and Heatran much harder, while Moonblast provides a stronger hit against the likes of Dragapult and Urshifu-R if Cresselia cannot afford to accumulate multiple Calm Mind boosts. Tera Poison is essential for removing Cresselia's weaknesses to Dark- and Ghost-type attacks from Dragapult, Gholdengo, and Hisuian Samurott while providing less exploitable weaknesses compared to Tera Steel, which makes Cresselia prone to being revenge killed by Fighting- and Fire-types such as Mega Lopunny, Sneasler, Heatran, and Mega Charizard Y. Covert Cloak allows Cresselia to negate secondary effects from Garganacl's Salt Cure and status from the likes of Toxapex, Sneasler, and Zapdos, while Leftovers provides passive recovery that makes Cresselia less exploitable and forced to heal. Maximum Speed EVs allow Cresselia to consistently outspeed Heatran and Gholdengo, which could otherwise irritate it, although more Defense investment could be used instead to better withstand attacks from the likes of Urshifu-R and Zamazenta. Cresselia fits best on either bulky balance or hyper offense teams, both able to provide support in different ways; the former give Cresselia a defensive core to fall back on should its sweep fail, while the latter pressure opposing defensive teams and can provide dual screens support via Tapu Koko and Dragapult to bolster its bulk even further. Both playstyles can reliably keep up Spikes using Skarmory, Clodsire, Mega Diancie, or Garchomp, which Cresselia mandates in order to wear down its checks such as Toxapex, Ferrothorn, and Heatran. Similarly, Knock Off support from the likes of Toxapex and Iron Valiant helps Cresselia pressure the aforementioned checks more effectively. Cresselia has difficulty withstanding rain teams due to them cutting Moonlight's healing, so defensive partners that match up positively against them such as Toxapex and Tera Water or Dragon Garganacl are appreciated. Cresselia struggles with bulkier playstyles that can neutralize it with the likes of Haze Toxapex and Unaware Tera Dark Clodsire, so Pokemon that can break defensive teams such as Swords Dance Gliscor and Gholdengo make for good partners.

Tail Glow.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Darkrai is an incredibly strong wallbreaker with a wide range of coverage moves, allowing it to hit a lot of the best Pokemon in the tier for super effective damage. Focus Blast hits Ferrothorn, Garganacl, Heatran, Mega Lopunny and Mega Tyranitar for massive damage, while Sludge Bomb hits Fairy-types such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Lele, and Tapu Koko. Ice Beam OHKOes Landorus-T and Gliscor. Trick lets Darkrai debilitate defensive Pokemon like Garganacl and Ting-Lu at the cost of weakening itself. Darkrai can use Tera Dark to net a crucial 2HKO on foes like Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Garganacl, as well as OHKOing Ogerpon-W, Tapu Lele, and Galarian Slowking after slight chip with Dark Pulse. Other special wallbreakers like Tapu Lele, Raging Bolt, and Iron Valiant appreciate Darkrai's ability to weaken or KO special walls such as Heatran or Gliscor. Darkrai is liable to being outsped and revenge killed by Pokemon like Booster Energy Iron Valiant, Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Booster Energy Iron Boulder, Mega Lopunny, Tapu Koko, Zamazenta, and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, so a strong defensive backbone with Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Heatran is heavily recommended.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Victini is a potent revenge killer, capable of picking almost any foe to trade with using Final Gambit including Zamazenta and Landorus-T while also having the option to cripple other switch-ins with its remaining movepool. U-turn is useful to pivot out of checks that shrug off V-create like Toxapex and defensive Landorus-T, although Victini should be wary of Rocky Helmet on the latter. Trick is used to cripple tanks like Garganacl and Slowbro, reducing their longevity while receiving Heavy-Duty Boots or Leftovers in return. V-create's explosive power needs little Attack investment to perform effectively, still easily 2HKOing most neutral targets including defensive Volcarona and Tornadus-T. Thus, 248 HP EVs are instead used to maximize the potential of Final Gambit while minimizing damage from Stealth Rock. Tera Fire is used to fuel V-create, notably OHKOing Tornadus-T, and remove Victini’s weakness to Pursuit, but this comes at the cost of a comparably worse defensive typing against foes like Iron Valiant and Zamazenta. Victini's ability to threaten any foe allows it to very easily pivot into wallbreakers like Tapu Lele and Urshifu-R, which appreciate having annoying defensive Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Toxapex crippled or removed with Trick or Final Gambit. Setup sweepers also benefit greatly from Victini's presence, as it can surprise and KO defensive threats that would otherwise impede their progress; allies like Mega Medicham and Garchomp enjoy having threats like Gliscor and Landorus-T removed, and the clean field left after Victini KOes itself also affords them a free point of entry. However, Victini must be kept as healthy as possible to ensure that Final Gambit can OHKO what it needs to. Thus, allies that can soak up Water- and Ground-type moves like Gastrodon and Rotom-W make for valuable partners. Entry hazard removal from allies like Zapdos is also useful to ensure hazards do not hamper Victini’s effectiveness.

Z-Celebrate.description: Victini is a potent user of Z-Celebrate, as its already decent natural bulk and typing greatly appreciate the defensive boosts, not to mention the offensive power gained. STAB-boosted Stored Power easily 2HKOes many defensive foes like Gliscor and even Unaware users including Clodsire and Skeledirge. Searing Shot is another STAB option to target Steel-types like Corviknight and Ferrothorn. Focus Blast allows Victini to target pesky Dark-types like Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu along with Heatran, with its low accuracy somewhat offset by Victory Star. Victini can leverage its bulk to set up on many fast threats such as Mega Lopunny, and its buff after omniboosting lets it survive super effective moves from more passive enemies like Gliscor, making it a perfect fit on hyper offense. It is also naturally resistant to priority moves like Bullet Punch from Scizor, Vacuum Wave from Iron Valiant, and Grassy Glide from Rillaboom. Z-Celebrate Victini pairs well with entry hazard suicide leads like Landorus-T and Garchomp, as their Stealth Rock and potentially Spikes support is invaluable; with Stealth Rock, an OHKO on Tera Water Great Tusk and Ogerpon-W are near guaranteed; Stealth Rock also notably breaks Ogerpon-C’s Sturdy along with stray Focus Sashes. Victini also appreciates teammates like Close Combat Iron Valiant luring Blissey and Tera Dark Clodsire, and they also help soften up Ting-Lu for Victini. Tapu Lele is another useful ally that can boost Stored Power with its summoned Psychic Terrain, which also prevents priority including Mega Lopunny’s Fake Out and Hisuian Samurott’s Sucker Punch for a limited time. After Victini heavily weakens foes and potentially forces them to Terastallize, Tapu Lele can also clean up, since any remaining Psychic-resistant foes would be heavily chipped.

Pivot.description: Victini is a pivot with a unique defensive typing, allowing it to soft check threats such as Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Mega Charizard Y, although its lack of recovery leaves it vulnerable over the course of a long game, even equipped with Heavy-Duty Boots. Instead, Victini makes explosive use of each opportunity it gets to blast through foes with V-create, leaving a massive dent in many defensive cores once it manages to pivot in. Bolt Strike is used for coverage, targeting Water-types like Pelipper, Alomomola, and Toxapex. U-turn allows Victini to pivot out of bad matchups like Great Tusk and Rotom-W or after using V-create, pivoting in teammates to help it wallbreak. Encore can lock greedy setup sweepers like Gliscor and Garganacl into moves like Swords Dance or Iron Defense, allowing Victini to give its ally a free switch in or simply hit something hard with V-create. Toxic is an alternative to wear down defensive threats like Ting-Lu and Landorus-T into range of Victini or an ally and also cripple other switch-ins like Garchomp and Dragonite. Tera Fire cranks up the power of V-create, turning Victini into a wallbreaker capable of scorching most neutral targets for a 2HKO, like Tera Fairy Garganacl and Ting-Lu, and also notably OHKOing Tornadus-T. However, it then loses valuable resistances to Fighting- and Psychic-type moves, leaving it unable to check Tapu Lele and Mega Medicham after Tera. Victini suits bulky offense teams that appreciate its role compression both offensively and defensively. Wallbreakers like Weavile, Urshifu-R, and Mega Charizard Y all appreciate Victini's ability to give them free points of entry with U-turn, and the latter also boosts V-create with sun. However, due to its weakness to Stealth Rock if its Heavy-Duty Boots have been removed, as well as its weakness to Knock Off and Pursuit in general, Victini appreciates having teammates that can beat Dark-types like Mega Tyranitar and Weavile; Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny are good partners to check them and in the latter's case also absorb Knock Off. Victini is also vulnerable to Water-type moves from the likes of Mega Swampert and Basculegion especially when they are in rain, so allies that can soak up these moves like Gastrodon and Ferrothorn are good partners. In return, Victini takes Grass- and Fire-type moves for them, respectively. Finally, Tornadus-T, Landorus-T and Gliscor can help switch into Ground-type moves from the likes of Great Tusk, opposing Landorus-T, and Garchomp, and in return Victini tanks Ice-type moves from Alolan Ninetales and Kyurem for them.

Contrary Sweeper.description: Serperior is a good cleaner due to its excellent Speed tier and the combination of Contrary and Leaf Storm. It has decent natural bulk and a useful defensive typing that helps it find opportunities to switch in and set up against foes like Gliscor and Ogerpon-W. Hidden Power Fire is its most important coverage move for foes like Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, Corviknight, and Iron Crown, all of which could stop Serperior otherwise even after several boosts. Glare provides excellent utility by crippling would-be checks such as Tornadus-T, Dragonite, and Volcarona with paralysis. Substitute, when paired with Glare and passive recovery from Leftovers, enables Serperior to fish for full paralysis and set up against more passive foes like Ferrothorn and Galarian Slowking, and it can even stall out Heatran's Magma Storm PP. The combination of Glare and Substitute often forces faster revenge killers like Zamazenta and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele to accept paralysis if they want to break Serperior's Substitute. Leech Seed is an alternative that enables Serperior to beat threats like Heatran on its own. Tera Steel is a wonderful defensive choice that helps against the likes of Tapu Lele, Weavile, and Flying-types such as Zapdos and Tornadus-T, and it completely shuts down walls like Galarian Slowking alongside Substitute. 56 HP EVs make sure that Serperior can keep its Substitute from being broken by Rotom-W's Hydro Pump and Ferrothorn's Power Whip. Tera Blast with an EV spread of 252 SpA / 4 SpD / 252 Spe and Tera Ground can be chosen over Substitute to hit foes like Heatran and Galarian Slowking, while Tera Rock trades Serperior's ability to break past Heatran and Galarian Slowking to beat Mega Charizard Y and Volcarona as well as Flying-types like Zapdos, Moltres, and Flyinium Z Tornadus-T. Wallbreakers that benefits from speed control like Urshifu-R, Tapu Lele, and Mega Medicham appreciate Serperior paralyzing faster foes like Darkrai, Tornadus-T, and Iron Valiant with Glare. Specially defensive Pokemon like Heatran and Galarian Slowking can give Serperior a hard time, especially when it's unable to Terastallize, so it is very helpful to have teammates like Landorus-T that can threaten them. Mega Tyranitar and Weavile can both provide Pursuit support for Serperior to pressure Galarian Slowking and Mega Latios, and both of them can also threaten foes like Zapdos and Tornadus-T.

Choice Scarf.description: Hisuian Samurott is a great wallbreaker that can also set Spikes with Ceaseless Edge, allowing the team to make progress easier. Razor Shell provides a strong STAB move with a nasty chance to drop the foe's Defense, while Aqua Cutter has perfect accuracy and doesn't make contact, eliminating the risk of Static versus Zapdos and Rocky Helmet versus Landorus-T. Knock Off allows Hisuian Samurott to remove items, especially Heavy-Duty Boots users like Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Alomomola. Flip Turn allows for pivoting while doing decent STAB damage. Sacred Sword allows Hisuian Samurott to 2HKO Ferrothorn and OHKO Mega Lopunny, Darkrai, and Mega Tyranitar. Tera Water lets Hisuian Samurott 2HKO defensive Zapdos and OHKO Mega Medicham most of the time. Tera Dark allows Hisuian Samurott to OHKO Galarian Slowking and Tapu Lele. Tera Poison is an alternative choice, providing a resistance to Fighting-type coverage from Pokemon like Iron Boulder and Mega Lopunny, Fairy-type coverage from Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant, and U-turn from foes such as Landorus-T. Wallbreakers such as Tapu Lele, Darkrai, and Urshifu-R appreciate Hisuian Samurott's ability to chip foes with Ceaseless Edge. Other Spikes setters like Ferrothorn and Gliscor are able to run different moves, as Hisuian Samurott can set Spikes itself. Hisuian Samurott is very frail, and it can have trouble switching in safely, so have pivots that can help with this, such as Landorus-T, Corviknight, Tapu Koko, and Alomomola. Despite using Choice Scarf, Hisuian Samurott is outsped and OHKOed by Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, Booster Energy Iron Valiant and Iron Boulder, and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R, so checks to these like Heatran, Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Zapdos help a lot.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Hisuian Samurott is a very threatening wallbreaker that provides invaluable utility to its team with the Spikes laid by Ceaseless Edge. Black Glasses boosts Hisuian Samurott's Ceaseless Edge and Sucker Punch to further heights, allowing it to have an easier time breaking through foes such as Toxapex, Alomomola, and Ferrothorn with the former while also giving it an easier time dispatching of revenge killers like Kartana and Iron Moth with the latter. Protective Pads lets Hisuian Samurott avoid contact effects from Ferrothorn, Zapdos, and Moltres which could otherwise stop or significantly hinder its ability to wallbreak. Tera Dark further amplifies the power of Hisuian Samurott's Dark-type STAB attacks, allowing it to OHKO targets like Mega Medicham with Sucker Punch without Black Glasses while dealing massive damage to defensive cores which could otherwise shrug off Ceaseless Edge even while boosted, such as Zapdos and Skarmory. Alternatively, Tera Poison provides a useful defensive typing that can turn the tables on foes such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant, as well as deny Toxic from Alomomola and turn it into setup fodder. Offensive teams that appreciate Hisuian Samurott's ability to punch holes in opposing defensive structures while laying Spikes to help them break such as Kartana, Mega Diancie, and Tapu Lele make for good teammates. Defensive teams featuring Dondozo have no trouble with taking boosted Ceaseless Edge, so Tapu Koko and Ferrothorn are good teammates to help with this weakness. These two also assist with ensuring Alomomola and Toxapex are no problem for Hisuian Samurott, since they can otherwise threaten with a potential Toxic or Scald. Additionally, opposing offensive teams can make it hard for Hisuian Samurott to find its footing due to its middling Speed stat, so Mega Lopunny and Mega Medicham can assist in these matchups while appreciating the Spikes set versus more balanced styles. Teammates who effectively use Knock Off such as Tornadus-T, Weavile, and Ferrothorn are great teammates as they can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes like Toxapex, making them more susceptible to the Spikes set by Hisuian Samurott's Ceaseless Edge.

Sand Rush Sweeper.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Sun Sweeper.description: With Chlorophyll, powerful STAB options in Solar Blade and Close Combat, along with a respectable base 105 Attack stat, Hisuian Lilligant can function as a powerful sun sweeper. It pairs well with the main sun setter, Mega Charizard Y, as it can switch into and threaten Mega Charizard Y’s checks such as Hippowdon, Heatran, and Clodsire; in return, Mega Charizard Y beats its checks like Gholdengo and Mega Scizor, if Hisuian Lilligant lacks Tera Blast. Solar Blade is used for raw power, although Leaf Blade is still an option for consistency outside sun. Tera Blast Fire, especially in sun, gives Lilligant a powerful third STAB option to punish foes that can tank its original STAB combination like Gholdengo, Mega Scizor, and Tera Poison Cresselia. Sleep Powder is an option to shut down checks such as Dragapult or scout for Tera types from Pokemon like Kingambit and Dondozo, which can be used as setup fodders or opportunities to give a free switch to an ally; this also allows Hisuian Lilligant to use Tera Fighting over Tera Fire for more power. Ice Spinner is another option, granting an OHKO on Flying-types that can absorb Hisuian Lilligant's STAB options such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and most Zapdos sets. Hazard support is invaluable in allowing boosted Solar Blade to OHKO Toxapex lacking Heavy-Duty Boots and Mega Scizor, making Great Tusk and Heatran good partners that also passively benefit from the sun. Finally, Hisuian Lilligant is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster threats once the sun ends, so it appreciates a sturdy defensive core to back it up; Toxapex, Heatran, and Great Tusk can tank hits from and reliably check threats such as Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny once the sun goes down, while Landorus-T and Rotom-W are examples of pivots that can help bring Hisuian Lilligant in more easily.

Hustle Breaker.description: Hustle coupled with Victory Dance can be used to break common defensive Pokemon like Toxapex, Great Tusk, Landorus, Kingambit, and Heatran; Hisuian Lilligant also outspeeds a good portion of the metagame after a Victory Dance boost, allowing it to threaten even common Choice Scarf users such as Urshifu-R, Tapu Lele, and Gholdengo. Its main drawback lies in the decrease in accuracy, which makes it inconsistent and potentially easy to KO. Wide Lens can be used to circumvent this, as the accuracy boost will minimize the chances of a miss. Grassium Z can allow Hisuian Lilligant to dismantle defensive cores, letting it OHKO the likes of Toxapex , Landorus-T, and defensive Tornadus-T and heavily damage Zapdos after a Victory Dance and Stealth Rock damage to potentially open up a hole for another ally like Kartana or Volcarona to clean up. Victory Dance allows it to outpace most of the metagame and fire off powerful attacks. Tera Blast Ground allows Hisuian Lilligant to snipe Gholdengo and Skeledirge for super effective damage whilst also notably beating common Poison-types like Toxapex and Sneasler. Sleep Powder can be considered to shut down foes and set up more easily. Ice Spinner is also an option to beat common Flying-types like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Icium Z is an option when running this, as it allows Hisuian Lilligant to score an OHKO on Gliscor, defensive Landorus-T, and defensive Garchomp whilst avoiding Rocky Helmet and Rough Skin chip from the latter two. Hisuian Lilligant has trouble setting up, as it is frail enough to be susceptible to the multitude of offensive Pokemon in the tier. Its inconsistent accuracy may also sometimes leave it open to attacks. Thus, dual screens support from the likes of Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko is beneficial, although it should be noted that the latter summons Electric Terrain, which nullifies Sleep Powder. Entry hazard support is important to score OHKOs on certain Pokemon; for example, Bloom Doom OHKOes Toxapex and Tornadus lacking Heavy-Duty Boots after Stealth Rock damage. As such, Garchomp and Ferrothorn are examples of good entry hazard setters. Finally, Hisuian Lilligant can still be defensively checked by Pokemon like Zapdos, if lacking Ice Spinner, Volcarona, and defensive Gholdengo; allies that can beat these checks include Volcarona and Mega Diancie.

Calm Mind.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Defensive.description: Amoonguss is a decent wall that serves as a stopgap against rain wallbreakers like Barraskewda and Floatzel while also checking other offensive threats like Kartana, Iron Valiant, Zamazenta, and Urshifu-R. Regenerator allows Amoonguss to check those same threats long-term; it also prevents it from being worn down by pivots like Rotom-W and Tapu Koko as well as entry hazards if its Heavy-Duty Boots is removed via Knock Off. Spore incapacitates switch-ins such as Heatran, Volcarona, and Dragapult; the latter two would otherwise use it as setup fodder, while the former completely walls Amoonguss by being immune to Sludge Bomb. Sludge Bomb spreads status against the aforementioned Volcarona and Dragapult as well as bulkier switch-ins like Skeledirge and Tornadus-T and threatens Iron Valiant. Hidden Power Fire lets Amoonguss chip Poison-immune foes like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor as well as OHKO Kartana, preventing them from safely switching in. Heavy-Duty Boots lets it switch in as much as needed without fear of entry hazard damage; it also prevents Regenerator recovery from being stifled in longer games. Rocky Helmet is an alternative that wears down contact attackers like Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T as well as the aforementioned rain wallbreakers in Barraskewda and Floatzel. It should only be used if entry hazard control is decent enough, however, with support from Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Rotom-W. Tera Water provides invaluable resistances against Fire and Ice, letting Amoonguss potentially get an emergency Sludge Bomb or Spore in against foes like Weavile and Heatran. Tera Steel is an alternative that lets Amoonguss emergency check offensive foes like Tapu Lele while also giving it a better matchup against non-Heat Wave Tornadus-T; it also retains the Ice resistance given by Tera Water. Rotom-W is an excellent partner, as it stifles offensive and defensive Pokemon alike that Amoonguss struggles with, such as Heatran, Skeledirge, and Tornadus-T. In return, Amoonguss takes pressure off Rotom-W as a check to rain wallbreakers and can deal with Rotom-W switch-ins like Ferrothorn and Tangrowth. Gholdengo completely counters Amoonguss by virtue of its immunity to Spore and it taking negligible damage from Hidden Power Fire; as such, checks to it such as Kingambit and Poison Jab Clodsire are recommended, with the latter forcing Gholdengo to Terastallize so it can freely fish for poison.

With Flip Turn, Alomomola differentiates itself from the abundance of bulky Water-types as an excellent defensive pivot with Regenerator and a premiere Wish passer, supporting a myriad of different team archetypes by providing longevity to bulky Pokemon that lack reliable recovery, such as Mega Tyranitar, Ting-Lu, and Heatran. Heavy-Duty Boots is the standard item for Alomomola; however if a team lacks a way to punish contact moves and has sufficient hazard removal, then Rocky Helmet should be considered. Tera Dragon allows Alomomola to check Mega Charizard Y and Tapu Koko missing Dazzling Gleam, while Tera Fairy improves its matchup against Choice Band Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny, and Tera Poison provides a Toxic immunity and checks Iron Valiant. Common Pokemon unhindered by Toxic use Alomomola as setup fodder, such as Gliscor, Substitute variants of Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor. Rocky Helmet users such as Ferrothorn and Skarmory can punish the use of Flip Turn, along with Water Absorb Pokemon such as Ogerpon-W and some Clodsire variants can prevent the move from having any effect. Spikes, in conjunction with Knock Off from users like Mega Scizor, Hisuian Samurott, and Ferrothorn can also be extremely lethal to Alomomola. Knock Off can be used to cripple Pokemon that heavily rely on Heavy-Duty Boots or Leftovers, such as Zapdos, opposing Alomomola, Heatran, and Landorus-T, or Scald to threaten Kartana and Mega Scizor; but it should be noted that not using Toxic gives free setup turns to dangerous foes like Volcarona and Calm Mind Iron Valiant. Running a Sassy nature allows Alomomola to check Mega Diancie, while a Relaxed nature helps Alomomola pivot around Great Tusk. Teammates such as Ting-Lu and Heatran both take great advantage of Alomomola's support and can help shore up some of Alomomola's weaknesses, checking Tapu Koko, Zapdos, and Volcarona, while more offensive partners like Zapdos and Gouging Fire can cover some of these weaknesses while also offsetting Alomomola's passivity, the former answering Kartana, and Zamazenta while the latter helps with Tapu Koko and Zapdos.

Ferrothorn is a premier entry hazard setter, being able to keep them up reliably against common Defog users like Rotom-W, Landorus-T, and Gliscor, as well as dissuade Great Tusk from switching into it. Leech Seed is Ferrothorn’s main form of recovery, letting it slowly wear down and pressure its switch-ins while also sustaining itself. Gyro Ball is a strong STAB option that allows Ferrothorn to put significant pressure on Tornadus-T, Dragonite, and Serperior, which can otherwise setup on it safely, and deter Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele from switching in. Thunder Wave lets Ferrothorn immediately cripple switch-ins like Volcarona, Heatran, and Kartana, while Knock Off removes items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers from switch-ins like Galarian Slowking and opposing Ferrothorn, respectively, making them more susceptible to its entry hazards. Tera Ghost lets Ferrothorn flip its matchup against Pokemon using Fighting-type moves such as Superpower Ogerpon-W, Mega Medicham, or Zamazenta in a pinch, as well as block Great Tusk’s Rapid Spin and become neutral to Fire-type moves. The given EV spread allows Ferrothorn to survive a +2 Knock Off from Mega Mawile while otherwise maximizing its special bulk in order to handle threats like Tapu Koko and Tapu Lele better. Due to Ferrothorn’s limited longevity, it fits best on offensively geared teams that appreciate the constant pressure it applies to Pokemon like Heatran and Toxapex with its entry hazards, making Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny fantastic partners. Due to Ferrothorn’s lack of longevity, pairing it with a sturdy defensive backbone on more balanced structures with Pokemon like Toxapex, Clefable, and Alomomola is important, with the latter especially useful due to it being able to pass Wish to keep Ferrothorn healthy. These Pokemon also check pesky Fire- and Fighting-types such as Volcarona, Mega Lopunny, and Zamazenta for Ferrothorn, while in return Ferrothorn deals with Grass- and Psychic-types such as Kartana and Tapu Lele that these Pokemon struggle with. Other Pokemon that can set entry hazards, such as Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Heatran, work well with Ferrothorn to form a potent hazard-stacking core, significantly pressuring Defog users such as Landorus-T and Tornadus-T with Toxic, Knock Off, and Gyro Ball, maximizing the chip damage dealt.

Choice Specs.description: Hydreigon carves a niche in National Dex courtesy of its powerful Choice Specs-boosted attacks and nearly unresisted STAB combo. Additionally, its useful typing allows it to pivot into common defensive Pokemon such as Rotom-W and Gholdengo, giving it opportunities of entry. Fire Blast complements Dark Pulse and Draco Meteor very well, hitting Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Kingambit. Flash Cannon allows Hydreigon to hit Fairy-types that would otherwise pivot into it, such as Mega Diancie and Iron Valiant, as well as hitting Mega Tyranitar moderately hard. U-turn is an alternative over the latter two moves that provides a more risk-free option to exploit Hydreigon's checks, giving Pokemon like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny free entry. Tera Dark further boosts Hydreigon’s power, allowing its Dark Pulse to reliably 2HKO the likes of Toxapex and Heatran. Hydreigon fits best on bulky offense and offense teams that have reliable options to switch it in safely. Hydreigon pairs very well with pivots such as Mega Lopunny, Tornadus-T, and Landorus-T, as they can switch it in against opposing defensive Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Rotom-W. Assault Vest Tornadus-T pairs particularly well with Hydreigon, as it notably checks Dragapult, as well as providing insurance against foes such as Iron Valiant. Pokemon that can exploit common switch-ins to Hydreigon such as Mega Tyranitar and Kingambit pair well with Hydreigon, meaning the likes of Great Tusk and Zamazenta are good partners. Similarly, Pokemon that can lure or weaken the aforementioned switchins, such as Gholdengo and Dragapult, pair well with Hydreigon.

Fire Spin.description: With its solid natural bulk and good defensive typing in conjunction with Levitate, Hydreigon serves as a trapper that checks and eliminates Pokemon like Skeledirge and Mega Charizard Y lacking Focus Blast. Fire Spin traps and accumulates chip on a myriad of defensive Pokemon, such as Toxapex, Ting-Lu, Gastrodon, and Clodsire. Earth Power, in combination with Fire Spin, increases the damage that the aforementioned Pokemon take while also threatening Heatran. Alternatively, Dark Pulse can be used as a solid STAB move to hit airborne Pokemon such as Gliscor. Taunt prevents passive walls such as Toxapex and Gastrodon from healing while also preventing Hydreigon from being crippled by status from the aforementioned Pokemon as well. Tera Poison gives Hydreigon a Toxic immunity and a favorable defensive typing, allowing it to safely trap Pokemon such as Great Tusk and Iron Valiant. Offensive teammates like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, and Dragapult appreciate Hydreigon trapping and removing walls like Toxapex, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu. Entry hazard setters such as Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Gastrodon support Hydreigon, as they heavily chip and pressure switch-ins like Kingambit in combination with Hydreigon's Fire Spin. Hydreigon is easily forced out by Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Iron Valiant. As such, Pokemon that can handle the aforementioned threats such as Gholdengo, Clodsire, and Toxapex make great teammates for it.

Offensive Quiver Dance.description: Volcarona is a highly threatening sweeper that can end the game on the spot if given the opportunity to set up a Quiver Dance while being able to force out major threats to the hyper offense teams that it finds itself on such as Swords Dance Mega Scizor. Flamethrower is Volcarona's Fire-type STAB move of choice thanks to its decent Base Power and consistent damage output, although Fire Blast can be used for the extra power, allowing Volcarona to notably have a very high chance to OHKO defensive Landorus-T and Tapu Lele after Stealth Rock and OHKO Gliscor after one Quiver Dance, while Flamethrower cannot. Giga Drain provides good coverage alongside Volcarona's Fire STAB move, allowing it to hit Water-types such as Alomomola and potentially forcing them to Terastallize. Finally, Hidden Power Ground allows Volcarona to hit unexpecting Heatran, which would otherwise be a hard counter to this set. Flame Body allows it to punish careless contact moves from Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Landorus-T, non-Protective Pads Meowscarada, and Mega Scizor. Tera Grass powers up Giga Drain while turning Volcarona's Water weakness into a resistance, allowing it to safely take on threats such as Ogerpon-W and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R. Alternatively, Tera Ground allows Volcarona to dodge revenge killing attempts from the likes of Iron Boulder while powering up Hidden Power Ground to let it potentially OHKO Gouging Fire at +1. Due to Volcarona's high threat level, common attempts to check it involve using Terastallization on a defensive Pokemon, such as Heatran or Alomomola; as such, partners like Raging Bolt and Kyurem appreciate Volcarona forcing those Pokemon to Terastallize. Grass-types like Serperior are also great partners, as they can bait in Heatran for Volcarona while being able to switch in situationally on Water-types like Ogerpon-W and Choice Scarf Urshifu-R that threaten it out. Serperior can also force progress with Glare on threats like Gouging Fire or setting up with Leaf Storm while chipping checks like Raging Bolt. Dual screens setters like Grimmsnarl are also good teammates to allow Volcarona to set up far more easily and win games quickly.

Bulky Quiver Dance.description: Due to its typing, ability, and the combination of Quiver Dance and Roost, Defensive Quiver Dance Volcarona is a powerful late-game sweeper and a decent pivot against Fairy- and Fighting-type moves such as Iron Valiant's Moonblast as well as Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta's Close Combat. Hidden Power Ground is an alternative to hit foes like Heatran, Garganacl, Mega Diancie, and Raging Bolt. Giga Drain can be paired with Tera Grass to provide coverage against Rock-types like Garganacl and Mega Diancie, as well as Water-types like Ogerpon-W, Alomomola, and Mega Swampert, and it helps to keep Volcarona healthy without sacking momentum to use Roost. Roost makes sure that Volcarona can check foes like Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny in the long run and win the 1v1 against Tapu Lele and Darkrai without being chipped severely. Tera Grass gives Giga Drain a STAB boost and removes Volcarona's weakness to Water-types, which can be useful against offensive threats like Ogerpon-W and rain. Tera Steel allows Volcarona to turn walls relying on Toxic to make progress into its setup fodder, examples of which are Alomomola and Blissey. It also provides Volcarona with better matchups against the likes of Mega Tyranitar and Mega Diancie. The above EVs make sure that Volcarona can survive the damage from Stealth Rock twice and outspeed Zamazenta at +1. Teammates like Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W can lure in walls like Ferrothorn and provide Volcarona with great opportunities to set up. They can also handle specially defensive foes like Heatran and Galarian Slowking for Volcarona when it's not equipped with Hidden Power Ground. Since it heavily relies on Heavy-Duty Boots to prevent entry hazard damage, Volcarona appreciates teammates like Gliscor and Mega Tyranitar to absorb Knock Off from foes like Landorus-T. It also benefits from teammates like Ferrothorn and Landorus-T checking Dragonite. Great Tusk and Landorus-T can relieve Volcarona of pressure from Stealth Rock by using Rapid Spin and Defog respectively when Volcarona loses its Heavy-Duty Boots.

Assault Vest.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Defensive Pivot.description: Landorus-T is the quintessential defensive pivot for many offense and balance teams, combining a unique blend of defensive prowess and utility to perform as a stellar support Pokemon. Intimidate gives Landorus-T the ability to pivot into many of the tier's physical attackers like Gouging Fire, Mega Mawile, and Mega Medicham, and while it may fear Ice Punch from the latter two, they will still be left with reduced Attack allowing teammates to have an easier time pivoting around them. Additionally, a crucial immunity to both Ground- and Electric-type attacks provides valuable role compression for offensive teams, helping deter the likes of Tapu Koko and Choice Scarf Landorus-T from freely attacking. Leftovers provides passive recovery and longevity, but Rocky Helmet can be used instead on more aggressive teams that appreciate its ability to chip down threats like Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta. Toxic gives Landorus-T the ability to put a timer on foes such as Zapdos and opposing Landorus-T as well as setup sweepers like Dragonite, while common Pokemon immune to Toxic such as Toxapex and Galarian Slowking fear taking an Earthquake, rendering them unable to safely absorb it. Due to Landorus-T's ability to hit the field plenty of times over the course of a game, it is the single most effective and splashable Stealth Rock setter in the metagame. Defog is also within its wheelhouse due to naturally positive matchups versus common Stealth Rock users like Heatran and Garganacl as well as the more niche Ting-Lu. Taunt is an alternative option to prevent Defog from opposing Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Zapdos, and should be used with 76 Speed EVs to outspeed the latter two. Although Taunt is generally preferred on Stealth Rock sets, it can be used on Defog variants as well due to its ability to prevent both Toxic and additional hazards from opposing Landorus-T and Gliscor. Tera Water grants Landorus-T the ability to flip its weaknesses to Water- and Ice-type attacks from the likes of Urshifu-R, Ogerpon-W, and Weavile while pivoting out and dealing large damage to the latter two with U-turn. Furthermore, it provides a temporary backbone for its team versus physical wallbreakers like Mega Swampert and Barraskewda found on rain teams, which could otherwise run over the offensive structures Landorus-T is typically found on. Teammates that appreciate Landorus-T pivoting into Ground-, Fighting-, and Electric-type attacks from the likes of Garchomp, Zamazenta, and Tapu Koko while maintaining momentum for its team, such as Galarian Slowking, Darkrai, and Tornadus-T, make for great teammates. Defensively, foes capable of absorbing the combination of Earthquake and Toxic like Gliscor, Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Corviknight prove to be difficult for Landorus-T to make progress against; however, with U-turn it can pivot out of these Pokemon and create opportunities for teammates such as Ogerpon-W, Volcarona, and Tapu Koko. Taunt variants, on the other hand, struggle to significantly threaten Ground-immune foes, often inviting in dangerous threats such as Mega Charizard Y, Tornadus-T, and Rotom-W; teammates that check these like Dragonite, Tapu Koko, and Ferrothorn are appreciated. Offensively, teams relying on Landorus-T as a physically defensive backbone may struggle with Ogerpon-W, Weavile, and Iron Defense Zamazenta; these weaknesses can be supported by pairing it with Dragonite, Mega Scizor, Volcarona, and Tapu Lele. The aforementioned Mega Scizor also helps by absorbing Knock Off from Kartana and Mega Tyranitar that would otherwise impair Landorus-T’s longevity, which is usually only supplemented by Leftovers.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Landorus-T is a great choice of role compression with various utilities such as a Ground- and Electric-type immunity, a soft check into Pokemon like Mega Mawile and Mega Medicham, speed control, and sometimes even a late-game cleaner. Thanks to Intimidate and a powerful Earthquake, Landorus-T has plentiful opportunities to pivot on forced switches with U-turn against threats like Iron Boulder and Galarian Slowking. Stone Edge hits Flying-types like Zapdos, Moltres, Mega Charizard Y, and Tornadus-T as well as Volcarona. Defog is very effective since most entry hazard setters like Heatran, Mega Diancie, and Garganacl don't like being hit by Earthquake, which prevents them from staying in against Landorus-T and gives it easy opportunities to Defog. Explosion as an alternative allows Landorus-T to trade with threats like Ogerpon-W, Darkrai, and Mega Lopunny as well as weakened checks like Gliscor, especially when Landorus-T is low HP. Tera Water removes Landorus-T's weakness against Water-types like Urshifu-R, Mega Swampert, and Hisuian Samurott, as well as common Ice-type moves like Ice Beam from Darkrai and Ice Shard from Weavile, and also gives Landorus-T a chance to revenge kill Volcarona. The given EVs make sure that Landorus-T outspeeds Zamazenta and survives a Choice Specs Moonblast from Iron Valiant and two Zen Headbutt from Mega Medicham after Stealth Rock. Teammates like Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Darkrai appreciate Landorus-T for bringing them in safely via U-turn. In return, they can threaten walls like Alomomola and Gliscor for Landorus-T. Landorus-T can be worn down quickly due to Stealth Rock and its lack of recovery, so teammates like Alomomola and Ferrothorn are helpful to protect it from being overwhelmed too quickly by foes like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny, both of which can also check Water-types like Mega Swampert for Landorus-T. Additionally, Alomomola can heal Landorus-T with Wish and form a pivoting core with it. Other pivots like Rotom-W and Iron Crown bring in Landorus-T safely and form VoltTurn cores with it.

Suicide Lead.description: Landorus-T is an effective suicide lead, being able to inflict damage to incoming Pokemon with Stealth Rock, making it most suitable for hyper offensive teams. It can run Taunt to shut down any entry hazard setters like Ferrothorn, Ting-Lu, and opposing Landorus-T or deny Defog from the likes of Zapdos and Gliscor. Explosion lets Landorus-T deal massive damage once its job is done, being able to take a good chunk of damage out of almost any foe while also denying hazard removal from the aforementioned Defoggers and Rapid Spin from Great Tusk. Tera Ghost prevents any hazards on the field from being removed by Rapid Spin users like Great Tusk if it's unable to safely use Explosion on it. Ogerpon-W is great offensive partner, as it’s able to come in on Surging Strikes from Urshifu-R which threatens Landorus-T. Volcarona is another solid teammate that’s able to switch into Weavile’s Triple Axel and has a chance to burn it in the process.

SubRoost.description: Kyurem's excellent matchups against common Pokemon like Gliscor, Raging Bolt, and Alomomola, while having fantastic coverage with Earth Power that lets it hit Ice-resistant foes like Iron Moth and Heatran makes it incredibly annoying to switch into. Substitute lets it take advantage of Pokemon that cannot heavily damage it, like Toxapex and Rotom-W, as well as Pokemon it scares out like Gliscor and Gastrodon while also making itself safer against revenge killers like Iron Valiant and Mega Lopunny, forcing them to get rid of its Substitute before being able to threaten it out. Tera Water and Tera Fairy are Kyurem's main Tera types, as these let it change its defensive matchups behind Substitute making it harder for the likes of Mega Scizor, Ferrothorn, and Garganacl to remove its Substitute. Tera Ground is another alternative to give Kyurem STAB on Earth Power, notably dealing more damage against Steel-types that aren't weak to Ground, like Mega Scizor and Ferrothorn. The EV Spread lets Kyurem hit 405 HP, meaning that its Substitute takes two Seismic Toss to remove. Teammates that struggle with the Flying-, Water-, and Ground-types that Kyurem preys on like Ogerpon-W, Gliscor, and Tapu Koko make for excellent teammates, as they appreciate its ability to deal with the Pokemon they can't. Resilient defensive partners like Alomomola, Clefable, and Galarian Slowking help switch into revenge killers like Iron Boulder and Zamazenta that force Kyurem out. Additionally, Alomomola and Galarian Slowking can also help pivot in Kyurem, something it appreciates.

Dragon Dance.description: With Dragon Dance, good bulk that allows it to set up on the likes Landorus-T and Zapdos, and incredibly strong STAB moves thanks to Loaded Dice, Kyurem is an extremely scary sweeper. Tera Blast Ground lets it beat Steel-types that would normally be an answer to Kyurem, like Iron Crown and Heatran. Choice Scarf users and other fast Pokemon like Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Hawlucha greatly appreciate Kyurem's breaking prowess, as they can sweep teams much more easily after it has wreaked havoc on the opposing team. Dual screens support from teammates like Tapu Koko and Grimmsnarl are also incredible alongside Kyurem, giving it more opportunites to set up as well as hindering revenge killing attemps from the likes of Mega Medicham and Mega Scizor. Bulky Water-types like Slowbro and Alomomola are able to withstand Kyurem's attacks even after a boost, making wallbreakers like Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant good teammates, as they can use them for opportunities to switch in, or weaken them down so Kyurem can take them out. Consistent entry hazard removal is also much appreciated thanks to its weakness to hazards, making partners like Great Tusk and Landorus-T fantastic.

Battle Bond Sweeper.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

SubToxic.description: 112 Special Attack EVs with a Modest Nature lets Shadow Ball OHKO Tapu Lele after Stealth Rock. 60 Speed EVs outspeed Corviknight.

Unburden Sweeper.description: Hawlucha features as a threatening setup sweeper on Terrain teams with its high Speed boosted by Unburden and great offensive STAB move combination. Substitute is the premier choice, as it enables Hawlucha to take advantage of passive foes like Ferrothorn, Alomomola, and Landorus-T and punish the foes it forces to switch out by setting up. Encore is an alternative option that turns setup sweepers like Swords Dance Gliscor into setup fodder and locks defensive pieces like Alomomola and Corviknight into status moves. Tera Flying removes Hawlucha's weakness to Psychic- and Fairy-type foes like Iron Crown, Clefable, and Iron Valiant and makes Acrobatics a terrifying STAB move that OHKOes Zamazenta with Dauntless Shield active and Landorus-T after Stealth Rock at +2. Tera Electric, on the other hand, makes Hawlucha resist Electric-type moves, notably Thunderclap from Raging Bolt, and it also allows Hawlucha to ignore Static from Zapdos and benefit from Terrain effects. The given EVs can allow Hawlucha to take a Moonblast from Clefable and outspeed Excadrill in sand. A good Terrain setter like Tapu Koko, Rillaboom, or Tapu Lele is necessary for Hawlucha to sweep. Tapu Koko can either set up dual screens to help Hawlucha set up or threaten Water- and Flying-types like Alomomola, Corviknight, and Tornadus-T for it. Rillaboom also helps with aforementioned Water-types and Landorus-T for Hawlucha. Both of them can pressure Dondozo for Hawlucha and pivot it in. Tapu Lele, on the other hand, enables an even more offensive playstyle with teammates like Armarouge, Iron Crown, and Polteageist for Hawlucha, which tears the opponent's defensive core in a pinch with powerful special attacks and appreciates Hawlucha threatening Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn. Hawlucha dislikes foes that punish contact moves, such as Rocky Helmet Landorus-T, Zapdos, and Volcarona, which makes Knock Off support from the likes of Rillaboom and Iron Valiant greatly appreciated. Due to its mediocre offensive stats, it also benefits from wallbreakers with immediate power like Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele. Hawlucha is prone to priority move users like Raging Bolt and Weavile before Terastallizing, so it is useful to have teammates like Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele to threaten them.

Wallbreaker.description: With its stellar offensive stats, good Speed, and great coverage, Mega Diancie is a terrific wallbreaker that is able to threaten common defensive staples like Zapdos and Galarian Slowking and is just as potent of an entry hazard setter because of how it efficiently pressures common hazard removal options like Tornadus-T and Corviknight. Diamond Storm is used over Power Gem to dent common defensive checks harder like Galarian Slowking and Tera Grass Heatran. Moonblast is an amazing STAB move that crushes Stealth Rock setters like Garchomp and Mega Tyranitar while doing very considerable damage to Landorus-T. Mystical Fire hits Steel-types that Mega Diancie would be checked by, such as Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, and Corviknight. If a hazard setter is already present, Earth Power can be used alongside Mystical Fire to pressure Pokemon like Heatran, Toxapex, and Iron Crown. Other niche options like Encore and Protect are also usable, with the former allowing Mega Diancie to lock Pokemon like Raging Bolt and Gliscor into setup moves and the latter letting it scout foes like Landorus-T and Mega Medicham. 28 Attack EVs let Mega Diancie 2HKO Galarian Slowking with Diamond Storm. A Naive nature lets Mega Diancie stave off physical attackers like Mega Lopunny and Mega Tyranitar more, while a Hasty nature improves its matchup against special attackers like Tornadus-T and Darkrai. While Mega Diancie is an amazing offensive Pokemon, it often lacks opportunities to wallbreak due to its frailty. Defensive pivots like Landorus-T, Zapdos, and Galarian Slowking can deal with revenge killers to Mega Diancie like Mega Lopunny, Rillaboom, and Iron Valiant, respectively. In return, Mega Diancie can stack entry hazards in tandem with the aforementioned pivots, forming a good balance core that wears down teams with ease. Offensive Pokemon like Ogerpon-W and Darkrai appreciate Mega Diancie dealing with foes like Raging Bolt and Mega Tyranitar; said offensive Pokemon can also mess with common checks to Mega Diancie like Toxapex and Iron Crown.

Choice Band Hoopa-U is a strong physical wallbreaker that threatens slower teams thanks to its massive Attack stat and spammable STAB move in Hyperspace Fury. That said, Hoopa-U competes with Kingambit, which has significantly higher bulk and a way to bypass its Speed tier issue in Sucker Punch. Hoopa-U has a 4x weakness to U-turn and neutrality to Pursuit, meaning it cannot enter or leave the field easily. Nonetheless, Hoopa-U does not require setup, and it therefore has a niche into bulkier teams thanks to its immediate power. Drain Punch lets Hoopa-U take on Dark-types that would otherwise wall it, such as Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, and Zen Headbutt hammers Zamazenta, Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Toxapex while also hitting Clefable and Tera Fairy Garganacl neutrally. Gunk Shot provides Hoopa-U with another way to break through Fairy-types such as Tera Fairy Garganacl and Clefable. Tera Dark powers up Hoopa-U's Hyperspace Fury while giving it a resistance to Pursuit. Hoopa-U fits well on bulky offense teams, which appreciate its power allowing teammates to clean. As such, partners such as Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, Iron Valiant, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele pair well with Hoopa-U. The former three also check Kingambit, making Hoopa-U less prediction reliant with its attacks, while the latter appreciates Hoopa-U being able to wear down Steel-types such as Ferrothorn and Kingambit. Hoopa-U also has trouble getting into the field due to its low Speed and frail physical bulk, so pivots such as Mega Scizor and Rotom-W are appreciated to bring it in Hoopa-U more consistently. Rotom-W also pivots into Toxapex and Heatran to bring in Hoopa-U, while Mega Scizor pivots into Tapu Lele and Kingambit and brings in Heatran and Skeledirge for Hoopa-U to break through. Entry hazard setters are also appreciated, as Hoopa-U can more easily break through defensive teams with Spikes or Stealth Rock on the field. Thus, partners such as Ferrothorn and Garchomp are appreciated.
The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

The Pex.description: Toxapex is a versatile wall that can take on both physical and special hits, thanks to its great defensive stats, typing, and Regenerator, making it difficult to KO. Its typing in particular allows it to check common Pokemon such as Iron Valiant, Mega Lopunny, Zamazenta, and Urshifu-R while its utility moves like Knock Off and Toxic let it cripple them to benefit teammates. Scald can cripple physical attackers like Garchomp and Mega Medicham, discouraging them from directly switching in to take advantage of Toxapex. Scald’s damage output reduces Toxapex's passivity and is also just enough to threaten Water-weak foes like Landorus-T, Iron Boulder, and Mega Diancie; this allows Toxapex to use Recover or Toxic with general safety. Knock Off allows Toxapex to remove valuable items like Choice items, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Leftovers from switch-ins like Tapu Lele, Zapdos, and Ferrothorn. Toxic Spikes allows Toxapex to pressure offensive teams, forcing them to give up momentum to clear it lest they get poisoned. Haze prevents setup sweepers like Gouging Fire and Iron Valiant from exploiting Toxapex, forcing them to attack, and disrupts wincons like IronPress Zamazenta and Volcarona. An EV spread of 248 HP / 212 Def / 48 SpD with a Bold nature allows Toxapex to maximize its physical bulk while surviving two Scorching Sands from Mega Charizard Y. On the other hand, 248 HP / 8 Def / 252 SpD with a Calm nature simply maximizes special bulk. 248 HP EVs are important as it reduces entry hazard damage while benefiting more from Regenerator. Tera Dragon is useful to check Ogerpon-W and Mega Charizard Y, the latter of which is especially important on specially defensive sets, Tera Fairy helps versus Raging Bolt and Garchomp, and Tera Steel lets it check Serperior and Tapu Lele. The former two are also notable for removing Toxapex’s Ground weakness versus the likes of Great Tusk and Landorus-T. Toxapex, by nature of being a fat wall with little offensive presence, fits like a glove on stall and balance playstyles, sapping momentum but providing valuable utility. Allies on balance that can take advantage of Toxapex through double switches, like Ogerpon-W, Urshifu-R, and Mega Tyranitar, benefit from Toxapex baiting in Ground- and Psychic-types; by using Toxapex as a mid-ground, they can enter the field safely as the opponent switches to a Toxapex check like Gliscor and Choice item Tapu Lele. Teammates that help with the Ground and Psychic weaknesses on the defensive side, such as Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Heatran, are useful as well; in return, Toxapex tanks hits from Ice- and Fighting-types like Weavile, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny for them.

Assault Vest.description: These sets are currently up for reservation for a revamp; please check out the C&C thread for more information!

Clangorous Booster.description: Kommo-o is a fearsome wallbreaker with its capability to omniboost as soon as it gets an opportunity with Clangorous Soul. Its ability to set up on common Pokemon like Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Volcarona and to potentially use Tera Steel to ignore Toxic from defensive Pokemon like Heatran and Toxapex allows it to start wallbreaking very early with its powerful coverage. Throat Spray grants an extra Special Attack boost when using Clangorous Soul, whereas Kommonium Z gives it Clangorous Soulblaze, which allows it to deal heavy damage while boosting its stats. Boomburst lets Kommo-o neutrally hit much of the metagame for large damage, which, when coupled with STAB Clanging Scales and Flamethrower as coverage for Steel-types, can easily break cores featuring the likes of Great Tusk, Skarmory, Ferrothorn, Toxapex, Gliscor, Landorus-T, and more. Bulletproof along with Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to wall Choice Scarf Tapu Lele looking to revenge kill it as well as set up in front of Gholdengo and Choice Specs Dragapult. Tera Normal gives Kommo-o a stronger Boomburst, while Tera Steel gives it a Toxic immunity and useful resistances to all of its weaknesses, allowing Kommo-o to take would-be checks, such as Dragapult, Tapu Lele, Baxcalibur, and Iron Valiant, by surprise and set up in front of them. However, Kommo-o likes to use its Tera and thus denies its teammates this option, and it can be checked by a well-timed Tera from Pokemon such as Tera Steel Garchomp and subsequently be revenge killed. It is also walled by the likes of Heatran, Garganacl, and Clodsire, which can tank its coverage options even without Terastallizing and cripple it with Toxic or Salt Cure or simply force it out and deny future setup opportunities. Finally, due to the nature of Kommo-o’s setup, it can only reasonably do so once per game, making Kommo-o more suited for offensive teams. Thus, having allies that can take care of Kommo-o’s defensive checks before it sets up can allow it to do its job much more effectively; physical attackers like Iron Valiant, offensive Landorus-T, and Samurott-H can pressure and remove checks for Kommo-o to break and potentially sweep. Hazard support is also valuable in preventing opponents from switching back and forth between Pokemon in a Regenerator core; in particular, Assault Vest Tornadus + Toxapex; Pokemon like Great Tusk and Garchomp can set up Stealth Rock to pressure switches.

Belly Drum.description: With Belly Drum, Kommo-o becomes a fearsome sweeper capable of wiping unprepared teams with relative ease. The HP cuts from Substitute and Belly Drum will immediately activate Salac Berry, giving Kommo-o maximum Attack along with increased Speed to sweep offensive and defensive teams alike. Substitute also allows Kommo-o to dodge status moves like Ferrothorn’s Leech Seed, Garganacl's Salt Cure, Landorus-T's Toxic, and Rotom-W's Will-O-Wisp that could potentially ruin Kommo-o’s sweep, instead giving it a free set up opportunity. Drain Punch is chosen over heavier hitting moves like Close Combat, as the extra damage is not needed, and Drain Punch can heal off the HP lost through Belly Drum and Substitute, making Kommo-o harder to revenge kill. Thunder Punch is used to dent and possibly KO common defensive tanks that can survive Drain Punch, like Skarmory, Toxapex, Tera Water Garganacl, Gholdengo, and Tera Flying Kingambit. Bulletproof stacked on top of Tera Steel allows Kommo-o to surprise opponents like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Specs Dragapult looking to revenge kill it. Although Soundproof blocks moves such as Roar from defensive Garchomp and Bug Buzz from Volcarona, it is generally not preferred due to the lack of relevant sound-based moves in comparison to the bevy of aforementioned qualities gained from Bulletproof. Tera Electric can power up Thunder Punch with STAB to score KOs on the likes of Gholdengo, Tapu Lele, and Tera Fairy Kingambit, while Tera Steel gives it useful resistances that may allow it to reach Salac Berry range without Substitute by tanking a resisted hit from the likes of Tapu Lele or Mega Diancie. Belly Drum Kommo-o fits on hyper offensive teams that appreciate its ability to sweep or clean up teams once its checks are removed. Therefore, it appreciates partners that can lure and remove Pokemon like Clodsire, Tera Grass Heatran, Gliscor, and Landorus-T that check it; Tapu Koko in particular is good, as it can run Hidden Power Ice to bait and KO the latter two and badly chip the former two potentially into Kommo-o’s range while also boosting the power of its Thunder Punch by setting Electric Terrain. Belly Drum Kommo-o also has trouble setting up, as it mainly uses the element of surprise to get up a Substitute —namely, it exploits the opponent's fear of Clangorous Soulblaze and thus forces them to switch. Thus, it appreciates dual screens support from the likes of Grimmsnarl in order to more consistently set up Belly Drum.

Offensive Pivot.description: Thanks to its great Speed, power-boosting ability in Electric Terrain, and access to both U-turn and Volt Switch, Tapu Koko functions as a great offensive pivot. It often utilizes its ability to force out slower foes like Mega Charizard Y, Alomomola, and Hisuian Samurott to safely pivot in wallbreakers that take advantage of Electric Terrain like Iron Valiant, Iron Boulder, and Iron Moth in safely via U-turn or Volt Switch. U-turn is usually favored for its consistency against Ground-types like Gliscor and Clodsire and ability to deal more chip damage to Grass-type Pokemon such as Rillaboom and Serperior; alternatively, Volt Switch has higher damage output and avoids contact punishment from Pokemon like Ferrothorn and Volcarona, but being blocked by Ground-type Pokemon makes it less reliable. Hidden Power Ice targets popular Ground-type such as Landorus-T and Gliscor and is the preferred option over Dazzling Gleam. Heavy-Duty Boots complements Tapu Koko's frequent pivoting by negating entry hazard damage, while Electrium Z lets it pick off weakened foes such as Galarian Slowking, Heatran, and Volcarona. Due to its typing and mediocre Special Attack stat, Tapu Koko struggles with bulky Ground-type Pokemon like Clodsire and Ting-Lu, as well as sturdy walls like Galarian Slowking, Garganacl, and Ferrothorn; therefore, it needs powerful teammates like Mega Medicham, Iron Valiant, and Hawlucha to break through them. Those teammates also appreciate Tapu Koko checking faster offensive threats such as Tornadus-T, pressuring walls such as Toxapex, and generating momentum for them to make use of. Tapu Koko also has great synergy with the likes of Iron Crown, Landorus-T, and Iron Moth, forming the infamous VoltTurn combo. In the case of Iron Moth and Iron Crown, Tapu Koko’s Electric Surge activates Quark Drive for them. In return, they take care of Tapu Koko’s checks such as Ferrothorn and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele.

Dual Screens.description: Access to Light Screen and Reflect alongside an excellent Speed tier allows Tapu Koko to function as an effective dual screens setter in hyper offense teams. Taunt is a powerful tool on Tapu Koko, allowing it to prevent the use of Defog from the likes of Tornadus-T and Corviknight, deny setup from Pokemon such as Volcarona, Ogerpon-W, and Raging Bolt, and prevent opposing leads, such as Landorus-T and Ribombee, from setting up entry hazards. Tera Ghost is used solely for blocking Rapid Spin from Great Tusk, whereas Tera Flying allows Tapu Koko to safely set up dual screens in front of Ground-type Pokemon such as Gliscor and Landorus-T, though it should be noted that Tapu Koko rarely Terastallizes. Tapu Koko's Electric Surge is a powerful tool, allowing Hawlucha to reliably activate Unburden while also activating Quark Drive from the likes of Iron Valiant, Iron Crown, and Iron Boulder. Setup sweepers such as Volcarona, Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor appreciate Tapu Koko's dual screens, which allow for easier setup. Defog is able to remove Tapu Koko's dual screens and Electric Terrain, making Serperior, Encore variants of Iron Valiant and Ogerpon-W, and Taunt from Hisuan Samurott and Landorus-T solid options to use alongside Tapu Koko, as they can punish Defog users. Pokemon such as Mega Lopunny, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, and Iron Moth are able to outspeed and threaten to KO Tapu Koko, making teammates that can take advantage of them, such as Iron Valiant, Mega Gyarados, and Dragonite, excellent partners.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Tapu Lele is the premier speed control option in the tier, outrunning and OHKOing common offensive threats such as Speed Booster Energy Great Tusk, Swords Dance Urshifu-R, and non-Booster Energy Iron Valiant. Additionally, Psychic Terrain blocks priority moves like Mega Lopunny's Fake Out and Weavile's Ice Shard, which is useful for Tapu Lele itself and teammates that aim for a sweep such as Hawlucha and Volcarona. Focus Blast lets Tapu Lele hit common Steel-types such as Heatran and Ferrothorn. Psyshock allows Tapu Lele to hit foes with weaker Defense stats like Assault Vest Tornadus-T and Volcarona, along with shutting down Calm Mind Tera Poison Cresselia. Future Sight can be used to hit in tandem with teammates such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta, threatening Toxapex and Zapdos looking to switch into their attacks. Alternatively, Hidden Power Fire nails Mega Scizor along with hitting Ferrothorn more consistently than Focus Blast. Tera Psychic is the premier Tera option, as it boosts Tapu Lele's Psychic STAB attacks to ludicrous heights, smashing through most neutral targets such as Landorus-T, Rotom-W, and Tapu Koko. Tera Fairy is a niche alternative, boosting Moonblast to powerful levels while minimizing the threat of Pursuit from Mega Tyranitar and Weavile. Despite having Focus Blast, Steel-types like Heatran and Ferrothorn are still effective checks to Tapu Lele, so teammates such as Gliscor and Mega Lopunny can be used to mitigate this. Hawlucha can both utilize Psychic Terrain to activate Unburden while helping break through Mega Scizor, allowing Tapu Lele to clean up with ease late-game.

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Tapu Lele is one of the strongest in the tier, having no commonly used consistent defensive checks. Hidden Power Fire can OHKO most Mega Scizor and deal heavy damage to Ferrothorn without the chance of missing, unlike Focus Blast. Focus Blast hits Heatran and Ferrothorn and OHKOes Mega Tyranitar. Psyshock can hit Galarian Slowking, 2HKO Chansey, and OHKO Assault Vest Tornadus-T. Future Sight can help teammates like Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny wallbreak, as it deals good damage to switch-ins like Alomomola, Toxapex, and Landorus-T. Late-game cleaners like Mega Lopunny, Volcarona, Urshifu-R, and Bulk Up Great Tusk really appreciate Tapu Lele's ability to force damage onto would-be checks such as Corviknight and Heatran. However, Tapu Lele is very prediction reliant and can often invite in Steel-types such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, Iron Crown, and Mega Scizor. Additionally, it struggles against common revenge killers such as Urshifu-R, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Lopunny. Therefore, a strong defensive core is recommended when building around Tapu Lele to minimize the impact of these offensive threats, especially having a switch-in to the aforementioned Steel-types that may come in on a Psychic or Moonblast. Good switch-ins to these include Heatran and Alomomola, with the latter serving as a pivot with Flip Turn to safely get Tapu Lele on the field against passive foes like Toxapex and Gliscor.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Tapu Lele becomes a fearsome breaker after a single boost, threatening common defensive Pokemon like Ferrothorn, Toxapex, and Mega Tyranitar. Focus Blast is useful coverage, hitting many defensive staples like Ferrothorn, Garganacl, and Heatran for super effective damage. Fightinium Z in tandem with Focus Blast allows Tapu Lele to reliably OHKO Ferrothorn and Heatran, and heavily damage Mega Scizor and Ting-Lu. Although Tapu Lele is a fearsome wallbreaker, it requires a Calm Mind boost to heavily damage the majority of the metagame, so Pokemon that can provide it a setup opportunity via pivoting such as Urshifu-R, Gliscor, and Alomomola are beneficial. Tapu Lele is also very prone to getting revenge killed by physical attackers that can bypass Tapu Lele's Special Defense boosts, such as Zamazenta, Kartana, and Weavile, so teammates such as Zapdos, Moltres, and Toxapex are appreciated.

Swords Dance.description: Tapu Bulu sets itself apart from other Grass-types thanks to its high offensive capabilities, Terrain-boosted Horn Leech, good coverage in Close Combat and Stone Edge, and good defensive typing, checking Pokemon like Zamazenta, Urshifu-R and Rotom-W. It also provides Grassy Terrain for its team, giving passive recovery to teammates like Heatran and Toxapex, making them even harder to deal with. Close Combat hits Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Kingambit and Stone Edge threaten Flying-types like Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Dragonite while letting Tapu Bulu beat Volcarona. Rockium Z gives Tapu Bulu a strong nuke, allowing it to break through Zapdos more reliably while also OHKOing would-be checks like Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y on the switch-in. Fightinium Z, on the other hand, helps it break through Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor and KOes Heatran after luring it in. Leftovers gives Tapu Bulu more passive recovery, allowing it to set up multiple times against more balanced teams. The given EV spread ensures Tapu Bulu outspeeds Magnezone and Mega Tyranitar while optimizing its bulk. Tera Water retains Tapu Bulu's utility against rain while making it resist Ice-types moves from Pokemon like Weavile and Fire-type moves from Heatran and Volcarona, while Tera Steel avoids Toxic, grants a helpful Flying resistance against the lieks of Tornadus-T and Zados, and synergizes well with Grassy Terrain, as it weakens Earthquake. Both options also let it resist Make It Rain from Gholdengo, allowing Tapu Bulu to win against it thanks to Horn Leech's recovery. Tapu Bulu fits best on offense and bulky offense teams, which appreciate its strong wallbreaking capability. Heatran checks Fire-types like Volcarona and Skeledirge, Flying-types like Tornadus-T, and appreciates Grassy Terrain weakening Earthquake. In return, Tapu Bulu can check Rotom-W and Urshifu-R, using them as setup fodder. Kartana synergizes well with Tapu Bulu, as Tapu Bulu can break through most of Kartana's checks thanks to Z-Moves (added hyphen) and boosts its Leaf Blade with Grassy Terrain, letting Kartana clean with its Choice Scarf set. In the same vein, Mega Scizor works well with Tapu Bulu, as together they can overwhelm their common checks, like Zapdos and Heatran.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Tapu Fini compresses roles as speed control that provides valuable defensive utility and support. It can outspeed and revenge kill foes like Mega Lopunny, Dragapult, Garchomp, and Iron Valiant while using its typing and remarkable bulk to switch into Pokemon like Heatran, Weavile, and Urshifu-R. Other than shutting down problematic setup sweepers like Volcarona, Trick + Taunt improves Tapu Fini's matchup against defensive Pokemon by crippling and shutting down switch-ins such as Ferrothorn, Clodsire, and Toxapex, especially with Misty Terrain to protect it and its teammates against theirs and the likes of Rotom-W, Heatran, and Gastrodon's status moves. If the team lacks an entry hazard remover, Tapu Fini can run Defog if necessary, as it matches up well against entry hazard setters like Heatran, Landorus-T, and Garchomp. However, its vulnerability to all forms of entry hazards and lack of longevity make it a poor candidate to do it consistently. Ice Beam can be run to potentially 2HKO offensive Tornadus-T and OHKO Landorus-T, while Nature's Madness is an option to dent its checks hard—especially ones that lack reliable recovery—such as Ferrothorn, Galarian Slowking, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. However, forgoing Taunt or Defog loses out on Tapu Fini's utility, which makes shutting down walls and supporting its team needlessly more difficult. Tera Steel allows Tapu Fini to emergency check threats like Tapu Lele and Nasty Plot Tornadus-T; it also provides a better defensive typing against walls like Toxapex and Ferrothorn, which is more useful if using Taunt. The Speed EVs allow Tapu Fini to outspeed +1 Mega Gyarados, while the Special Attack EVs allow it to KO Urshifu-R after Stealth Rock. Gholdengo, Tornadus-T, and Ferrothorn are great teammates to deal with faster threats like boosted Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf users such as Kartana, Tapu Lele, and Landorus-T; Ferrothorn also provides Spikes to chip down foes like Ferrothorn, Garchomp, and Garganacl into Tapu Fini's KO range, compensating for its middling damage output. Offensive teammates like Volcarona, Kartana, and Weavile love its Misty Terrain to protect them against debilitating status from walls like Toxapex, Rotom-W, and Skeledirge, letting them set up and attack more safely; Volcarona also enjoys Tapu Fini luring in and crippling their shared checks like Toxapex and Clodsire with Trick, while Choice Band Weavile appreciates Tapu Fini removing Stealth Rock with Defog.

Meteor Beam.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Wall.description: Buzzwole serves as a solid wall, as its typing lets it take on some of the most powerful attackers in the tier, such as Zamazenta, Kingambit, and Great Tusk. Ice Punch allows Buzzwole to threaten Ground-types such as Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Clodsire, as well as Dragon Dance Dragapult and Dragonite. Bulk Up accumulates boosts alongside Pokemon such as Howl Zamazenta, Dragon Dance Dragapult, and defensive Mega Scizor, meaning they cannot overwhelm Buzzwole. Toxic is a niche alternative if Buzzwole's team wishes to play more proactively, as it cripples the likes of Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, and Skeledirge that would otherwise take advantage of Buzzwole. Heavy-Duty Boots ignores entry hazards, letting Buzzwole consistently switch into the Pokemon it gets tasked to counter without being worn down. Tera Water gives Buzzwole a Water resistance, allowing it to wall Pokemon such as Urshifu-R, Floatzel, and Barraskewda in rain. The given EV spread maximizes Buzzwole's physical bulk while ensuring it always outspeeds Kingambit. Buzzwole fits best on defensive teams, which appreciate it as a fallback measure against the myriad of physical wallbreakers while not caring for its relative passivity. Pokemon such as Clodsire and Hippowdon can shore up Buzzwole's weakness to common special attackers such as Mega Diancie, Dragapult, and Tapu Koko. Buzzwole appreciates pivots such as Toxapex, Tornadus-T, and Gliscor, which can absorb chip damage from moves like Scald, Salt Cure and—for the latter two—Knock Off. Buzzwole has a tendency to thud into Pokemon like Tornadus-T and Tapu Lele if not using Toxic, so it pairs well with the likes of Gholdengo and Weavile that can exploit them.

Defensive.description: 16 Defense EVs with a Relaxed Nature lets Celesteela live 2 Close Combats from Mega Lopunny from full.

Autotomize Sweeper.description: 196 Speed EVs outspeed Zamazenta after one Autotomize.

Choice Scarf.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Bulky Defog.description: Kartana serves as a good check to Pokemon like Garchomp, Mega Tyranitar, and Ogerpon-W lacking Superpower, while packing good utility with Defog. Its great matchup versus the former two, along with Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Ferrothorn exacerbate this, being particularly one of the most effective Defoggers in the metagame. With Grassium Z, Kartana is even more effective at removing entry hazards, being able to deal a massive blow to Garchomp, Landorus-T, and Gliscor, KOing even the latter two with minor chip. Knock Off is Kartana's coverage move of choice, removing Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Volcarona while giving it an avenue to make meaningful progress against Ferrothorn, Heatran, and Galarian Slowking. The given EV spread lets Bloom Doom OHKO offensive Garchomp, which could otherwise comfortably tank Leaf Blade and KO Kartana with its +2 Earthquake. Due to Kartana's ability to often lure Ground-types like Landorus-T, Gliscor, and Garchomp with its Bloom Doom, Tapu Koko makes for an excellent teammate, also appreciating Kartana's ability to keep Ferrothorn's entry hazards off the field; in return, Tapu Koko can check Flying-types like Zapdos and Tornadus-T for Kartana. Teammates that benefit from Kartana’s entry hazard removal like Nasty Plot Tornadus-T and Mega Charizard Y form a nice core with it as well, allowing them to stay healthy and hit the field to help break down Kartana’s checks like Zapdos and Heatran. Kartana is not without flaw as a Defogger; it is most notably helpless against Stealth Rock Heatran, so teammates that assist with Heatran such as Gliscor and Hisuian Samurott work well, being able to often trade entry hazards to help mitigate Kartana's inability to safely clear them in the face of Heatran. Furthermore, Kartana’s terrible Special Defense renders it unable to check Tapu Lele and Tapu Koko effectively unlike other Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Heatran, so teammates like Galarian Slowking, Weavile, and Landorus-T can ease these matchups.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Rillaboom is a decent wallbreaker that can easily break through offensive teams and revenge kill offensive staples like Iron Valiant and Iron Boulder with its strong priority move in Grassy Glide. Wood Hammer is an even stronger STAB move, allowing Rillaboom to dispatch defensive stopgaps like Toxapex and Landorus-T; its recoil is also partially offset by Grassy Terrain recovery. Knock Off lets Rillaboom force progress on its rather limited defensive answers like Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Zapdos by removing their Leftovers and Heavy-Duty Boots and making them more prone to being worn down by repeated hits or entry hazards, while Superpower shellacks supposed switch-ins like Heatran and Ferrothorn. U-turn lets Rillaboom pivot itself out from unfavorable matchups against the aforementioned Corviknight, as well as against Dragonite and Mega Scizor, letting it form a pivoting core with teammates like Urshifu-R or switch into threatening teammates like Volcarona and Heatran. Hawlucha in particular greatly benefits from being able to activate Unburden through Grassy Seed, giving it a Defense boost and letting it sweep weakened teams. In return, it threatens the Steel-types that wall Rillaboom, like Ferrothorn and Heatran. Dragon-types like Raging Bolt and Gouging Fire can be massive headaches for Rillaboom, so teammates that can threaten them, like Weavile, Iron Valiant, and Tapu Lele, are great partners for Rillaboom. On the flip side, teammates like Gouging Fire and Mega Scizor can struggle to break through bulky Water-types like Rotom-W and Toxapex, a job well-suited for Rillaboom. In return, those teammates appreciate Rillaboom's Grassy Terrain halving the power of miscellaneous uses of Earthquake, while they break through troublesome Steel- and Poison-types like Heatran and Galarian Slowking.

Swords Dance.description:
188 Speed EVs outspeed uninvested Heatran.
