The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Offensive Pivot.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Bulky Pivot.description: Cinderace is a good bulky pivot thanks to its high Speed, good Attack, and utility options in Will-O-Wisp and Court Change. These traits along with its typing let Cinderace act as a soft check to Pokemon like Iron Valiant, Kartana, and Mega Scizor, which is useful on offense and bulky offense teams. Will-O-Wisp cripples physically offensive Pokemon like Great Tusk, Garchomp, and Mega Mawile. Court Change helps temporarily keep off entry hazards, especially from the likes of Ferrothorn, while High Jump Kick OHKOes Mega Tyranitar and deals heavy damage to Heatran and Mega Diance. The given EV spread allows Cinderace to outspeed Iron Valiant and 2HKO maximum HP Galarian Slowking with Pyro Ball. Tera Fire bolsters Pyro Ball's damage, letting it OHKO offensive Volcarona and 2HKO Gliscor after Stealth Rock. Cinderace can form a VoltTurn core with other pivots like Tapu Koko and Meowscarada, as they can take advantage of its checks like Toxapex, Alomomola, and Rotom-W. In return, Cinderace can pivot in to help deal with their checks like Ferrothorn and Heatran. Cinderace struggles to damage defensive Pokemon like Zapdos, Landorus-T, and Great Tusk, making offensive teammates like Iron Boulder, Meowscarada, and Urshifu-R good options to help weaken or outright OHKO them. Teammates like Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko can benefit from Cinderace's ability to often burn Ground-types like Landorus-T, Great Tusk, and Garchomp, making it much easier to chip them down while reducing the power of their Ground-type STAB.

Bulk Up + Substitute.description: Substitute + Bulk Up Corviknight is a formidable wincon on balance teams, utilizing its elite bulk in combination with Pressure to PP stall would-be checks like Heatran, Zapdos, and Toxapex while still being a consistent check to Tapu Lele and Calm Mind Iron Valiant. Bulk Up is important for Corviknight to attempt a sweep in the later stages of the game as well as still be a functional check to the likes of Mega Scizor and Swords Dance Gliscor. Substitute lets Corviknight rack up boosts safely on more passive Pokemon like Clefable, Toxapex, and Galarian Slowking; it also prevents it from having its Leftovers removed from Knock Off and avoid status while also letting it waste more PP from Heatran's and Zapdos’s attacks. Tera Dragon is extremely important for Corviknight, as it lets it flip the matchup on Fire- and Electric-types like Volcarona, Mega Charizard Y, and Rotom-W, turning the latter two into setup fodder. The given EV spread allows Corviknight to live a boosted Continental Crush from Garchomp and outspeed uninvested Mega Scizor, with the rest maximizing its special bulk. Entry hazard support is crucial for Corviknight to sweep, as it needs to waste as much recovery PP as it can from its checks to sweep in the later stages of the game, making Clefable and Gliscor important teammates. Both of these also switch into Toxapex safely, while the latter can also pivot and take advantage of Heatran. Knock Off support further supplements Corviknight by crippling Zapdos, Toxapex, and Rotom-W, making Mega Tyranitar and Weavile good partners. Corviknight can often be worn down easily and forced to waste Roost PP early on if it is the sole defensive pivot, making it inefficient at sweeping, so pairing it up with a sturdy defensive backbone, for example Toxapex + Mega Latias, can help spread the load. Prior to Terastallizing, Corviknight can be forced out by strong Electric- and Fire-types like Tapu Koko, Heatran, and Raging Bolt, so having strong checks to these Pokemon such as the aforementioned Gliscor, Ting-Lu, and Draco Meteor Mega Latias is important.

Rain Wallbreaker.description: Choice Band Barraskewda serves as one of the best wallbreakers on rain teams due to its high Attack and Speed in conjunction with its rain- and Tera-boosted Water-type attacks. With Swift Swim, Barraskewda outspeeds nearly the entire metagame, including boosted foes like Iron Valiant, Iron Boulder, and Hawlucha. Liquidation's chance to drop Defense potentially lets Barraskewda beat Pokemon it normally can't on the switch in like Latias and Rotom-W. Aqua Jet allows it to finish off dangerous foes outside of rain like Volcarona and Iron Boulder. Flip Turn allows Barraskewda to pivot out on Pokemon like Toxapex and Dondozo while also chipping them and giving a free switch to its teammates like Mega Swampert. Close Combat KOes Ferrothorn and Archaludon after Stealth Rock and can chip Ogerpon-W on the switch. Psychic Fangs is a niche move that allows it to beat Pokemon that it would otherwise struggle against like Toxapex, but it doesn't do much else. Tera Water allows Barraskewda to significantly dent checks like Mega Latias and Rotom-W, as well as potentially breaking Toxapex after Defense drops. Pelipper is necessary teammate to set up rain, remove entry hazards, or pivot out with U-turn and let Barraskewda in safely due to its extreme frailty. Mega Swampert is an important teammate thanks to its immunity to Electric-type attacks from Raging Bolt and Rotom-W; it also threatens Toxapex and can wear down foes like Rotom-W and Ferrothorn so Barraskewda has an easier time muscling past them. Barraskewda is easily revenge killed by Rillaboom and Raging Bolt so defensive teammates like Iron Treads and Ferrothorn are necessary; they can also set up hazards that will wear down Barraskewda's checks like Ferrothorn and Rotom-W. Iron Treads in particular is a good partner because it pivots in Barraskewda with Volt Switch and removes hazards so Barraskewda can break through teams more often. In return, Barraskewda forces out Fighting- and Fire-types that check Iron Treads and Ferrothorn such as Mega Lopunny, Iron Valiant, and Volcarona. While it has a great Attack stat, Barraskewda struggles to beat defensive foes that resist Water-type attacks like Dondozo, Alomomola, Dragonite, and Tera Dragon Zapdos, so Archaludon is a good partner to threaten these foes. In return, Barraskewda threatens Ground- and Fire-types that check Archaludon such as Gliscor, Ting-Lu, and Volcarona.

Shell Smash.description: The set(s) displayed are used as a placeholder until an analysis is written for this Pokemon. Stay tuned for any updates!

Eject Button Support.description: Hatterene's access to Magic Bounce, a vast support movepool, and Eject Button gives it a key role on offense teams as a pivot and a way to prevent entry hazards. Healing Wish gives Hatterene the ability to fully heal one of its teammates, giving wallbreakers and setup Pokemon such as Mega Charizard Y and Kingambit another chance to break through the opposing team. Mystical Fire is generally preferred over Dazzling Gleam to hit Gholdengo, Ferrothorn, and Kingambit on the switch, but Dazzling Gleam can be used to threaten Dragonite, Garchomp, and Dragapult. Nuzzle provides Hatterene with a way to punish Pokemon that would safely pivot into it otherwise, such as Heatran and Tornadus-T. Eject Button gives Hatterene the ability to take a hit and pivot into a teammate, letting frail wallbreakers such as Mega Charizard Y and Weavile come onto the field. Tera Steel removes Hatterene's weaknesses to Ghost and Steel, letting it pass a Healing Wish or cripple an opposing Pokemon such as Dragapult and Gholdengo while retaining its advantage against Dragon-types, though typically you would want to Terastallize a teammate for more offensive pressure. The given EV spread lets Hatterene outspeed Garganacl and Toxapex while maximizing its ability to pivot into physical attacks. Hatterene greatly benefits teams that rely on keeping entry hazards off the field, such as sun teams and some offense teams. As such, Mega Charizard Y is a fantastic partner, as it appreciates Hatterene keeping Stealth Rock off the field and walling Toxapex; in return, it is able to pressure Pokemon Hatterene brings in, such as Gholdengo and Kingambit. Focus Sash users such as Polteageist and Cloyster also make for good teammates thanks to Hatterene's ability to keep off hazards. Similarly, pivots such as Tapu Lele and Dragapult appreciate Hatterene's ability to keep off hazards and give them a second chance with Healing Wish, letting them come in safely and consistently. Hatterene's lack of longevity means that it usually cannot act as the sole form of hazard control. As such, Rapid Spin Great Tusk is a good partner alongside Hatterene for keeping hazards off of the field while also being able to support Mega Charizard Y on sun teams.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Hatterene is a solid option for balance teams looking for both entry hazard control and a late-game wincon. Magic Bounce gives Hatterene a way to switch into entry hazard setters, utilize Calm Mind to force them out, and avoid status from Pokemon such as Garchomp and Toxapex. Psyshock lets Hatterene beat opposing Calm Mind and Quiver Dance sweepers like Iron Valiant and Volcarona, while Stored Power lets it bypass Skeledirge with enough Calm Mind boosts. Mystical Fire hits Kingambit, Gholdengo, and Ferrothorn super effectively. Draining Kiss acts as a form of recovery for Hatterene. Tera Water gives Hatterene a solid defensive typing while removing its weakness to Steel-type attacks from the likes of Gholdengo, Kingambit, and Mega Scizor. The given EV spread lets Hatterene outspeed Garganacl and Toxapex, letting Hatterene take out Toxapex with an attack before having its boosts removed by Haze. Hatterene works well when paired with Pokemon that dislike entry hazards, such as defensive Pokemon without Heavy-Duty Boots. These include partners like Toxapex and Garganacl, which can check other offensive and defensive Pokemon, giving Hatterene the leeway for a late-game sweep. Flyinium Z Tornadus-T appreciates Hatterene being able to Terastallize to force opposing Gholdengo to Terastallize, as well as keeping hazards off the field for it. Kingambit and Garganacl are great partners for their ability to reliably check Ghost-types like Dragapult and Gholdengo, with Kingambit even being able to Pursuit trap them. Great Tusk, Zamazenta, and Mega Scizor can check Kingambit for Hatterene as well. Hatterene's lack of longevity outside of Draining Kiss means that it appreciates a secondary form of entry hazard removal from teammates such as Tornadus-T, Zapdos, Great Tusk, Rotom-W, and Landorus-T. Alternatively, Hatterene enjoys pairing up with Spikes users such as Ferrothorn and Skarmory, as they pressure the opponent into using Defog, alleviating Hatterene's need to block entry hazards, as well as wearing down Hatterene's answers such as Heatran and Gholdengo.

Dual Screens.description: Grimmsnarl's solid defensive typing and Prankster make it a decent dual screens setter on hyper offense teams. Taunt denies Defog from foes such as Rotom-W and Tornadus-T and denies entry hazards from foes such as Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Hippowdon. It also prevents foes such as Volcarona and Annihilape from using Grimmsnarl as setup fodder. Spirit Break chips foes such as Ting-Lu and makes it easier to set up dual screens in front of special attackers such as Tapu Lele. Parting Shot can be used to pivot into teammates such as Dragonite, Dragapult, and Mega Scizor after setting screens, but it lets Dark-types such as Mega Tyranitar and Weavile—as well as Annihilape—exploit it, hindering its effectiveness. Superpower lets Grimmsnarl OHKO Kingambit after Stealth Rock, but it is ineffective outside of this matchup and is hard to justify over other alternatives. Grimmsnarl will very rarely Terastallize since teammates such as Dragonite take advantage of it far better. In a pinch, however, Tera Steel reverses its weaknesses and provides an overall solid defensive typing, which helps against foes such as Tapu Lele and Gholdengo. Tera Ghost is an alternative that prevents opposing Great Tusk from removing entry hazards with Rapid Spin. Teammates that take advantage of dual screen support such as Mega Scizor, Volcarona, Dragonite, and Kingambit make good partners, setting up safely and avoiding potential revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and opposing Kingambit. Mega Scizor is a particularly good partner, handling foes such as Kingambit that use Grimmsnarl as setup fodder. Grimmsnarl has difficulty denying entry hazards from foes such as Mega Tyranitar and Ting-Lu, so it appreciates teammates such as Cyclizar clearing hazards from the field. Cyclizar also appreciates dual screen support from Grimmsnarl making it more difficult for foes to break the Substitute it passes to teammates.

All-Out Attacker.description: With four attacks, Zamazenta wields an array of colorful coverage alongside the tier's highest unboosted Speed stat, threatening a majority of the metagame. Its natural bulk and Dauntless Shield give it opportunities to wallbreak via its prowess in offensively checking Mega Lopunny, Hisuian Samurott, and Ogerpon-W. Stone Edge pairs fantastically with Zamazenta's STAB, nailing Volcarona, Zapdos, Moltres, and Tornadus-T while avoiding adverse contact effects from the former three. Ice Fang is Zamazenta's only option to break through Gliscor and Landorus-T and its strongest attack against Dragonite. Heavy Slam is the preferred last coverage move to hit Clefable and render Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant incapable of soft checking Zamazenta, while Crunch threatens Psychic-types in Galarian Slowking, Slowbro, and Mega Latias. Wild Charge is Zamazenta's strongest attack against Toxapex but deals pitiful damage regardless without a Choice Band and can still be easily pivoted against even with the boost. Heavy-Duty Boots increase Zamazenta's longevity, allowing it to switch in and threaten opposing teams more often, whereas Choice Band provides more immediate power, albeit at the cost of being incredibly prediction-reliant to break through most teams carrying multiple Fighting-resistant foes. Rockium Z is a niche alternative that reduces difficulties in KOing Zapdos by minimizing the need for prior chip damage mitigating and Stone Edge's meager accuracy. It also helps in breaking through Fighting-resistant Pokemon such as Clefable and Galarian Slowking without the correct coverage move once properly chipped. Tera Fighting is preferred to boost Close Combat's power against neutral targets such as Ogerpon-W and Alomomola, with chances to OHKO and 2HKO them, respectively, without Choice Band and muscle through checks such as Tornadus-T. Alternatively, Tera Steel flips the tables against Choice Scarf Tapu Lele's revenge killing attempts and secures the KO on Clefable after minimal chip. Zamazenta can fit on more defensive teams as speed control that forces out offensive terrors such as Ogerpon-W to supplement a defensive core, or it can be used on offensive teams supported by other wallbreakers while helping check threats to such teams such as Mega Lopunny with its natural bulk and Dauntless Shield. Regardless, its best support remains Future Sight from Tapu Lele, Galarian Slowking, or Slowbro, as Zamazenta is most often handled by switching between Pokemon that resist its moves and physically bulky pivots such as Galarian Slowking, Landorus-T, and Alomomola or stopped in its tracks by Toxapex. Future Sight punishes these situations by dealing massive damage, particularly against Toxapex. Similarly, Pursuit support from Mega Tyranitar and Weavile weakens or removes pivots such as Galarian Slowking, Mega Latias, and Zapdos.

Iron Defense + Body Press.description: Boasting extraordinary physical bulk and the highest unboosted Speed in the tier, Zamazenta can use Iron Defense and Body Press to become a powerful setup sweeper and cleaner. Substitute allows Zamazenta to set up on Pokemon such as Gliscor and Alomomola that heavily rely on Toxic for their offensive pressure and to be unthreatened by Knock Off from the likes of Mega Tyranitar and Hisuian Samurott, while Heavy Slam allows Zamazenta to immediately threaten Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant, both of which commonly use Choice Scarf and Booster Energy respectively to outspeed Zamazenta and have enough bulk coupled with a Fighting resistance to take a Body Press and threaten Zamazenta immediately. Alternatively, Crunch can be used to deal with Galarian Slowking and is also stronger than Heavy Slam against Pokemon such as Ferrothorn that commonly Terastallize into the Ghost typing, and Stone Edge is another option that threatens Volcarona and Zapdos while avoiding Flame Body and Static, respectively, and allows Zamazenta to deal with Tornadus-T without the need to Terastallize. Zamazenta struggles to break through Pokemon such as Galarian Slowking, Zapdos, and Toxapex that have the bulk to take multiple boosted Body Press and either threaten it back directly or can use Haze to remove Zamazenta's boosts. Therefore, teammates such as Mega Tyranitar that can Pursuit trap and wear down these Pokemon are invaluable. Other options such as Calm Mind Iron Valiant can also trade for heavy damage against most of these Pokemon, clearing the way for Zamazenta to sweep. Tera Electric allows Zamazenta to turn Zapdos into a setup opportunity, resisting both of its STAB attacks and being unafraid of Static, while Tera Steel allows Zamazenta to set up on Choice-locked Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant as well as turning Heavy Slam into an OHKO on both.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Urshifu-R becomes a powerful wallbreaker after a single boost, threatening common metagame threats like Gliscor, Ferrothorn, Landorus-T, and Heatran with its power and coverage. Surging Strikes even has the additional merit of bypassing Defense boosts from the likes of Zamazenta, Garganacl, and Great Tusk. Trailblaze is the recommended move for the last slot as it allows Urshifu-R to avoid revenge killing from naturally fast Pokemon such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele. Thunder Punch is an alternative that threatens Pokemon like Toxapex, Slowbro, and Alomomola. Tera Steel is advised for preventing revenge killing from the likes of Tornadus-T, Iron Valiant, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, while granting a Toxic immunity allowing it to use Alomomola as setup fodder. If using Thunder Punch, however, Tera Electric is recommended to meaningfully threaten Toxapex and Slowbro notably letting Urshifu-R OHKO Toxapex with Tera Electric Thunder Punch after a boost. Protective Pads is recommended to ignore problematic abilities like Rough Skin, Iron Barbs, Static, and Flame Body, from Pokemon like Garchomp, Ferrothorn, Zapdos, and Moltres. Urshifu-R has a hard time sweeping without Trailblaze, so defensive options to fall back on like Ferrothorn, Mega Scizor, Garganacl, and Zapdos are appreciated. Variants without Thunder Punch struggle against common Water-types like Toxapex and Dondozo, so special wallbreakers that can force them out such as Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko are good teammates.

Choice Band.description: Urshifu-R's decent Speed tier, powerful STAB combination, and Choice Band allow it to break past common bulky Pokemon like Landorus-T, Galarian Slowking, and Ferrothorn. U-turn allows Urshifu-R to maintain momentum against Pokemon that it would usually struggle to deal meaningful damage against such as Slowbro and Mega Latias. Aqua Jet allows Urshifu-R to revenge kill faster Pokemon such as chipped Mega Diancie and Volcarona. Thunder Punch can deal considerable damage to the likes of Toxapex and Slowbro. Urshifu-R makes use of Tera Water to deal massive damage with Surging Strikes and force its typical checks like Iron Defense Zamazenta and Galarian Slowking to switch out. It appreciates teammates like Galarian Slowking due to its ability to set Future Sight to break past Toxapex and Alomomola and Mega Scizor, which can also cover Urshifu-R's bad matchup against Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele. Both Galarian Slowking and Mega Scizor are able to pivot, bringing Urshifu-R in safely against Pokemon such as Heatran and Mega Tyranitar. Water-types such as Slowbro, Alomomola, and Toxapex are roadblocks for Urshifu-R, so partners that threaten them like Tapu Koko and Raging Bolt are appreciated. Tapu Koko can also boost the damage of Urshifu-R's Thunder Punch with Electric Terrain. Zapdos is able to hinder Urshifu-R with Static, making Mega Diancie, Kyurem, and Iron Valiant valuable options for teammates with their shared ability to threaten Zapdos. Urshifu-R is also threatened by faster offensive Pokemon such as Iron Valiant, Tapu Koko, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, which makes bulkier Pokemon such as Ferrothorn, Galarian Slowking, and Gliscor excellent partners.

Choice Scarf.description: With the Speed boost from Choice Scarf, Urshifu-R is one of the strongest pivots and cleaners in the metagame. It can outspeed many common threats like Mega Lopunny, Greninja, Ogerpon-W, Mega Diancie, and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele while also being able to revenge kill many setup sweepers even after a boost, such as Mega Gyarados and Gouging Fire. Addtionally, Surging Strikes allows Urshifu-R to OHKO Focus Sash users like Glimmora and Landorus-T while also improving its matchup against Zamazenta, bypassing its Dauntless Shield Defense boost. U-turn provides Urshifu-R the utility to gain momentum from its checks like Alomomola, Slowbro, Toxapex, and Corviknight. Aqua Jet can serve as a backup plan to revenge kill faster setup sweepers like Volcarona, while Thunder Punch can hit bulky Water-types like Alomomola, Toxapex, and Slowbro as well as Corviknight. Tera Water enables Urshifu-R to achieve valuable OHKOes versus the likes of Tapu Lele, Tapu Koko, and Mega Lopunny, while also strengthening Aqua Jet to better combat setup sweepers like Iron Boulder. Teammates like Raging Bolt and Tapu Lele appreciate Urshifu-R's ability to bring them in against bulky defensive walls like Corviknight, Alomomola, and Toxapex. Tapu Lele can also set strong Future Sight for Urshifu-R to abuse and break through Toxapex. However, it is recommended to not to use Aqua Jet when Urshifu-R is paired with Tapu Lele due to its Psychic Surge. Abilities like Rough Skin, Static, and Flame Body as well as Rocky Helmet punish Choice Scarf Urshifu-R due to the multi-hit nature of Surging Strikes, so teammates with access to Knock Off like Landorus-T and Tornadus-T are useful to help Urshifu-R by removing Rocky Helmet from the aforementioned foes as well as Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Zapdos and Moltres.

Bulk Up.description:
140 Speed EVs outspeed uninvested Corviknight.

The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Choice Specs.description: Choice Specs Enamorus is a potent wallbreaker, utilizing its strong Moonblast alongside colorful coverage to punch severe holes into defensive cores. Earth Power and Mystical Fire complement its STAB Moonblast well, with the former hitting Toxapex, Clodsire, Gholdengo, and Heatran, while the latter OHKOes Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor. Focus Blast grants Enamorus its strongest attack to hit Garganacl and Mega Tyranitar, which could otherwise survive Earth Power and Moonblast, respectively, while Psychic provides a safer middle ground option for Toxapex Clodsire, and Mega Venusaur, which staves off its attacks otherwise. Tera Fairy grants Enamorus a power boost to Moonblast, notably allowing it to secure OHKOs against the likes of Landorus-T and Rotom-W, which would barely survive it otherwise. Enamorus fits best on bulky offense teams that appreciate its wallbreaking power while being able to support it adequately. Pivots such as Mega Lopunny, Landorus-T, and Tornadus-T grant Enamorus free switch in opportunities against Great Tusk, opposing Landorus-T, and Rotom-W. The latter two pivots and Great Tusk, also provide entry hazard removal, which aids Enamorus given its Stealth Rock weakness. Enamorus works well with fast cleaners such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Kartana, as they appreciate Enamorus punching holes into the likes of Gholdengo and Mega Scizor for the latter two to clean up weakened defensive cores.

Calm Mind.description: Calm Mind Enamorus serve as a solid wallbreaker, using forced switches from the likes of Great Tusk and Garchomp to set up. It is incredibly difficult to switch into after a boost given its strong Moonblast alongside coverage options in Earth Power and Mystical Fire to hit Fairy-resistant foes such as Heatran, Toxapex, and Ferrothorn, respectively. Alternatively, Enamorus can forgo Mystical Fire for Substitute to take advantage of pivoting attempts as well as sponge attacks from revenge killers such as Mega Lopunny and Iron Valiant, although it makes it less effective at hitting Ferrothorn and Mega Scizor. If using Substitute, Enamorus can opt for Leftovers instead of the standard Heavy-Duty Boots to potentially set up more Substitutes. Tera Ground boosts the power of Earth Power, allowing it to KO most Toxapex and Gholdengo sets after a boost, as well as giving it an immunity to Tapu Koko and Rotom-W's Electric-type attacks. Enamorus fits best on bulky offense and offense teams that appreciate its use as an early- to mid-game wallbreaker while granting it sufficient opportunities to enter the field. Therefore, pivots such as Mega Lopunny and Landorus-T pair well with it, bringing Enamorus in on physical walls it can exploit such as Great Tusk, Buzzwole, and Skarmory. Additionally, Pursuit trappers such as Mega Tyranitar and Weavile eliminate special walls such as Clodsire and Gholdengo that can serve as a roadblock to Enamorus. Fast late-game cleaners such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Choice Scarf Kartana appreciate Enamorus, as they capitalize on it weakening or removing Steel-types for them to clean up.

Choice Scarf.description: Choice Scarf Enamorus functions as an interesting revenge killer, being able to KO a range of setup sweepers such as Dragonite, Mega Gyarados, Baxcalibur, and even a weakened Volcarona courtesy of its great speed tier. Additionally, it can serve as a late-game cleaner once its checks such as Toxapex, Gholdengo, and Assault Vest Tornadus-T have been weakened by its teammates. However, its Stealth Rock weakness and relative frailty mean Enamorus struggles to withstand repeated switches as well as priority moves from the likes of Urshifu-R and Mega Lopunny. Tera Fairy boosts the power of Moonblast, notably allowing it to 2HKO Assault Vest Tornadus-T after Stealth Rock. Aside from coverage to hit Steel-types in Mystical Fire and Earth Power, Healing Wish can bring back a weakened teammate in a pinch, potentially being able to change the tide of a game. Therefore, Enamorus fits best on offense teams that appreciate its utility in Healing Wish while providing a positive matchup against opposing offensive teams. Powerful wallbreakers such as Baxcalibur and Volcarona appreciate Enamorus's Healing Wish, giving them a second lease on life, while Enamorus in turn capitalizes on them weakening the likes of Toxapex and Mega Scizor to clean late-game. Enamorus also greatly enjoys entry hazard removal support from Rotom-W, Tornadus-T, or Great Tusk, as it minimalizes its Stealth Rock weakness so it can switch in more effectively mid-game. Enamorus struggles with special wall such as Clodsire and Gholdengo, so Pokemon such as Landorus-T and Great Tusk make for good partners that can take advantage of them.

Offensive Pivot.description: Meowscarada is a powerful offensive pivot that utilizes its good Attack, high Speed, and great coverage to support teammates like Landorus-T. Triple Axel helps against Flying-types like Zapdos and Tornadus-T, and it can OHKO Gliscor, Landorus-T, and Garchomp. Toxic Spikes, when paired with Pokemon like Tapu Lele and Landorus-T that pressure Toxic Spikes absorbers such as Toxapex and Galarian Slowking, can be hard to deal with and put setup sweepers like Iron Boulder on a timer. Spikes can be used to chip down foes like Ferrothorn and Toxapex after they have had their Heavy-Duty Boots removed. U-turn pivots out Meowscarda from its checks like Toxapex and Ferrothorn and brings in wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Zamazenta against them. Protective Pads protects Meowscarada from the abilities of Garchomp, Ferrothorn, and Zapdos and Rocky Helmet Pokemon like on Landorus-T, while Heavy-Duty Boots lets it avoid getting worn down by entry hazards. Tera Grass can help Meowscarada survive moves like Moonblast from Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Aqua Jet from Urshifu-R, if Protean has changed its type. Entry hazard setters like Garganacl, Landorus-T, and Gliscor appreciate having Meowscarada as a teammate, as it can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from foes such as Toxapex and Zapdos, making their hazards more potent. Meowscarada's mediocre defenses and weaknesses to Fighting-, Fire-, and Flying-type attacks mean it appreciates defensive teammates like Clefable, Alomomola, and Ferrothorn that resist or are neutral to those attacks. Meowscarada can pair well with other pivots like Landrous-T and Iron Crown, forming a VoltTurn core to help it deal with its checks like Toxapex. Meowscarada also pairs well with wallbreakers like Urshifu-R and Zamazenta, which can help break through checks like Ferrothorn.

Defensive.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Iron Defense + Body Press.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Stealth Rock.description: Garganacl is a practical Stealth Rock setter due to its high bulk, amazing ability, and access to Salt Cure. Garganacl can safely set up Stealth Rock against common pivots like Ferrothorn, Alomomola, and Galarian Slowking. Common Defog users like Zapdos, Corviknight, and Moltres can barely threaten Garganacl and take dangerous passive damage from Salt Cure. Other entry hazard removal Pokemon like Landorus-T and Great Tusk also dislike Salt Cure as they rely on Leftovers for passive recovery. Protect is crucial for Garganacl for passive recovery from Leftovers and to exacerbate chip damage from Salt Cure. It can also help to scout moves from Choice item users like Tapu Lele and Rillaboom, as well as stalling weather turns against rain and sun teams. However, it is important not to rely on Protect too much to the point where Garganacl can be exploited by opponents. Garganacl has a variety of good Tera types; Tera Water turns the tables versus Pokemon like Urshifu-Rapid-Strike and Mega Scizor and performs better against rain and sun, but leaves it vulernable to opposing Garganacl and Electric-types like Raging Bolt and Tapu Koko. Tera Dragon has most of the advantages of Tera Water in addition to checking Ogerpon-W and Mega Charizard Y, but it makes Garganacl weak to Iron Valiant and Tapu Lele. Tera Fairy and Tera Ghost both help Garganacl to check Fighting-types like Zamazenta and Mega Lopunny. Teammates like Ogerpon-W and Mega Lopunny appreciate Garganacl's ability to threaten Water- and Flying-types. Garganacl also benefits from them dealing with offensive targets like Tapu Lele and opposing Ogerpon-W. Garganacl's main way to gain momentum is via Salt Cure, so foes with Abilities like Regenerator and Poison Heal can nullify its chip damage. It is therefore very helpful to have teammates like Weavile, Tornadus-T, and Tapu Koko to spam Knock Off or threaten common Regenerator pivots.

Curse.description: Curse Garganacl is a solid wincon that can turn games around in the blink of an eye. Curse in conjunction with Terastallization lets it take hits from common physical attackers like Mega Lopunny, Great Tusk, and Landorus-T, and its ability prevents it from getting Toxic poisoned, a major roadblock to slow setup sweepers. Salt Cure allows Garganacl to chip foes and is complemented by Attack boosts from Curse; it also discourages common threats to Garganacl like Iron Crown and Urshifu-R from switching in directly. Earthquake hits almost all foes for decent damage with enough boosts, threatening Steel- and Electric-types like Iron Crown, Raging Bolt, Galarian Slowking, and Tapu Koko for particularly high damage; Salt Cure covers Flying-types that Earthquake cannot reach. Heavy Slam deals immediate damage to Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, and Clefable, which threaten to deal massive damage with their STAB moves or are immune to Salt Cure's passive damage in the latter's case. Tera Water allows Garganacl to beat common Water-types like Manaphy, Urshifu-R, and Mega Swampert, giving its team a positive matchup against rain teams. Tera Fairy allows Garganacl to resist Fighting-type moves from Urshifu-R, Zamazenta, and Mega Lopunny, especially when unboosted, as Garganacl gets several free turns to set up after surprising these foes. Garganacl is a fat momentum sapper that lends itself well to balance teams, as they are able to compensate for its lack of immediate power with their ability to withstand heavy damage; Alomomola, a commonly seen Pokemon on these archetypes, is a great ally that can heal up Garganacl, allowing it to be used more recklessly with Salt Cure to offset the passivity of other allies. Garganacl is extremely hampered by Taunt and Knock Off users, as they prevent it from setting up and healing and prevent Leftovers passive recovery. It is best to wait for such foes to be eliminated before trying to set up. Therefore, Knock Off absorbers like Mega Scizor and Gliscor are good teammates to threaten Knock Off users including Hisuian Samurott and Ferrothorn. Garganacl performs best when used with Terastallization, as its base typing gives it nasty weaknesses to common foes like Zamazenta and Landorus-T; thus, allies should try not to expend Terastallization early-game. This means that a solid defensive core, such as Alomomola and Heatran, should be used to help with the longevity of the team and can chip down foes until it is safe to set up.

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Ceruledge is a massively threatening wallbreaker that fits well on hyper-offensive teams due to its ability to threaten common defensive pieces, like Galarian Slowking and Ferrothorn, while being able to take on offensive threats such as Volcarona and Iron Valiant thanks to its typing. Close Combat is a good coverage option, letting Ceruledge dent bulky Dark-types like Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar; alternatively, Shadow Sneak offers a form of priority that can pick off unsuspecting revenge killers like Iron Boulder. Focus Sash allows Ceruledge to usually guarantee an oppotunity to set up one Swords Dance, while Ghostium Z turns Poltergeist into a nuke that can eviscerate even the bulkiest of Pokemon, OHKOing even Alomomola and Toxapex at +2. Tera Ghost allows Poltergeist to be boosted to ludicrous power levels without having to invest in Ghostium Z, letting Ceruledge OHKO offensive Great Tusk and Gliscor after a boost. Bulky Dark-types, like the aforementioned Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar, can force Ceruledge out - therefore, Fighting-types such as Urshifu-R and Zamazenta as well as Fairy-types such as Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant are great partners for it. In return, all of them appreciate Ceruledge being able to threaten bulky Pokemon that might try to take their attacks, such as Galarian Slowking, Alomomola, Toxapex, and Heatran. Revenge killers like Choice Scarf Urshifu-R and Samurott-H also limit Ceruledge's ability to impact the game beyond potentially grabbing one KO, so teammates that can deal with them, such as Mega Scizor and Dragonite, are highly appreciated. Water-types like the aforementioned Urshifu-R and Ogerpon-W are also effective teammates for Ceruledge, as they can come in on Water-type attacks from opposing Urshifu-R and Samurott-H while being able to rely on Ceruledge to break through troublesome Grass-types like Ferrothorn.

Suicide Lead.description: Glimmora is a valuable dedicated lead on hyper offense teams that can reliably set up multiple entry hazards in Stealth Rock, Toxic Spikes, and potentially Spikes, as well as remove opposing ones with Mortal Spin. It can make use of its solid coverage options and remarkable Special Attack to pose a noticeable offensive threat itself, especially against common entry hazard setters, removers, and other dedicated leads. Power Gem threatens the metagame's best Defogger in Tornadus-T, while Sludge Bomb dents screens setters such as Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko and—if Focus Sash is still intact—Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant as well, which can be problematic against offensive teams. Earth Power pressures Steel-types like Heatran, Gholdengo, and Kingambit that would otherwise block Glimmora's Mortal Spin, while Energy Ball deals with other entry hazard setters and removers such as Great Tusk, Gastrodon, Mega Swampert, and Rotom-W. Focus Sash guarantees that Glimmora can set at least one layer of entry hazards, potentially letting Toxic Debris trigger twice as well. Tera Ghost is used in a pinch to spinblock foes such as Great Tusk and Excadrill and remove its Ground weakness to set up multiple entry hazards in the face of other setters like Landorus-T, Garchomp, and Gastrodon. Gholdengo is a near-mandatory teammate to keep up entry hazards by blocking every attempts to remove them, such as Defog and Rapid Spin. Setup sweepers like Kingambit, Volcarona, Dragapult, Dragonite, and Iron Valiant appreciate entry hazards wearing down foes such as Dondozo and Clodsire and not being chipped down by opposing ones themselves; particularly, Kingambit's Knock Off can remove Heavy-Duty Boots from the likes of Tornadus-T, Toxapex, and Volcarona to make them vulnerable to Glimmora's entry hazards.

Wall.description: With massive physical bulk, the superb ability of Unaware, and a solid defensive typing, Dondozo functions as a sturdy wall to many of the physical threats roaming the tier. While it prefers Liquidation, Waterfall is a good alternative, trading power and a potential Defense drop for greater PP, allowing Dondozo to continually chip away at threats during longer games. Curse turns Dondozo into an intimidating win condition in the later stages of the game, able to set up on the likes of Mega Mawile and Gouging Fire, while Body Press allows Dondozo to hit Water-resistant foes like Ferrothorn and Ogerpon-W. Tera Dragon flips the matchup on Pokemon which would normally threaten it, such as Kartana, Rillaboom, and especially Ogerpon-W. Due to its passive nature, Dondozo is found mainly on bulky teams, partnering well with Pokemon like Gliscor and Ting-Lu, which can handle Dondozo checks like Toxapex, Mega Latios, and Mega Latias, while Dondozo can check the Water-types that would threaten them, like Urshifu-R or Hisuian Samurott. Dondozo usually carries Heavy-Duty Boots as its item to ensure it can switch in safely when it is used on teams with less reliable entry hazard removal, though if paired with a reliable hazard remover like Tornadus-T, Dondozo can opt for Leftovers to shore up its poor recovery, allowing it to 1v1 threats such as Mega Scizor and Zamazenta more reliably.

Unaware Wall.description: Clodsire serves as a fantastic special wall, able to take on powerful attackers such as Dragapult and Mega Diancie while simultaneously stopping setup sweepers such as Gholdengo and Volcarona. Spikes are preferred on Clodsire, as the move has more limited distribution and Clodsire enters the field commonly enough to have the opportunity to use the move. However, Stealth Rock can be used if Clodsire's team requires it. Toxic is used to cripple common switch-ins to Clodsire, such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Great Tusk. Poison Jab can be used to poison post-Tera Gholdengo attempting to remove its Ground weakness, and it forces damage on Tornadus-T faster. Heavy-Duty Boots are preferred on Clodsire to negate its weakness to opposing Spikes teams, although Leftovers are also viable to increase Clodsire's longevity. Unaware is preferred over Water Absorb to negate Clodsire's passivity against setup sweepers, and Water Absorb does little to help against the likes of Mega Swampert and Gastrodon. Tera Dark grants Clodsire a Ghost resistance, which helps against Choice Specs Dragapult and Gholdengo, especially if using Poison Jab against the latter. It also grants Clodsire with a Pursuit resistance against the likes of Kingambit and Mega Tyranitar, which can both exploit its physical frailty. Clodsire fits best on defensively oriented teams that appreciate its special walling and entry hazard support. As Clodsire is weak to most physical attackers such as Kingambit, Great Tusk, and Dragonite, teammates that can cover them, such as Toxapex, Skeledirge, and Buzzwole, make for good partners. In return, Clodsire can switch into Electric-type attacks for the former, and powerful special attackers such as Dragapult for the latter two. Pokemon that benefit from Spikes support, such as Tornadus-T and Gholdengo, also pair well with Clodsire, as Spikes puts pressure on checks to them such as Ting-Lu and Mega Tyranitar. In return, Clodsire appreciates these teammates being able to make more immediate progress. Knock Off users such as the aforementioned Tornadus-T as well as Weavile and Mega Scizor pair well with Clodsire, crippling Heavy-Duty Boots users such as opposing Clodsire and Toxapex, giving Clodsire's entry hazards support a greater impact.

Offensive.description: Great Tusk possesses a lot of invaluable traits with its amazing physical bulk, solid defensive typing, and role compression, all contributing to making it a good Pokemon. Earthquake can be used over Headlong Rush to have a strong STAB without drawbacks, but the power difference is noticeable. Stealth Rock can be used over Close Combat if the team lacks a Stealth Rock setter, but leaves Great Tusk unable to dent Rotom-W and Ting-Lu. Rapid Spin is essential, since it both boosts Great Tusk's Speed and clears entry hazards, which it won’t have a hard time doing against common hazard setters like Landorus-T and Garchomp. Icium Z + Ice Spinner lets it destroy switch-ins like Zapdos and Tornadus-T while also chipping down Moltres for a good amount of damage. Tera Water lets it emergency check Urshifu-R, while Tera Ground lets it deal large amounts of damage with Headlong Rush against Pokemon like Mega Scizor and Volcarona. Tera Steel lets Great Tusk eat a hit from Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant in a pinch, but gaining a Fighting weakness isn’t so desirable. Great Tusk hates having to deal with Zapdos and Moltres due to being threatened by Static and Flame Body, so Pokemon that can deal with them, such as Tapu Koko and Mega Tyranitar, are appreciated. In return, it clears hazards for both of them and beats their checks like Ferrothorn and Ting-Lu.

Defensive.description: Defensively, Great Tusk is a behemoth that is able to shrug off hits from threats like Mega Lopunny and Dragonite while providing the team with good utility options. Ice Spinner helps Great Tusk to not be fodder against Gliscor, Tornadus-T and Zapdos. Body Press lets it deal with Mega Lopunny and pressure Ferrothorn. 56 Speed EVs let it outspeed Garchomp after one speed boost from Rapid Spin. Tera Water lets it check Pokemon like Mega Swampert and Urshifu-RS in a pinch. Tera Dragon allows it to check Ogerpon-W, and deal with Heatran better. Tera Poison provides a useful Toxic immunity. Great Tusk is often set up fodder for Pokemon like aforementioned Iron Valiant, so Pokemon that can deal with it, like Volcarona and Galarian Slowking, are appriciated. In return, it checks Mega Tyranitar and Gliscor for them while also providing Rapid Spin support.

Defensive Bulk Up.description: Bulk Up boosts Great Tusk’s already high Attack and Defense even further, allowing it to brute force past would-be checks like Ferrothorn, Alomomola, and opposing Great Tusk, turning them into set-up fodder with Terastallization. Earthquake is chosen over Headlong Rush, as the damage is sufficient with Bulk Up boosts, and the Defense and Special Defense drops can make Great Tusk easier to revenge kill. Ice Spinner lets it break past Pokemon like Tornadus-T, Zapdos, and Landorus. Rapid Spin acts as a secondary boosting move for Great Tusk, alleviating its mediocre Speed tier and allowing it to sweep undeterred. The given EV spread allows Great Tusk to outspeed Ogerpon-W after a Rapid Spin boost, with the rest used to maximize its physical bulk. Tera Poison prevents Great Tusk from being hit by Toxic while providing crucial resistances to Fairy- and Fighting-type attacks. Tera Electric provides a Flying resistance, allowing Great Tusk to use Zapdos and Tornadus-T as setup fodder while also preventing it from getting paralyzed by Static. Tera Steel combines the Flying resistance from Electric with the Fairy resistance and Toxic immunity from Poison while adding on a Psychic resistance at the cost of being weak to Fighting. Due to its relatively low Speed tier even after a boost, Great Tusk will need help against revenge killers like Iron Valiant and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, so Pokemon that can handle the two, such as Mega Scizor, Slowking-G, and Heatran, are appreciated. A more offensive set utilising Booster Energy can also be used on hyper offense teams, but it is generally less effective compared to other choices.

Choice Band.description: STAB U-turn and First Impression combined with a massive Attack stat make Slither Wing a solid wallbreaker, revenge killer, and pivot. First Impression clears Pokemon such as Kartana while also denting Bug-resistant Pokemon such as Dragapult and Mega Lopunny. U-turn lets Slither Wing obtain momentum while also chipping switch-ins like Tornadus-T and Landorus-T. Flare Blitz tears through Gholdengo and is Slither Wing's strongest attack against Landorus-T and Gliscor, while Earthquake hits Pokemon like Toxapex and Skeledirge while still threatening Gholdengo as well. Tera Bug bolsters First Impression's power to high levels, maximizing Slither Wing's revenge killing potential and enabling it to spread much more chip damage with U-turn; however, it gains a Stealth Rock weakness. Slither Wing pairs well with Mega Charizard Y, as it enables Protosynthesis, which lets Slither Wing threaten the opposition more often. It also boosts Flare Blitz, letting it dent Landorus-T and Gliscor better. In return, Mega Charizard Y threatens Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Gholdengo. Special wallbreakers that wear down Slither Wing checks such as Mega Diancie and Tapu Koko pair well with it; they also benefit from Slither Wing breaking their checks. Slither Wing lures in Flying-types such as Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Dragonite, so Pokemon such as Weavile and Tapu Koko pair well with it, both notably forcing Dragonite to Terastallize into the Normal-type and making it prone to First Impression.

Entry Hazard Lead.description: Iron Treads has a niche as an interesting entry hazard lead in the metagame. With both Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, it can lay entry hazards while keeping them off for its teammates, and it is very threatening to Magic Bounce Pokemon in Mega Diancie and Hatterene. Steel Beam allows Iron Treads to sacrifice itself quickly in order to deny Defog attempts from the likes of Tornadus-T, Landorus-T, and Rotom-W. It is also Iron Treads's main tool of pressuring Hatterene, and it is generally powerful enough to chunk certain Ground-resistant and immune Pokemon, like Landorus-T, Tornadus-T, and Buzzwole. Booster Energy and Quark Drive together allows Iron Treads to outrun the entire unboosted metagame as well as Choice Scarf users like Tapu Lele, Urshifu-R, and Gholdengo, allowing it to consistently lay entry hazards. Tera Ghost allows Iron Treads to block opposing Rapid Spin attempts from Great Tusk if necessary. Iron Treads should be used as a lead on hyper offense teams, so other support teammates and sweepers are natural partners. Dual screens setters like Grimmsnarl and Tapu Koko allow their sweeping teammates another layer of support and safety, and they can use Taunt to consistently deny Defog attempts even after Iron Treads has fainted. Common hyper offense sweepers, like Mega Gyarados, Galarian Moltres, Kingambit, Volcarona, and Baxcalibur appreciate Iron Treads laying Stealth Rock while keeping hazards off at the same time. The former two in particular appreciate this, as Mega Gyarados is weak to Stealth Rock before mega evolving, while Galarian Moltres often prefers other items over Heavy-Duty Boots.

Bulky Swords Dance.description: With fantastic defensive and offensive stats, Iron Hands can act as a bulky setup sweeper or a strong wallbreaker for its team. Due to its amazing bulk, Iron Hands is able to setup Swords Dance reliably to punch holes through foes more easily. Ice Punch allows Iron Hands to hit Gliscor, Landorus-T and Garchomp super effectively, complementing its STAB moves nicely. Iron Hands can use Tera Water to take otherwise super effective hits from the likes of Tapu Lele, Mega Diancie, and Great Tusk, alongside gaining a resistance to Water-type moves, allowing Iron Hands to answer common rain abusers including Mega Swampert and Barraskewda, while Tera Flying makes Iron Hands immune to Ground-type moves from the likes of Landorus-T and Garchomp. The given EV spread allows Iron Hands to survive an unboosted Tapu Lele Psychic from full HP, while the Speed investment lets Iron Hands outspeed Clefable. Because of Iron Hands's poor Speed but fantastic bulk, it's more suited to bulky offense and balance teams as opposed to hyper offensive team structures. Pokemon like Landorus-T, Gliscor and Tornadus-T are fantastic teammates because they can switch into the strong Ground-type moves that threaten Iron Hands such as Great Tusk's Headlong Rush; in addition, they can all remove entry hazards, which is appreciated by Tera Flying variants, and the former two are also able to set hazards, helping Iron Hands break through teams more easily. Rillaboom can setup Grassy Terrain, weakening opposing Earthquake and giving Iron Hands more passive recovery alongside Leftovers while weakening the defensive Ground-types that could stop Iron Hands, although it should be noted Tera Flying variants will not benefit from the terrain. Defensive Steel-types such as Heatran, Ferrothorn, and Iron Crown are good teammates because they can come in on the Psychic- and Fairy- types that Iron Hands dislikes, such as Tapu Lele, Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and Mega Latios. Alomomola boosts Iron Hands's longevity with Wish while being a good answer to Ground-types such as Great Tusk and Garchomp. Strong special attackers such as Mega Diancie, Serperior, Tapu Lele, and Volcarona appreciate Iron Hands breaking through common special walls like Galarian Slowking, Corviknight, Ferrothorn, and Gliscor, and in return they break through physically defensive walls like Landorus-T and Dondozo. Thunder Wave users such as Galarian Slowking and Ferrothorn slow down foes such as Corviknight and Skarmory for Iron Hands to outspeed afterwards, so that it can hit them with boosted attacks before they can setup against it with Iron Defense.

Choice Specs.description: Iron Jugulis serves as a solid wallbreaker, utilizing its solid STAB combination, coverage, and Speed tier to threaten foes. Earth Power snipes would-be checks like Heatran, Toxapex, and Mega Diancie. U-turn lets Iron Jugulis pivot into Pokemon that solve unfavorable matchups for it such as Kartana and Mega Scizor while also providing momentum for teammates like Tapu Koko and Great Tusk. Tera Flying boosts Hurricane to obscene levels while also giving it a resistance to Close Combat from the likes of Mega Lopunny and Zamazenta. Alternatively, Tera Ground gives Iron Jugulis a Stealth Rock resistance and gives it an easier time breaking through the likes of Mega Tyranitar and Clodsire. Iron Jugulis values pivots like Tapu Koko, Landorus-T, and Slowbro, as they provide it opportunities for it to come in and pressure Pokemon like Tangrowth and opposing Slowbro. Tapu Koko in particular is an astounding partner, as it enables Quark Drive for Iron Jugulis, which lets it outspeed Pokemon like Dragapult and Mega Lopunny. Slowbro also provides Future Sight to pressure Toxapex and Clodsire. Pokemon that can wear down checks to Iron Jugulis such as Assault Vest Tornadus-T and Ting-Lu with entry hazards like Landorus-T, Ferrothorn, and Heatran are appreciated. Entry hazard removers such as the aforementioned Tornadus-T and Rotom-W help compensate for Iron Jugulis's Stealth Rock weakness.

Booster Energy Attacker.description: Iron Moth is a great sweeper, since the combination of the Speed boost from Booster Energy, its colorful coverage moves, and boosts from Fiery Dance allows it to snowball easily. The potential Special Attack boost from Fiery Dance makes scouting the set of Iron Moth extremely dangerous. Energy Ball is for Rock-types like Mega Diancie and Water-types like Alomomola, Dondozo, and Urshifu-R. Dazzling Gleam threatens foes like Zamazenta and Garchomp with an OHKO at +1. Tera Blast with Tera Ground allows Iron Moth to OHKO Heatran, 2HKO Galarian Slowking or OHKO it at +1 with minor chip damage, and 2HKO Garganacl, meanwhile providing Iron Moth with a valuable immunity to Thunder Wave from the likes of Galarian Slowking and Ferrothorn. Tera Grass, on the other hand, gives Energy Ball a STAB boost, which can guarantee it OHKOes foes like Mega Diancie and Urshifu-R without a Fiery Dance boost. It also flips Iron Moth's weakness to Water- and Ground-types, easing the matchup versus Ogerpon-W and Garchomp. The Special Attack and Speed EVs give Iron Moth a Speed boost with Quark Drive, and the remainder goes to Defense instead of HP in order to better take priority moves like Fake Out from Mega Lopunny and Mega Medicham, Extreme Speed from Dragonite, Sucker Punch from Mega Mawile, and Aqua Jet from Urshifu-R after Terastallizing. Iron Moth appreciates teammates like Ogerpon-W and Landorus-T to pressure its common checks like Heatran and Galarian Slowking when not running Tera Ground. Additionally, Ogerpon-W can break Multiscale on Dragonite to give Iron Moth an easier clean. Landorus-T and Great Tusk can provide entry hazard control with Defog and Rapid Spin respectively to cover Iron Moth's weakness to Stealth Rock. Tapu Lele is also a great partner of Iron Moth since its Psychic Surge can protect Iron Moth from revenge killers like Mega Mawile, and the two of them can wear down their common checks like Galarian Slowking and Heatran for each other.

Offensive.description: With decent offensive stats, unique typing and wide movepool, Heavy-Duty Boots Iron Moth is a great offensive threat that is capable of checking popular threats such as Choice Specs Iron Valiant and Mega Scizor and keeps momentum up if needed. Fiery Dance is favored over other Fire-type moves because with its boost, Iron Moth is able to break through lesser sturdy checks like Gliscor. Energy Ball paired with Tera Grass is usually the first choice to reverse its matchup against Water-, Ground-, and Rock-type Pokemon such as Alomomola, Ting-Lu, and Garganacl. Dazzling Gleam boosted by Tera Fairy allows it to blow up Zamazenta, Dragon-type Pokemon like Garchomp and Raging Bolt that it otherwise struggles against. Tera Blast combined with Tera Ground lets it OHKO its biggest predator, Heatran, as well as hit popular special walls like Galarian Slowking and Toxapex for super effective damage. All three coverage moves also help Iron Moth beat Mega Tyranitar after it switches into entry hazards multiple times. The last slot is usually reserved for utility. U-turn takes advantage of Iron Moth's ability to lure in checks such as Galarian Slowking and Clodsire and pivots wallbreaker teammates like Mega Tyranitar and Mega Medicham in, aiding a more offensive playstyle; Morning Sun boosts Iron Moth's longevity, enabling it to stay healthy and check opposing Mega Scizor and Iron Valiant throughout the game. Because of its mediocre Base Power moves, Iron Moth often struggles with bulky walls; therefore, it appreciates hazard support from teammates like Gliscor, Hisuian Samurott, and Ferrothorn to chip at checks such as Heatran and Garganacl, while powerful wallbreakers such as Mega Medicham, Mega Tyranitar, and Weavile improve its matchup against sturdy walls that ignore hazard chip damage like Galarian Slowking, Toxapex, and Blissey. Mega Tyranitar and Weavile especially help in chipping and even eliminating those walls with Pursuit support, which often relieves the urgency for Iron Moth to use Tera as well. In return, Iron Moth can pressure and threaten physical walls like Slowbro and Great Tusk that its teammates have trouble with. Iron Moth also appreciates slow pivots that can bring it safely onto the field, such as Galarian Slowking and Alomomola.

Entry Hazard Setter.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Choice Specs.description: The set(s) displayed are currently up for reservation to be revamped; please check out the National Dex C&C thread for more information!

Swords Dance.description: Swords Dance Iron Valiant is both a powerful sweeper and revenge killer mainly seen on hyper offense teams. Its high Speed combined with Booster Energy allows it to outspeed +1 setup sweepers like Mega Gyarados, Gouging Fire, and Volcarona, as well as naturally fast targets like Mega Lopunny and Darkrai. The popularity of specially offensive Iron Valiant can allow this set to catch opponents off guard and give it a free opportunity to use Swords Dance against foes like Galarian Slowking. Swords Dance boosts Iron Valiant's power to dangerous levels, enabling it to OHKO foes neutral to Fighting like Corviknight and Alomomola with a favorable roll or minor chip damage. Knock Off provides valuable coverage for Psychic-types like Galarian Slowking and Iron Crown, and it can also take down walls like Ferrothorn and Garganacl after they use Tera Ghost. Encore can lock physically defensive walls like Alomomola and Landorus-T into recovery moves or status moves like Defog, which can give Iron Valiant a good chance to set up. Ice Punch is an alternative to Encore for Landorus-T and Dragonite. Tera Dark gives Knock Off a STAB boost, allowing it to do more damage to foes like Galarian Slowking and Zapdos. Tera Steel, on the other hand, provides Iron Valiant with resistances to common priority moves like Bullet Punch from Mega Scizor, Ice Shard from Weavile, and Extreme Speed from Dragonite, which can prevent it from being revenge killed. Tera Steel can also be paired with Encore to take advantage of Sludge Bomb from Galarian Slowking and Toxic from foes like Alomomola. Iron Valiant pairs well with teammates like Iron Boulder, Ogerpon-W, and Raging Bolt, since they can pressure common checks for it, such as Zapdos, Dragonite, and Dondozo. Iron Valiant is very fragile to priority moves due to its low bulk and the side effects of Close Combat, so Tapu Lele's Psychic Surge can protect it from priority moves and allow it to safely sweep. In addition, Tapu Lele and Iron Valiant can take care of each other's checks. Iron Valiant can break Galarian Slowking and Heatran, while Tapu Lele gives physical walls like Dondozo a hard time. Iron Valiant also appreciates other Knock Off users on its team to help wear down Unaware users like Dondozo and Skeledirge by removing their Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers.

Calm Mind.description: With a wide variety of special coverage moves and a great Speed stat, Calm Mind Iron Valiant is one of the best sweepers and cleaners in the tier. Speed Booster Energy allows it to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame, as well as setup sweepers like Mega Gyarados, Great Tusk, and Dragonite at +1 without being Choice locked. Moonblast is its most spammable STAB move, since most Steel-types are threatened by Focus Blast, leaving Galarian Slowking as one of its few reliable checks. Thunderbolt provides valuable coverage against Water-types like Alomomola and Toxapex, while Shadow Ball hits Galarian Slowking super effectively. Focus Blast is Iron Valiant's strongest STAB move, OHKOing common Steel-type walls at +1 such as Mega Scizor after a decent amount of chip damage, Ferrothorn, and Heatran. Encore prevents sweeps from setup Pokemon like Volcarona and lets Iron Valiant set up against Pokemon like Alomomola and Toxapex. Tera Electric makes Iron Valiant immune to paralysis from walls like Ferrothorn and Galarian Slowking while allowing Thunderbolt to OHKO Alomomola and specially defensive Toxapex after minimal chip at +1. Tera Ghost grants Iron Valiant a resistance to Poison-type moves and gives Shadow Ball a STAB boost, allowing it to better take advantage of its coverage and 2HKO Galarian Slowking with minimal chip or at +1. Tera Steel is a good defensive type that helps Iron Valiant set up on the likes of Alomomola and Choice-locked Tapu Lele and provides a resistance to priority moves such as Bullet Punch, Ice Shard, and Extreme Speed. It can also be paired with Encore to turn Galarian Slowking into setup fodder by locking it into Sludge Bomb. Iron Valiant appreciates teammates like Great Tusk, Dragonite, and Mega Scizor that overwhelm common special walls in Galarian Slowking, Heatran, and Blissey, letting it sweep. Knock Off support from the likes of Mega Scizor and Tyranitar is also appreciated, as removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Galarian Slowking, Blissey, and Toxapex and Leftovers from Heatran and Ferrothorn can help position Iron Valiant to sweep.

Choice Scarf.description: Due to its naturally high Speed and Choice Scarf, Iron Valiant outspeeds the entire metagame at +1 except for +1 Iron Boulder and Hawlucha with Unburden active, which makes it a solid cleaner and revenge killer. Close Combat is the preferred Fighting-type STAB move over Aura Sphere or Focus Blast because it can do more damage to foes like Heatran and Iron Boulder while maintaining strength and accuracy. Knock Off is an excellent way of making progress, as it can remove items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers on common walls like Galarian Slowking, Alomomola, and Landorus-T, and it can provide valuable coverage for Psychic-types like Galarian Slowking and Iron Crown. Trick is fantastic against more passive teams and can cripple switch-ins like Toxapex and Alomomola. It can also lock setup sweepers like Volcarona into one move, making them much easier to deal with. Destiny Bond, on the other hand, can be used as an emergency plan to trade with foes like Ogerpon-W and Gouging Fire, especially after they acquire several boosts. Tera Fairy can increase the power of Moonblast, guaranteeing a 2HKO against utility Tornadus-T and Zapdos and an OHKO against Zamazenta. Teammates like Hisuian Samurott and Ogerpon-W pair well with Iron Valiant, since they can pressure foes like Galarian Slowking and Alomomola. In addition, Hisuian Samurott can also stack Spikes via Ceaseless Edge, which greatly helps Iron Valiant with its lack of power, as it can often remove Heavy-Duty Boots from key targets such as Toxapex, Alomomola, and Galarian Slowking with Knock Off or Trick. Iron Valiant appreciates teammates like Mega Scizor and Zapdos to help it deal with Iron Boulder and Hawlucha, which are capable of outspeeding it.

Swords Dance.description: Ogerpon, similar to its masked counterparts, occupies a niche as a Swords Dance wallbreaker and sweeper, but with a few tricks up its sleeve. Ogerpon’s unique Speed boost upon Terastallizing and ability to hold an item give it more potential to clean through a weakened team while outrunning common revenge killers such as Choice Scarf Tapu Lele and Kartana. However, Ogerpon faces stiff competition from other offensive Grass-types such as Rillaboom and Kartana, as well as the other Ogerpon formes that possess a beneficial dual typing and an automatic 1.2x boost to their attacks. Superpower allows Ogerpon to wreak havoc on defensive cores using Ferrothorn and Heatran as Grass-type switch-ins, scoring a clean OHKO on Heatran and heavily denting physically defensive Ferrothorn after a Swords Dance. Meadow Plate is the item of choice, OHKOing Gliscor after Swords Dance with Stealth Rock chip, as well as potentially OHKOing Toxapex after Tera Grass and Swords Dance. Knock Off is Ogerpon's strongest option to hit Tornadus-T, Moltres, Zapdos, and Galarian Slowking. Additionally, Defiant leverages Landorus-T's Intimidate against it; however, its poor matchup versus Defog users such as Zapdos, Tornadus-T, and Corviknight render it unable to effectively switch in on Defog attempts and activate Defiant. Teammates that match up effectively into these aforementioned Defog users, such as Ting Lu, Mega Tyranitar, and Gliscor, serve as quality teammates, with Mega Tyranitar in particular being able to chip these foes into range of Ogerpon's attacks. Skarmory and Corviknight are also major roadblocks for Ogerpon, so teammates that can switch into them and force progress like Zapdos and Heatran make for effective teammates.

Swords Dance Ogerpon-W is an incredibly dangerous wallbreaker and sweeper thanks to its ability to take advantage of defensive staples like Alomomola and Ting-Lu, the power boost from Wellspring Mask, and its good Speed tier. Swords Dance amps up Ogerpon-W's power to dangerous levels, most notably OHKOing standard Ferrothorn with Superpower and 2HKOing defensive Zapdos and Toxapex with Ivy Cudgel and Power Whip, respectively. Power Whip is a more threatening STAB option thanks to its high Base Power, but Horn Leech lets Ogerpon-W offset any Toxic damage from Toxapex and Alomomola, letting it set up on the pair. Superpower hits Steel-types like Ferrothorn and Archaludon, OHKOing them at +2. Alternatively, Encore lets Ogerpon-W gain setup opportunities against passive foes like Ferrothorn and Toxapex using status moves. With Tera Water, Ogerpon-W not only gets a huge boost to Ivy Cudgel's power, but also gains a Special Defense boost, which can help stave off revenge killing attempts from threats like Tornadus-T and Iron Valiant. Ogerpon-W can struggle with Grass-types like Kartana and Ferrothorn, especially if lacking Superpower, so teammates like Heatran and Tornadus-T are greatly appreciated. Heatran also sets Stealth Rock to help Ogerpon-W defeat its answers that lack recovery, like Raging Bolt and Archaludon if Ogerpon-W lacks Superpower, over a longer period of time if it cannot brute-force its way through them. Tornadus-T, meanwhile, can remove entry hazards to improve Ogerpon-W's longevity as well as remove crucial items like Leftovers from defensive stops like Toxapex and Raging Bolt. Its Nasty Plot set also appreciates Ogerpon-W's ability to take advantage of specially defensive walls like Ting-Lu and Chansey. Offensive teammates like Tapu Lele, Iron Valiant, Weavile, and Mega Tyranitar can deal with Dragon-types like the aforementioned Raging Bolt and Dragonite; Weavile and Mega Tyranitar in particular can Pursuit trap said Dragon-types, opening Ogerpon-W up to sweeping. Despite having a good Speed tier, Ogerpon-W is vulnerable to being revenge killed by faster threats like Iron Boulder and Mega Lopunny; as such, teammates that can switch into these threats, like Landorus-T and Gliscor, are highly appreciated. Additionally, teammates that offensively pressure these revenge killers, like Zamazenta and Great Tusk, are good choices to pair with Ogerpon-W.

With a good Speed tier, access to Sturdy, and a good offensive profile, Ogerpon-C cements itself as a solid option for hyper offense teams; it also fits on any team that can reliably keep entry hazards off the field, as Sturdy allows it to act as an emergency button when faced with a setup sweeper such as Volcarona or Mega Gyarados. However, Ogerpon-C should be mindful about using its Tera, as this removes its Sturdy for an arguably worse +1 Defense. Power Whip is used for its higher Base Power, which reduces Ogerpon-C's reliance on Swords Dance for immediate power, while Horn Leech trades damage for healing and reliability. Superpower allows Ogerpon-C to hit Ferrothorn, although this breaks Sturdy, along with Tera Steel foes like Iron Valiant. Ogerpon-C's main weakness lies in its reliance on Sturdy to set up against more powerful foes and its lack of immediate power before setting up. Thus, it is better off being saved as a cleaner for the later stages of a game. Entry hazard support, in particular Spikes, is highly valued to allow Ogerpon-C to KO many more threats; it can capitalize on hazard chip, for instance KOing even bulky foes like defensive Great Tusk unboosted once they are chipped. Thus, allies that can set hazards early-game like Hisuian Samurott and Garchomp are good partners. Ogerpon-C is also held back by its middling Speed tier, which leaves it susceptible to being revenge killed by Mega Lopunny, as it is capable of bypassing Sturdy, along with many other foes like Iron Valiant if Ogerpon-C has already lost Sturdy. Thus, Pokemon like Choice Scarf Tapu Lele that can threaten these frailer foes make for good allies.

Rain Wallbreaker.description: Thanks to its great typing, good bulk, and signature move Electro Shot, Archaludon is born to be an excellent wallbreaker on rain teams. The dual STAB moves and Electro Shot are must-haves for Archaludon as a rain wallbreaker; the last slot, however, is a bit flexible. Body Press and Aura Sphere both complement Archaludon's coverage to break through Steel-type Pokemon such as Ferrothorn and Heatran. The former receives a boost from Stamina and deals with Heatran and Ting-Lu better, while the latter is more consistent with Electro Shot boosts in rain and avoids chip damage from Iron Barbs. Stealth Rock can be used as an alternative choice on non-Assault Vest sets to allow teammates like Mega Swampert to run coverage moves like Ice Punch and Ferrothorn to run Spikes. Archaludon can threaten premier entry hazard removers such as Tornadus-T and Landorus-T, ensuring Stealth Rock stays up. Depending on the pacing of the team, different items and EV spreads are available for Archaludon. Leftovers is used to increase its longevity, which helps long-term. Eject Pack can be favored to keep the momentum up by preventing Archaludon from being stuck on the field against pivots such as Galarian Slowking and Assault Vest Iron Crown after its Special Attack is lowered by Draco Meteor. Assault Vest makes up for Archaludon's weak Special Defense and often lets it trade with one or more offensive threats like Tapu Lele and Iron Moth. To pair with Assault Vest, a bulky spread of 204 HP EVs is used, while 52 Speed EVs still allow Archaludon to outspeed uninvested Landorus-T. Tera Flying provides an immunity to Ground-type moves from Landorus-T and Garchomp and a resistance to Fighting-type moves from the likes of Zamazenta. Tera Fairy also grants a resistance to Fighting-type moves and is a better defensive type overall due to only having a few weaknesses as well as not being weak to Stealth Rock. Pelipper is a necessary teammate, as its Drizzle enables Archaludon to take advantage of Electro Shot. Other Water-type wallbreakers such as Mega Swampert and Ogerpon-W are also appreciated for their ability to break through bulky Ground-type Pokemon like Ting-Lu and Gliscor. In return, those Water-type wallbreakers appreciate Archaludon's ability to beat opposing Ogerpon-W.

Offensive Dragon Dance.description: Gouging Fire is a devastating wallbreaker and setup sweeper alike that can tear through teams easily. Earthquake allows Gouging Fire to break past Toxapex and Heatran, which would otherwise be able to wall it. Morning Sun gives Gouging Fire the ability to heal off any chip damage from priority or Rocky Helmet, making it even more difficult to take down for defensive teams. Outrage can be used as a nuke with Dragonium Z, letting Gouging Fire muscle past walls such as Dondozo through its sheer strength alone. Tera Ground can be used to power up Gouging Fire's Earthquake while allowing it to remove its weaknesses to revenge killers such as Booster Energy Iron Boulder and Great Tusk, allowing it to potentially win on the spot. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Gouging Fire to come in many times and attempt to set up, while Booster Energy gives Gouging Fire a one-time Attack boost that can be crucial in breaking past foes such as Great Tusk and Landorus-T while still allowing Gouging Fire to Terastallize. Teammates that struggle with Steel-types, like Tapu Lele and Pecharunt, appreciate Gouging Fire breaking through those Steel-types. In return, they dispatch the physical walls that trouble Gouging Fire, such as Dondozo. Gouging Fire is often prone to getting revenge killed by Pokemon such as Iron Boulder and Choice Scarf Tapu Lele, so teammates that can deal with the aforementioned threats, like Mega Scizor and Landorus-T, are appreciated.

Bulky Dragon Dance.description: Gouging Fire is a great setup sweeper that utilizes its good bulk, solid defensive typing, and Terastallization to exploit common Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y, Volcarona, Mega Scizor, and Alomomola and break through teams efficiently. Flare Blitz is reliable STAB into Pokemon like Zamazenta and Great Tusk; however, Heat Crash can be used for its lack of recoil, though its variable Base Power makes it harder to break through the aforementioned Pokemon. Earthquake lets Gouging Fire hit Heatran, Raging Bolt, and Toxapex. Morning Sun provides reliable recovery, letting Gouging Fire maintain a sweep, check Pokemon like Mega Charizard Y and Iron Valiant long term, and offset Flare Blitz recoil. The given EV spread lets Gouging Fire take Scorching Sands twice at full HP from Mega Charizard Y and outspeed Tornadus-T at +1. Tera Steel turns would-be checks to Gouging Fire like Alomomola and Raging Bolt into setup fodder while also providing a Toxic immunity. Teammates like Ogerpon-W and Tapu Lele that struggle against Steel-types like Kartana and Mega Scizor appreciate Gouging Fire checking and setting up on them. Gouging Fire also provides a good matchup into sun teams, which offensive teammates like Mega Lopunny and Kartana appreciate as well. In return, the latter threatens Water-types like Alomomola and other Pokemon that check Gouging Fire like Ting-Lu and Great Tusk.

Choice Band.description: Choice Band Gouging Fire is a potent wallbreaker and cleaner commonly found on sun teams. Under sun, Tera Fire makes Heat Crash a very powerful and spammable move. Flare Blitz allows Gouging Fire to hit heavier Pokemon that Gouging Fire can't hit as hard with Heat Crash, like Great Tusk and Ting-Lu. Raging Fury is an alternative option to this, as it is not a contact move and does not deal recoil damage. 168 Attack EVs and a Jolly Nature allow it to gain a Speed boost under sun with Protosynthesis. Even with this combination, Gouging Fire is still stopped by heavier foes that are also very physically bulky, such as Garganacl, Great Tusk and Dondozo. Choice Band Gouging Fire is also very prone to entry hazard chip, as it does not hold Heavy-Duty Boots. Because of these reasons, Gouging Fire largely appreciates hazard removal options like Great Tusk and Iron Treads that also synergize well with sun setters, which are Torkoal and Mega Charizard Y. Great Tusk is great under sun as it can be a good wallbreaking partner with an Attack Protosynthesis boost. Great Tusk is also able to help wallbreak against some other Fire-resistant foes, such as Garganacl, chipped Alomomola, and opposing Great Tusk. Iron Treads , on the other hand, has Volt Switch to bring Gouging Fire in safely. Gouging Fire also greatly appreciates Pokemon that can threaten Alomomola and Dondozo on their weaker Special Defense side, like Raging Bolt and Mega Charizard Y. Raging Bolt can threaten Gouging Fire's common switch-ins like Dondozo and Alomomola with powerful Special attacks and super effective STAB moves and also use Volt Switch to bring Gouging Fire in very easily. Gouging Fire also supports Raging Bolt by threatening the Ground-types and Electric-resistant foes that can switch into it, such as Gliscor, Ferrothorn, Landorus-T. Mega Charizard Y is one of Gouging Fire's best partners, as it sets up sun with Drought, allowing Gouging Fire to boost its Speed with Protosynthesis, and can also break holes into opposing teams with Solar Beam and powerful Fire-type moves.

Calm Mind.description: With access to Calm Mind and a stellar base 137 Special Attack, Raging Bolt is able to act as an excellent bulky setup sweeper. Raging Bolt’s good typing allows it to break through defensive Pokemon like Corviknight and bulky Water-types like Alomomola, Toxapex, and Rotom-W while also checking threats like Rillaboom, Ogerpon-W, and Kartana. Thunderclap offsets Raging Bolt’s subpar Speed stat, allowing it to revenge kill offensive threats such as Urshifu-R, Ogerpon-W, and Mega Lopunny as well as weakened setup sweepers like Iron Boulder, Volcarona, and Swords Dance Kartana, while Thunderbolt gives Raging Bolt a consistent damaging attack that doesn’t rely on prediction like Thunderclap and has significantly higher PP, allowing Raging Bolt to use its Electric-type moves in longer games. Substitute is an alternative to nullify passive Pokémon that can’t touch Raging Bolt such as Rotom-W, Ferrothorn, and Zapdos and give it more opportunities to set up, while Taunt can be used to deny setup from Garganacl and Mega Scizor but at the cost of a worse matchup against Galarian Slowking. Draco Meteor in tandem with Dragonium Z lets it break through Electric-immune Pokemon such as Gliscor, Clodsire, and Ting-Lu as well as other specially bulky Pokémon that can take on Raging Bolt such as Mega Tyranitar and Galarian Slowking. Alternatively, Leftovers is also an option on Substitute sets to passively heal the chip taken from Substitute and give Raging Bolt some form of recovery. Tera Flying grants Raging Bolt a Ground immunity while giving a Fighting resistance that helps against Great Tusk and Zamazenta while also avoiding any Ground-type coverage from Serperior. Tera Fairy gives this same Fighting resistance while giving Raging Bolt an immunity to Dragon-type moves from the likes of Garchomp and Gouging Fire. The given EV spread allows Raging Bolt to live a +2 Superpower from Ogerpon-W after Stealth Rock, as well as outspeeding uninvested Landorus-T. Raging Bolt struggles against fast Ground- and Fairy-types like Garchomp, Choice Scarf Landorus-T, Great Tusk, Tapu Koko, Iron Valiant, and especially Tapu Lele; Tapu Lele in particular can give Raging Bolt some trouble as well, as its Psychic Surge renders Thunderclap useless. Teammates like Mega Scizor, Ferrothorn, Rillaboom, and Galarian Slowking help beat these checks. Since Raging Bolt has no reliable recovery, Alomomola is a good partner to pass huge HP wishes to it and pivot it in. Other pivots like Tornadus-T, Mega Scizor, and Landorus-T also help bring Raging Bolt in safely. Teammates like Great Tusk and Zamazenta appreciate Raging Bolt taking care of Flying-types like Tornadus-T and Zapdos as well as bulky Waters like Rotom-W and Alomomola.
